Any remains, trace, or imprint of a plant or animal that has been preserved in the Earth's crust since some past geologic or prehistoric time.
The energy-containing materials which were converted over many thousands of years from their original form of trees, plants and other organisms after being buried in the ground.
An internal combustion engine whose cycle is completed in four piston strokes; includes a suction stroke, compression stroke, expansion stroke, and exhaust stroke.
A body of rules prescribed by a government, often composed in a series of inter-related parts, to establish or lay the foundation for a new project, agency or organizational structure.\n(Source: RHW)
The ability, right and permission to approach and use, or the general availability of resources that convey knowledge.
Transportation of goods by ship, aircraft or other vehicles.
Trade name for a group of polyhalogenated hydrocarbons containing fluorine and chlorine; an example is trichlorofluoromethane.
Water having a relatively low mineral content, generally less than 500 mg/l of dissolved solids.

The scientific study of the characteristic life processes of living organisms found in a natural body of water that does not contain significant amounts of dissolved salts and minerals, such as a lake or river.
The living organisms and nonliving materials of an inland aquatic environment.
Organism which lives in freshwater.\n\n(Source: PHC)

Any insectivorous anuran amphibian of the family Ranidae, such as Rana temporaria of Europe, having a short squat tailless body with a moist smooth skin and very long hind legs specialized for hopping.
A deposit of interlocking ice crystals formed by direct sublimation on objects.\n(Source: MGH)

1. A fully matured plant ovary with or without other floral or shoot parts united with it at maturity.
2. A botanical fruit that can be eaten raw used as food.
Cultivation of fruit trees for home consumption or on a commercial basis.
Any tree that bears edible fruit.\n(Source: CED)
Solid, liquid, or gaseous material such as gas, gasoline, oil, coal or wood, used to produce heat or power by burning.
Substance (such as tetraethyl lead) which is added to petrol to prevent knocking.
Alternative source of energy for motor vehicles. It is produced by fermentation of sugar cane by the yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae.\n(Source: DICCHE)
The amount of fuel utilized.\n(Source: PHCa)
A liquid product burned to generate heat, exclusive of oils with a flash point below 38C; includes heating oils, stove oils, furnace oils, bunker fuel oils.\n(Source: MGH)
Wood used for heating.

Solids in the air that have been generated by the condensation of vapors, chemical reactions or sublimation (a direct change from solid to gas). Often metallic oxides or metals, these particles are less than 1 micrometer in diameter and may be toxic.\n(Source: ALL)

The use of a chemical compound in a gaseous state to kill insects, nematodes, arachnids, rodents, weeds, and fungi in confined or inaccessible locations; also used to control weeds, nematodes, and insects in the field.
A substance from the point of view of its function or purpose, for example a painting agent or a preserving substance.
Nucleated usually filamentous, sporebearing organisms devoid of chlorophyll.
Nucleated usually filamentous, sporebearing organism devoid of chlorophyll.
A chemical used to kill or halt the development of fungi that cause plant disease.
The hair-covered, dressed pelt of a mammal, used in the making of garments and as trimming or decoration.
Animal bred and slaughtered for its fur.
A colourless flammable toxic liquid heterocyclic compound, used in the synthesis of nylon.\n(Source: CED)
A structure or apparatus in which heat is produced by the combustion of fuel, often to warm houses, melt metals, produce steam and bake pottery.

1. The movable articles in a room or an establishment that make it fit for living or working.
2. A movable object (such as a table, chair, lamp) inside a dwelling, that is useful or decorative.
The business or trade of dressed furs and garments made from the coats of certain animals.
A form of electromagnetic radiation or light emission of frequencies produced by sub-atomic particle interactions, such as electron-positron annihilation or radioactive decay.

1. A piece of land next to a house where flowers and other plants are grown and which often has an area of grass.
2. To grow plants in a garden; to create or maintain a garden.
Natural organic matter discarded from gardens and yards including leaves, grass clippings, prunings, brush and stumps.
Mediterranean bush consisting of low evergreen shrubs and abundant herbaceous plants.

1. A substance that continues to occupy in a continuous manner the whole of the space in which it is placed, however large or small this place is made, the temperature remaining constant.
2. A fuel for internal combustion engines consisting essentially of volatile flammable liquid hydrocarbons derived from crude petroleum.
3. To show off.

A separation technique involving passage of a gaseous moving phase through a column containing a fixed phase; it is used principally as a quantitative analytical technique for volatile compounds.\n(Source: MGH)
Company charged with the production and distribution of gas for domestic use.\n(Source: RRDA)
An internal combustion engine that uses gaseous fuel.
State of matter in which the matter concerned occupies the whole of its container irrespective of its quantity.\n(Source: DICCHE)
Any chemical or heat process used to convert a substance to a gas.
Conversion of a gas to the liquid phase by cooling or compression.
Mixture of two or more different gases.
Interconnected system of pipes for the distribution and supply of gas.
A mixture of 80% or 90% petrol with 20% or 10% ethyl alcohol, for use as a fuel in internal combustion engines.
An internal combustion engine that uses a mixture of air and gasoline vapour as a fuel.
A long pipe, especially underground, used to transport gas over long distances.
Power station which burns gas, as opposed to a coal-fired station or nuclear power station.
Removal of pollutants or contaminants from waste incineration or other combustion processes.\n(Source: MGHa)
Large tank for storing coal gas or natural gas.\n(Source: PHC)
The provision and storage of any fuel gas, for the use of a municipality, or other fuel gas user.
Any mollusc of the class Gastropoda, typically having a flattened muscular foot for locomotion and a head that bears stalked eyes.
Storehouse of seeds or vegetative tissue, kept in low humidity and temperature, to help maintain genetic diversity.
The study of the elements and the compounds they form.

A unit of heredity composed of DNA occupying a fixed position on a chromosome. A gene may determine a characteristic of an individual by specifying a polypeptide chain that forms a protein or part of a protein (structural gene); or repress such operation (repressor gene).\n(Source: CED)
The variation between individuals and between populations within a species.
Inheritable change, chiefly mutations produced by chemical substances, herbicides, radiations, etc.

1) The complex of techniques for the production of new genes and the alteration of the structure of the chromosomes to produce effects beneficial to man, in agriculture and medicine.\n2) The intentional production of new genes and alteration of genomes by the substitution or addition of new genetic material.\n(Source: ZINZAN /  MGH)
The information for protein synthesis contained in the nucleotide sequences of the DNA polynucleotide chain.\n(Source: RRDA)
Inheritable changes produced by ionizing radiation, exposure to certain chemicals, ingestion of some medication and from other causes.\n(Source: CONFER)

The gene pool in natural and cultivated stocks of organisms that are available for human exploitation. It is desirable to maintain as diverse a range of organisms as possible, particularly of domesticated cultivars and their ancestors, in order to maintain a wide genetic base. The wider the genetic base, the greater the capacity for adaptation to particular environmental conditions.\n(Source: ALL2)
The science that is concerned with the study of biological inheritance.
Change in one or more phenotypic characteristics, due to gene mutation or rearrangement, environmental effects, etc.

A subdivision of geophysics which includes determination of the size and shape of the earth, the earth's gravitational field, and the location of points fixed to the earth's crust in an earth-referred coordinate system.
Factors which originate in the soil, as opposed to those of anthropic origin (anthropogenic).\n(Source: RRDA)

An organized collection of computer hardware, software, geographic data, and personnel designed to efficiently capture, store, update, manipulate, analyze, and display all forms of geographically referenced information that can be drawn from different sources, both statistical and mapped.
The study of the natural features of the earth's surface, comprising topography, climate, soil, vegetation, etc. and man's response to them.
The study or science of the earth, its history, and its life as recorded in the rocks.

The study of the classification, description, nature, origin, and development of present landforms and their relationships to underlying structures, and of the history of geologic changes as recorded by these surface features.
The physics of the earth and its environment, that is, earth, air and space.
The application of scientific methods and engineering techniques to the exploitation and use of natural resources.

An energy produced by tapping the earth's internal heat. At present, the only available technologies to do this are those that extract heat from hydrothermal convection systems, where water or steam transfer the heat from the deeper part of the earth to the areas where the energy can be tapped. The amount of pollutants found in geothermal vary from area to area but may contain arsenic, boron, selenium, lead, cadmium, and fluorides. They also may contain hydrogen sulphide, mercury, ammonia, radon, carbon dioxide, and methane.\n(Source: KOREN)

1. A pathogenic micro-organism.
2. Living substance capable of developing into an organ, part, or organism as a whole; a primordium.
The beginning or the process of development of a spore or seed.
The hereditary material transmitted to the offspring via the gametes.
Slow moving masses of ice which have accumulated either on mountains or in polar regions.
The study of all aspects of snow and ice, and in particular of existing glaciers, ice sheets, and their physical properties.

1. A hard, amorphous, inorganic, usually transparent, brittle substance made by fusing silicates, sometimes borates and phosphates, with certain basic oxides and then rapidly cooling to prevent crystallization.
2. A surface that reflects light.
3. A vessel (especially one made of glass) from which drinks may be drunk.
4. A smooth surface, usually made of glass with reflective material painted on the underside, that reflects light so as to give an image of what is in front of it.
5. An addictive psychoactive drug of formula CHN.
Industry for the production of glassware.\n(Source: CED)
Changes in the surface-air temperature, referred to as the global temperature, brought about by the greenhouse effect which is induced by emission of greenhouse gases into the air.
An alphabetical list of terms concerned with a particular subject, field or area of usage that includes accompanying definitions.
Substance used for sticking objects together.

1. A game played on a large open course, the object of which is to hit a ball using clubs, with as few strokes as possible, into each of usually 18 holes.
2. To play golf.
Edible, starchy seeds of the grass family (Graminae) usable as food by man and his livestock.

1. A very large and widespread family of Monocotyledoneae, with more than 10.000 species, most of which are herbaceous, but a few are woody. The stems are jointed, the long, narrow leaves originating at the nodes. The flowers are inconspicuous, with a much reduced perianth, and are wind-pollinated or cleistogamous.
2. A drug prepared from the cannabis plant, that is smoked or ingested for its euphoric effect.
A conflagration in or destroying large areas of any vegetation in the Gramineae family as found in fields, meadows, savannas or other grasslands.
A plant-eating insect with long back legs that can jump very high and makes a sharp high noise using its back legs or wings.
An area where the vegetation is dominated by grasses and other herbaceous plants.

The interacting system of the biological communities located in biomes characterized by the dominance of indigenous grasses, grasslike plants and forbs, and their non-living environmental surroundings.\n(Source: TOE / DOE)

1. To have an unwanted negative influence on someone, to be distractive to or for someone, impress someone or something in a troublesome or uneasy way.
2. A mixture of rock fragments and pebbles that is coarser than sand.\n(Source: CED)
3. To make someone rather angry or impatient; to cause annoyance.
A place where gravel is dug out of the ground.
The vegetation on pastures that is available for livestock to feed upon.
An area of land around an urban area that is protected from large-scale housing.

Avenues along which wide-ranging animals can travel, plants can propagate, genetic interchange can occur, populations can move in response to environmental changes and natural disasters, and threatened species can be replenished from other areas.

An amount of money demanded by a government to finance clean-up, prevention, reduction, enforcement or educational efforts intended to promote ecological integrity and the conservation of natural resources.
Cultivation of plants, especially of out-of-season plants, in glass-enclosed, climate-controlled structures.\n(Source: MGH)

The warming of the Earth's atmosphere caused by the increasing concentration of atmospheric gases, such as water vapour and carbon dioxide. These gases absorb radiation emitted by the Earth, thus slowing down the loss of radiant energy from the Earth back to space.
A component of the atmosphere that influences the greenhouse effect, namely carbon dioxide, methane, nitrous oxides, ozone, CFCs and water vapour.
Herbaceous plant material plowed into the soil while still green.
The development of high-yield strains of wheat, corn and rice during the 1960s and early 1970s to increase the food supplies and solve the world's hunger problems.
A plot of vegetated land separating or surrounding areas of intensive residential or industrial use and devoted to recreation or park uses.
A vegetable having the edible parts rich in chlorophyll and forming an important source of vitamins and micronutrients.
The process of reducing an object to powder or small fragments.
Value of all goods and services produced in a country in one year, plus income earned by its citizens abroad, minus income earned by foreigners in the country.
Water that occupies pores and crevices in rock and soil, below the surface and above a layer of impermeable material.

The process, deliberate or inadvertent, of extracting ground water from a source at a rate so in excess of the replenishment that the ground water level declines persistently, threatening exhaustion of the supply or at least a decline of pumping levels to uneconomic depths.
An inlet of the sea of large areal proportions, more indented than a bay and generally more enclosed.
Any seed-bearing plant of the division Gymnospermae, in which the ovules are borne naked on the surface of the mega sporophylls, which are often arranged in cones.
A colourless or white mineral used in the building industry and in the manufacture of cement, rubber, paper and plaster of Paris.

The locality in which a plant or animal naturally grows or lives. It can be either the geographical area over which it extends, or the particular station in which a specimen is found.\n2) A physical portion of the environment that is inhabited by an organism or population of organisms. A habitat is characterized by a relative uniformity of the physical environment and fairly close interaction of all the biological species involved. In terms of region, a habitat may comprise a desert, a tropical forest, a prairie field, the Arctic Tundra or the Arctic Ocean.\n(Source: WRIGHT /  GILP)

1. Precipitation in the form of balls or irregular lumps of ice.
2. To fall from the clouds in form of ball or lumps of ice.
The time required for one-half the atoms of a given amount of radioactive material to undergo radioactive decay.

A haloalkane, containing three halogen atoms, e.g. iodoform, CHI3; a haloform reaction is a reaction to produce haloforms from a ketone. For example, if propanone is treated with bleaching powder, the chlorinated ketone so formed reacts to form chloroform.\n(Source: UVAROV)
Halogen derivatives of biphenyl.

One of a group of halogen derivatives of organic hydrogen and carbon containing compounds; the group includes monohalogen compounds (alkyl or aryl halides) and polyhalogen compounds that contain the same or different halogen atoms.
Halogen derivatives of phenol.

1. To maintain (a theory, thoughts, or feelings).
2. To secretly shelter (as of fugitives or criminals).
3. To keep in one's possession; of animals.
Resistance of a solid to indentation, scratching, abrasion or cutting.\n(Source: MGH)

1. The amount or measure of the crop gathered in a season.
2. To gather the ripened crop.
3. The process of gathering the ripened crop.
A physical or chemical agent capable of causing harm to persons, property, animals, plants or other natural resources.

1. Reduced visibility in the air as a result of condensed water vapour, dust, etc., in the atmosphere.\n(Source: CED)
2. Meteorologic phenomenon consisting of a big number of dry and extremely small particles (dust, sand, smoke) in suspension and carried by the air, so that visibility is considerably reduced (aprox. between 1 and 5 kms). It occurs when the relative humidity is below 70-80%. It has an opalescent color.
A state of dynamic equilibrium between an organism and its environment in which all functions of mind and body are normal.

1. The prevention, treatment, and management of illness and the preservation of mental and physical well being through the services offered by the medical, nursing, and allied health professions.
2. Treatment done for a patient in order to alleviate his pain and to heal him.
A facility or location where medical, dental, surgical, or nursing attention or treatment is provided to humans or animals.

A body of rules or orders prescribed by government or management to promote or protect the soundness of human bodies and minds in the workplace, at home or in the general environment.\n(Source: BLD / RHW)

A decrease in strength or any abnormality or partial or complete loss of hearing or of the function of ear, or hearing system, due directly \nor secondarily to pathology or injury; it may be either temporary or permanent.
The total of measures and devices implemented to preserve persons from harm to the faculty of perceiving sound.
An apparatus that heats or provides heat.
An area with poor acid soil, typically dominated by ling (Calluna) or heaths (Erica).
A system for supplying heat to a building.
A device which transfers heat from a cooler reservoir to a hotter one, expending mechanical energy in the process.
The provision of heating fuel, coal or other heating source materials, or the amount of heating capacity, for the use of a municipality, or other heat user.\n(Source: ISEP)
A metal whose specific gravity is approximately 5.0 kg/l or higher.
A line of closely planted bushes or shrubs, marking the boundaries of a property.
A chemical that controls or destroys undesirable plants.
An animal that feeds on plants.
Compound in which the ring structure is a combination of more than one kind of atom.
Study beyond secondary school at an institution that offers programs terminating in undergraduate and graduate degrees.\n(Source: COE)
The mountain part that exceeds the 1500 meters of altitude.
Railway track designed so that trains can travel at speeds in excess of 200 km/h.
Train travelling at maximum speeds of 320 km/h on special high-speed rail lines.
An electric line with a voltage on the order of thousands of volts.

1. A public road especially an important road that joins cities or towns together.
2. A wide road built for fast moving traffic travelling long distances, with a limited number of points at which drivers can enter and leave it.
A natural elevation of the land surface, usually rounded.
The study of events in relation to their development over time.\n(Source: GOOD)
Place where significant historical events occurred and which is important to an indigenous culture or a community.\n(Source: LANDYa)

1. A systematic written account comprising a chronological record of events (as affecting a city, state, nation, institution, science, or art) and usually including a philosophical explanation of the cause and origin of such events.
2. The scientific study of events from a time-related perspective and the passing on of the knowledge obtained by this study for the purpose of education.
3. the past events concerned in the development of a particular place, object, subject etc.
A day on which work is suspended by law or custom, such as a religious festival, bank holiday, etc.
A large animal with four legs of the Equus caballus species which people ride on or use for carrying things or pulling vehicles.
The art and science of growing plants.
A place where people who are ill or injured are treated and taken care of by doctors and nurses.
Solid waste, both biological and non-biological, produced by hospitals and discarded and not intended for further use.
The industry related with the provision of lodging and usually meals and other services for travelers and other paying guests.
Water that has been heated.

1. A group of persons sharing a home or living space, who aggregate and share their incomes, as evidenced by the fact that they regularly take meals together.
2. Found in or having its origin in a home.
Dwelling-houses collectively.
The number of dwelling units or the residential population of a given geographic area.
An addition, renovation or repair to a place of residence that increases its aesthetic, functional or financial value.

A norm or measure applicable in legal cases and considered to reflect a relatively high grade or level of excellence in the construction, maintenance, operation, occupancy, use or appearance of dwelling units.\n(Source: BLD)
The study of human life and character.
The study of the growth, distribution, and organization of human communities relative to their interrelationships with other humans and other species and with their environment.
The avoidance of disease and injury and the promotion of normalcy through efficient use of the environment, a properly functioning society, and an inner sense of well-being.\n(Source: KOREN)
Violent, sudden and destructive change in the environment caused by man.
Branch of medicine concerned with the cause, origin, and nature of disease, including the changes occurring as a result of disease.\n(Source: CED)
A branch of biological sciences that studies the functions of organs and tissues in human beings.\n(Source: OMD / WOR)
Cities, towns, villages, and other concentrations of human populations which inhabit a given segment or area of the environment.

1. The more or less decomposed organic matter in the soil.
2. Earth formed by the decay of vegetable matter.
3. A popular dish in the Middle East that consists of cooked, mashed chickpeas, blended with tahini, olive oil, lemon juice, salt and garlic.
The pursuit and killing or capture of wild animals.
A tropical cyclone of great intensity; any wind reaching a speed of more than 73 miles per hour (117 kilometers per hour) is said to have hurricane force.
A branch of civil engineering concerned with the design, erection, and construction of sewage disposal plants, waterworks, dams, water-operated power plants and such.
The branch of science and technology concerned with the mechanics of fluids, especially liquids.
Study of organisms living in water.\n(Source: ZINZAN)
A very large group of chemical compounds composed only of carbon and hydrogen.\n(Source: MGH)
A solution of hydrogen chloride gas in water.
Cultivation of plants without soil but in sand or vermiculite or other granular material, using a liquid solution of nutrients to feed them.
Power station which operates with the free renewable source of energy provided by falling water.

A flammable colourless gas that is the lightest and most abundant element in the universe. It occurs mainly in water and in most organic compounds and is used in the production of ammonia and other chemicals, in the hydrogenation of fats and oils, and in welding.
The science dealing with the occurrence of surface and ground water, its utilization, and its functions in modifying the earth, primarily by erosion and deposition.

Science which deals with the measurement and description of the physical features of the oceans, lakes, rivers, and their adjoining coastal areas, with particular reference to their control and utilization.

An accounting of the inflow to, outflow from, and storage in a hydrologic unit such as a drainage basin, aquifer, soil zone, lake or reservoir; the relationship between evaporation, precipitation, runoff, and the change in water storage.
The movement of water between the oceans, ground surface and atmosphere by evaporation, precipitation and the activity of living organisms.

1. The science that treats the occurrence, circulation, distribution, and properties of the waters of the earth, and their reaction with the environment.
2. The science that treats the occurrence, circulation, distribution, and properties of the waters of the earth, and their reaction with the environment.\n(Source: MGH)

Decomposition or alteration of a chemical substance by water; in aqueous solutions of electrolytes, the reactions of cations with water to produce a weak base or of anions to produce a weak acid.\n(Source: MGH)

That part of meteorology of direct concern to hydrologic problems, particularly to flood control, hydroelectric power, irrigation, and similar fields of engineering and water resource.\n(Source: ZINZAN)
Energy obtained from natural or artificial waterfalls, either directly by turning a water wheel or turbine, or indirectly by generating electricity in a dynamo driven by a turbine.
All the waters of the Earth, as distinguished from the rocks, living things , and the air.

1. A set of practices associated with the preservation of health, the prevention and fighting of diseases and healthy living.
2. The study and use of practical measures for the preservation of public health.
Insects including bees, wasps, ants, and sawflies, having two pair of membranous wings and an ovipositor specialized for stinging, sawing or piercing.\n(Source: CED)

1. The dense substance formed by the freezing of water to the solid state; it commonly occurs in the form of hexagonal crystals.
2. To cool with ice.
3. An addictive psychoactive drug of formula CHN.
A large mass of detached land ice floating in the sea or stranded in shallow water.
A body of ideas that reflects the beliefs and interest of a nation, political system, etc. and underlies political action.\n(Source: CED)

The process of converting 'raw' remotely sensed data into a usable form through the application of various transformations such as supervised and unsupervised classification schemes.\n(Source: FORUMT)
The reception of material, such as pollutants, by the environment and from any source.

Legislative and administrative procedures aimed at reducing the damage caused by emissions. Pollution control programmes are normally based on human-oriented acceptable dose limits. A very important measure concerns the organisation of an emission inventory.\n(Source: GOODa)
A law that protects the residents' health and resources of a region by limiting air pollution.
Damage caused by pollution from a distinct source of emission.
The prediction of immissions is calculated on the basis of the pollutant load, the source height, the wind speed and the dispersion coefficient.

A body system that helps an organism to resist disease, through the activities of specialised blood cells or antibodies produced by them in response to natural exposure or inoculation.\n(Source: KOREN /  CED)
The ability of an organism to resist disease or toxins by natural or artificial means.

Any of several methods for the quantitative determination of chemical substances such as hormones, drugs, and certain proteins that utilize the highly specific binding between an antigen and an antibody.

The disruption of the complex system of interacting cells, cell products and cell-forming tissues that protect the body from pathogens, destroys infected and malignant cells and removes cellular debris.\n(Source: SMD / RHW)
A branch of biology concerned with the native or acquired resistance of higher animal forms and humans to infections.
Instrument which samples atmospheric suspensoids by impaction; such instruments consist of a housing which constrains the air flow past a sensitized sampling plate.

1. The act of bringing goods and merchandise into a country from a foreign country.
2. To bring (something) in from a foreign country, especially for sale or trade.
3. An object brought from a foreign country, especially for sale or trade.
The state of having little or no money and few or no material possessions
Noise characterized by transient short-duration disturbances distributed essentially uniformly over the useful passband of a transmission system.
The burning of a dead body.

The controlled burning of solid, liquid, or gaseous combustible wastes to produce gases and solid residues containing little or no combustible material in order to reduce the bulk of the original waste materials.
Device which burns waste.

1. The inclined surface of any part of the Earth's surface, as a hillslope; also, a broad part of a continent descending toward an ocean, as the Pacific slope.\n(Source: BJGEO)
2. To be at an angle; to move downwards.

1. The gain derived from capital, from labour or effort, or both combined, including profit or gain through sale or conversion of capital.
2. Compensation for the selling of goods and services.
3. Payment received for goods or services or coming from other sources as for instance, investments.
4. Money that a person or an institution obtains.
The act of incorporating a substance to another substance.
Financial compensation, reimbursement or security for damages or loss offered by a government, insurance policy or contractual agreement under specified conditions and for specific casualties.

A body of water between the continents of Africa, Antarctica, Asia and Australia including the Bay of Bengal in the east and the Arabian Sea (with the Red Sea, the Gulf of Aden and the Persian Gulf) in the west, and containing several islands and island chains, such as the Andaman, Nicobar and Seychelles.
A blinking light mounted near the left and right front and rear corners of a vehicle, and sometimes on the sides, used to indicate the intention of a lateral change of position (turn or lane change).
Forests which are native to a given area.
Environment situated in the inside of a house or other building.

Areas allocated for industry within a town-planning scheme or environmental plan. The range of industries accommodated in a plan may include: light industry, service industry, general industry, hazardous, noxious or offensive industry, waterfront industry, extractive industry. Standards are usually defined for industrial areas relating to access and roads, drainage, car parking, aesthetics, landscaping, buffer zones, noise levels, and air and water pollution.\n(Source: GILP96)

The branch of medicine which deals with the relationship of humans to their occupations, for the purpose of the prevention of disease and injury and the promotion of optimal health, productivity, and social adjustment.
Procedures involving chemical or mechanical steps to aid in the manufacture of items, usually carried out on a very large scale.
The location for the individual manufacturing firm.
Sludge produced as a result of industrial production processes or manufacturing.
A large-scale community with diverse manufacturing sectors and an infrastructure and economy based on the science, technology and instrumental rationality of the modern West.

Waste materials discarded from industrial operations, or derived from manufacturing processes; may be solid, sludge (wet solids) or liquid wastes and may or may not be considered hazardous.\n(Source: HMD /  ISEP)

A group of establishments engaged in the same or similar kinds of economic activities. They produce a range of commodities that are sold with the expectation of recovering the total cost of production.
Wastes that do not undergo any significant physical, chemical, or biological transformations when deposited in a landfill.
The rate of deaths occurring in the first year of life for a given population.

1. The entry and development or multiplication of an infectious agent in the body of a living organism.
2. Process in which a disease is transmitted.

1. Pathogenic condition resulting from invasion of an host by a pathogen that propagates causing infection.
2. A disease caused by a microorganism or other agent, such as a bacterium, fungus, or virus, that enters the body of an organism.
Invasion of crop by parasites.
Movement of water through the soil surface into the ground.
Substance liable to catch fire.
Science and technique of data elaboration and of automatic treatment of information.
All facts, ideas or imaginative works of the mind which have been communicated, published or distributed formally or informally in any format, or the knowledge that is communicated or received.

An organized system of providing assistance or aid to individuals who are seeking information, such as by using databases and other information sources to communicate or supply knowledge or factual data.\n(Source: RHW / OMD)

Any coordinated assemblage of persons, devices and institutions used for communicating or exchanging knowledge or data, such as by simple verbal communication, or by completely computerized methods of storing, searching and retrieving information.\n(Source: MHD)

The systems, equipment, components and software required to ensure the retrieval, processing and storage of information in all centres of human activity (home, office, factory, etc.), the application of which generally requires the use of electronics or similar technology.

1. A breach, violation, or infringement; as of a law, a contract, a right or duty.
2. A crime less serious than a felony.
Electromagnetic radiation whose wavelengths lie in the range from 0.75 or 0.8 micrometer to 1000 micrometers.
Vibrations of the air at frequencies too low to be perceived as sound by the human ear, below about 15 hertz.
The basic network or foundation of capital facilities or community investments which are necessary to support economic and community activities.

1. A person occupying a region, town, house, country, etc.
2. A human, officially being inhabitant of certain area inside well defined, and precise, borders - usually seen from a standpoint of census, government, register, etc.
A stress upon an organism that disrupts the structure or function and results in a pathological process.

A dispersion of a pigment or a solution of a dye in a carrier vehicle, yielding a fluid, paste, or powder to be applied to and dried on a substrate; writing, marking, drawing, and printing inks are applied by several methods to paper, metal, plastic, wood, glass, fabric, or other substrate.
Fishing in lakes, streams, etc.
The navigation of inland waterways, i.e. navigable rivers, canals, sounds, lakes, inlets, etc.
A lake, river, or other body of water wholly within the boundaries of a state.\n(Source: MGH)
Transportation of persons and goods by boats travelling on rivers, channels or lakes.
Something newly introduced, such as a new method or device.
A branch of chemistry dealing with the chemical reactions and properties of all inorganic matter.\n(Source: LEE)
Chemical compound that does not contain carbon as the principal element (excepting carbonates, cyanides, and cyanates).\n(Source: MGH)
Any chemical agent used to destroy invertebrate pests.

1. (Insectivora) Order of placental mammals, being typically small, with simple teeth, and feeding on invertebrates.
2. An animal with a diet that consists chiefly of insects and similar small creatures.
In the natural or normal place.
An official examination and evaluation of the extent to which specified goals, objectives, standards, policies or procedures of an agency, organization, department or unit have been met properly.

An organization designated to look into, supervise and report upon, the staff members and workings of some institution or department, or the conforming to laws and regulations by a segment of society or other group.\n(Source: OED)
Material used to reduce the transmission of sound to or from a body, device, room, etc.

1. An agreement of providing financial protection contingencies, such as death, loss or damage and involving payment of regular premiums in return for a policy guaranteeing such protection.
2. The business of providing a financial protection against most losses or harm to a person, property or a firm in return for premiums paid.
The protection provided against risks or a risk, often as specified by the type of protection or the item being protected.
Farming in which as much use is made of the land as possible by growing crops close together or by growing several crops in a year or by using large amounts of fertilizers.\n(Source: PHC)
The enhancement of activity of pesticides when they are used in combination with others.\n(Source: PARCOR)
A transference of binary coded information items between two or more computers across any communications channel capable of carrying electromagnetic signals.
The utilisation, combination and coordination of two or more appropriate disciplines, technologies and humanities in an integrated approach toward problems.

1. A sum paid or charged for the use of money or for borrowing money over a given time period.
2. A great attention and concern from someone or something.
3. That which affects one's welfare or happiness.
4. To attract attention or concern; to excite the curiosity of; to engage the interest of.
5. To be on the mind of.
6. To be of importance or consequence.
A group of people who share common traits, attitudes, beliefs or objectives and who have formed a formal organization to serve specific concerns of the membership.
Tests performed at the same time in different laboratories to validate the quality of the results.
Cooperation in international efforts to support global goals.
The ability of firms to strive with rivals in the production and sale of commodities in worldwide markets.\n(Source: ODE / OED)
Treaties and other agreements of a contractual character between different countries or organizations of states creating legal rights and obligations between the parties.

Judicial arm of the United Nations. It has jurisdiction to give advisory opinions on matters of law and treaty construction when requested by the General Assembly, Security Council or any other international agency authorised by the General Assembly to petition for such opinion. It has jurisdiction, also, to settle legal disputes between nations when voluntarily submitted to it.\n(Source: BLACK)
The system of law regulating the interrelationship of sovereign states and their rights and duties with regard to one another.

Freedom from danger or the quality of averting risk of harm to persons, property or the environment shared across one or more national boundaries; consequently, the combined efforts of more than one nation to achieve or preserve that state.\n(Source: OED / RHW)
The flow of commodities and goods between nations.
Method employed in the assessment of the meaning and significance of data, results, facts, etc.
The area between land and sea which is regularly exposed to the air by the tidal movement of the sea.
A detailed list of articles, goods, property, etc.
A reversal in the usual direction of a process, as in the change of density of water at 4 C.\n(Source: PITT)
The atmosphere layer through which an inversion occurs.

1. Any animal lacking a backbone, including all species not classified as vertebrates.
2. Lacking a backbone.
Any item of value purchased for profitable return, as income, interest or capital appreciation.
Assay taking place in an artificial environment.
Experiment that is carried out in the living organism.

A nonmetallic halogen element; the poisonous, corrosive dark plates or granules are readily sublimed; insoluble in water, soluble in common solvents; used as germicide and antiseptic, in dyes, tinctures, and pharmaceuticals, in engraving lithography, and as a catalyst and analytical reagent.
The process in which ions are exchanged between a solution and an insoluble solid, usually a resin.
A permanent insoluble material (usually a synthetic resin) which contains ions that will exchange reversibly with other ions in a surrounding solution.

A region of the earth's atmosphere, extending from about 60 to 1000 kilometers above the earth's surface, in which there is a high concentration of free electrons and ions formed as a result of ionizing radiation entering the atmosphere from space.
An electrically charged atom or group of atoms formed by the loss or gain of one or more electrons.

1. A malleable ductile silvery-white ferromagnetic metallic element with symbol Fe and atomic number 26, occurring principally in haematite and magnetite. It is widely used for structural and engineering purposes.
2. Made out of iron.
3. A small appliance used in ironing to remove wrinkles from fabric.
4. To remove wrinkles from fabric.
Exposure to or treatment with light or other electromagnetic radiation or with beams of particles.
The act of supplying land with water so that crops and plants will grow or grow stronger.
A permanent irrigation conduit constructed to convey water from the source of supply to one or more farms.
Farming based on the artificial distribution and application of water to arable land to initiate and maintain plant growth.\n(Source: GOODa)

1. A land mass, especially one smaller than a continent, entirely surrounded by water.
2. A barrier on roads and highways between the opposing flows of traffic, usually covered with vegetation.
3. Area in the middle of a road where pedestrians can wait while crossing.

Unique but fragile and vulnerable ecosystem due to the fact that the evolution of their flora and fauna has taken place in relative isolation. Many remote islands have some of the most unique flora in the world; some have species of plants and animals that are not found anywhere else, which have evolved in a specialized way, sheltered from the fierce competition that species face on mainland.

1. Two or more compounds having the same molecular formula, but a different arrangement of atoms within the molecule. (Source: CED /  MGH)
2. One of two or more chemical substances having the same elementary percentage composition and molecular weight but differing in structure, and therefore in properties; there are many ways in which such structural differences occur.\n(Source: CED /  MGH)
Any of two or more atoms with the same atomic number that contain different numbers of neutrons.

The fine-grained creamy-white dentine forming the tusks of elephants, and the teeth or tusks of certain other large animals such as the walrus; it has long been esteemed for a wide variety of ornamental articles.\n(Source: BJGEO)
Persons united in a joint liability or indebtedness. Two or more persons jointly liable for the same debt.
A program sponsored or administered by a government to guide through and represent in court proceedings persons who are in financial need and cannot afford private counsel.\n(Source: BLD)
Any public organization or branch of government responsible for the administration of justice or the enforcement of laws.\n(Source: BLD)

1. The power of a court to hear and decide a case or give a certain punishment or sanction.
2. The area or territory where a particular person or group of people (such as a court) has the right to excersise their legal authority.
The science or philosophy of law.
A geological formation resulting from the erosion of carbonate rocks.
A soft garment worn on the foot and lower leg, usually knit or woven, worn under shoes or other footwear.

1. Higly refined kerosene used as fuel for jet engines.
2. Higly refined sulphurless kerosene used for kerosene lamps, lanterns and portable stoves and produces very little soot.
A room or building with scientific equipment for doing scientific tests or for teaching science, or a place where chemicals or medicines are produced.
Experimental tests or investigations carried out in a laboratory.\n(Source: CEDa)

Research carried out in a laboratory for testing chemical substances, growing tissues in cultures, or performing microbiological, biochemical, hematological, microscopical, immunological, parasitological tests, etc.\n(Source: PHC)
The sum of procedures used on natural sciences such as chemistry, biology, physics in order to conduct an experiment, all of them following the scientific method.
Discarded materials produced by analytical and research activities in a laboratory.\n(Source: ERG)

A material which contains a substantial quantity of a cellulose derivative, most commonly nitrocellulose but sometimes a cellulose ester, such as cellulose acetate or cellulose butyrate, or a cellulose ether such as ethyl cellulose; used to give a glossy finish, especially on brass and other bright metals.
A body of water cut off from the open sea by coral reefs or sand bars.
The depression in the Earth's surface occupied or formerly occupied by a lake.
The direct or indirect human alteration of the biological, physical, chemical or radiological integrity of lake water, or a lake ecosystem.\n(Source: Landy)
An enclosed body of water, usually but not necessarily fresh water, from which the sea is excluded.
A device for producing light.

1. A specified geographical tract of the Earth's surface including all its attributes, comprising its geology, superficial deposits, topography, hydrology, soils, flora and fauna, together with the results of past and present human activity, to the extent that these attributes exert a significant influence on the present and future land utilization.\n(Source: WHIT)
2. The range occupied by a community or other group.
3. To descend to a surface, especially from the air; to arrive on shore.
4. The part of Earth which is not covered by oceans or other bodies of water.
5. A partitioned and measurable area on the Earth which is owned.
6. Area that is suitable for farming.
7. In a compact disc or similar recording medium, an area of the medium which does not have pits.
8. The space between the rifling grooves in a gun.
9. A strip area in a field between furrows made for irrigation.
10. The geographic area under the control of a political state.
11. Territorial possessions.
12. To descend, reach or come to rest.
13. To deliver (a blow).
The system of registering certain legal estates or interests in land. It describes the land and any additional rights incidental to it, such as rights of way over adjoining land.\n(Source: DICLAW)
Removal of trees, undergrowth, etc. in preparation for ploughing, building, etc.
Joining small plots of land together to form larger farms or large fields.
Interface between the earth's crust and the atmosphere made of a combination of vegetation, soil, rock, water and human-made structures.
Study of the relationship between terrestrial organisms and their environment.
A site where garbage is collected and buried.
The protective shielding, consisting of soil or some other material, that encloses disposal sites for waste to minimize the chance of releasing hazardous substances into the environment.

Landfill gas is highly dangerous as methane is highly explosive; therefore it must be controlled at all operational landfill sites, whether by active or passive ventilation or both especially in the case of deep sites. There exist venting systems for shallow and deep sites respectively.\n(Source: PORT)

Any physical, recognizable form or feature of the Earth's surface, having a characteristic shape and produced by natural causes; it includes major forms such as plane, plateau and mountain, and minor forms such as hill, valley, slope, esker, and dune. Taken together the landforms make up the surface configuration of the Earth's.\n(Source: BJGEO)
Mammal that lives on shore.

The activity of designing, organizing or preparing for the future use of solid areas of the earth's surface, especially regions valued for natural resources, utilized as agricultural resources or considered for human settlement.\n(Source: RHW)
A public register containing information on the land and landowners.

1. The traits, patterns, and structure of a specific geographic area.
2. A mode of printing where the horizontal sides are longer than the vertical sides.
The creation, development, and decorative planting of gardens, grounds, parks, and other outdoor spaces.

The safeguarding, for public enjoyment, of landscape and of opportunities for outdoor recreation, tourism and similar activities; the concept includes the preservation and enhancement not only of what has been inherited but the provision of new amenities and facilities.

The study of landscapes taking account of the ecology of their biological populations. The subjects thus embraces geomorphology and ecology and is applied to the design and architecture of landscapes.\n(Source: ALL2)
Mass-movement landforms and processes involving the downslope transport, under gravitationary influence of soil and rock material en masse.
The monetary or material worth in commerce or trade of an area of ground considered as property.
A device that produces a powerful, highly directional, monochromatic, coherent beam of light.
The act of washing and ironing clothes, linen, etc.
An alteration of or addition to any statute with legal force that, if approved by the appropriate legislative authority, supersedes the original statute.

Any variety of activities associated with promoting compliance and obedience to the binding rules of a state, especially the prevention, investigation, apprehension or detention of individuals suspected or convicted of violating those rules.

1) The process of separating a liquid from a solid (as in waste liquid by percolation into the surrounding soil. \n2) Extraction of soluble components of a solid mixture by percolating a solvent through it.\n3) To lose or cause to lose soluble substances by the action of a percolating liquid.

1. A heavy toxic bluish-white metallic element with symbol Pb and atomic number 82 that is highly malleable; occurs principally as galena and is used in alloys, accumulators, cable sheaths, paints, and as a radiation shield.
2. To be ahead of others, e.g., in a race.
3. The distance that a shooter aims ahead of a moving target in order to hit it with the projectile.
4. To treat with lead.
5. To move ahead (of others) in time or space.
6. A small stick of graphite used in pencil that leaves marks when rubbed against a surface.

A chemical compound present as gasoline additives, in paint, ceramic products, roofing, caulking, electrical applications, tubes, or containers. Lead exposure may be due to air, water, food, or soil. Lead in the air is primarily due to lead-based fuels and the combustion of solid waste, coal, oils, and emissions from alkyl lead manufacturers, wind blown dust volcanoes, the burning of lead-painted surfaces, and cigarette smoke. Lead in drinking water comes from leaching from lead pipes, connectors, and solder in both the distribution system and household plumbing.\n(Source: KOREN)
A measure of the amount of lead or lead salts absorbed by the body as a possible sign of acute or chronic lead poisoning, which can affect the nervous, digestive or muscular systems.

1. The main organ of photosynthesis and transpiration in higher plants, usually consisting of a flat green blade attached to the stem directly or by a stalk.
2. A sheet of a book, magazine, etc (consisting of two pages, one on each face of the leaf).

The accidental, uncontrolled discharge or seepage of liquids, gases and other substances to unintended and unwanted locations, frequently causing risks of damage or harm to persons, property or the environment.
The dressed or tanned hide of an animal, usually with the hair removed.
Industry for the production of leather goods such as garments, bags, etc.
The fundamental law or judicial precedent that warrants or supports a subsequent decision or action by any governmental, corporate or private entity.
Any order or rule issued by a government stipulating its procedures for the creation, execution or adjudication of laws.
The means by which a right is enforced or the violation of a right is prevented, redressed, or compensated.\n(Source: BLACK)
The exact wording or language of a law or other document in conformity with the law or having the authority of law.\n(Source: BLD)
The act or process of making laws.
The power of a deliberative assembly of persons or delegates to bring a bill, resolution or special act to an official, legally binding status.\n(Source: RHW)
The skill, knowledge, qualification, capacity or authority to make, give or enact rules with binding force upon a population or jurisdiction.
The department, assembly, or body of persons that makes statutory laws for a state or nation.
Time free from work or other duties; spare time.
Any insect of the order Lepidoptera that has a slender body with clubbed antennae and typically rests with the wings (which are often brightly coloured) closed over the back.

A ratable portion of the produce of the property and labor of the individual citizens, taken by the nation, in the exercise of its sovereign rights, for the support of government, for the administration of the laws, and as the means for continuing in operation the various legitimate functions of the state.
The vocabulary of a particular sphere of activity, region, social class or individual, or the total set of morphemes or meaningful units of a language and its words.

1. Subjection to a legal obligation. Liability is civil or criminal according to whether it is enforced by the civil or criminal courts.
2. Responsibility to someone or for some activity.
3. An obligation to pay money to another party.
4. The quality of being something that holds you back.

1. Place where books and other literary materials are kept.
2. A collection of subroutines used to develop software.
Composite organisms formed by the symbiosis between species of fungi and an algae.

1. The phases, changes, or stages through which an organism passes throughout its lifetime.
2. The useful life of a product or system; the developmental history of an individual or group in society.
A science based on living organisms collectively.
The particular attitudes, habits or behaviour associated with an individual or group.

1. A device for producing light.
2. Electromagnetic radiation that is capable of causing a visual sensation.
3. To start (a fire).
4. To give light to (something).
5. Of low weight.
6. Object, natural or artificial, that produces light.
7. Having colors relatvely near white.
8. (of the military or industry) using (or being) relatively small or light weapons or equipment.
9. Low in degree or quantity or number (e.g. of rain, snow, accent).
10. Psychologically light; especially free from sadness or troubles.
11. Low in fat, calories, alcohol, salt, etc.
12. (used of soil) loose and large-grained in consistency.
The supply of illumination in streets or dwellings.

A mechanical device for separating and removing residues from fuel and lubricating oil from waste water coming from filling stations and industrial plants in order to avoid pollution of water bodies; this system is based on the different specific weights of water and fuel residues that float on the water and can be easily removed.

Coal of relatively recent origin consisting of accumulated layers of partially decomposed vegetation, intermediate between peat and bituminous coal; often contains patterns from the wood from which it formed.\n(Source: MGH /  CED /  WRIGHT)

Extraction of brown coal from natural deposits; lignite is a brownish-black solid fuel in the second stage in the development of coal. It has a little over half the heating value of bituminous or anthracite coal.\n(Source: KORENa)

1. Any of various mineral and industrial forms of calcium oxide differing chiefly in water content and percentage of constituent such as silica, alumina and iron.
2. A green citrus fruit
A sedimentary rock consisting chiefly of calcium carbonate, primarily in the form of the mineral calcite and with or without magnesium carbonate.
The study of bodies of fresh water with reference to their plant and animal life, physical properties, geographical features, etc.\n(Source: CED)
Point noise sources placed one after the other one as, for instance, in a row of cars moving on a road.\n(Source: VALAMB)
A source of air, noise, water contamination or electromagnetic radiation that emanates from a linear source such as a road.

One of a class of compounds which contain long-chain aliphatic hydrocarbons and their derivatives, such as fatty acids, alcohols, amines, amino alcohols, and aldehydes; includes waxes, fats, and derived compounds.\n(Source: MGH)
A gaseous compound or mixture converted to the liquid phase by cooling or compression; examples are liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), liquefied natural gas (LNG), liquid oxygen, and liquid ammonia.

1. Any fertilizer substance with a moisture content of over ninety percent, usually consisting of animal excrement with water added.
2. Liquid excrements of animals and people, accumulated for reuse as fertilizer.

A state of matter intermediate between that of crystalline substances and gases in which a substance has the capacity to flow under extremely small shear stresses and conforms to the shape of a confining vessel, but is relatively incompressible, lacks the capacity to expand without limit, and can posses a free surface.
Written material such as poetry, novels, essays, especially works of imagination characterized by excellence of style and expression and by themes of general or enduring interest.
A fund of information on a particular subject or group of related subjects, divided into discrete documents and usually stored in and used with a computer system.\n(Source: RHW)
The identification, description, analysis and classification of books and other materials used or consulted in the preparation of a work.\n(Source: WEBSTE)
The solid portion of the Earth, as compared with the atmosphere and the hydrosphere.\n(Source: BJGEO)

1. Straw, hay or similar material used as bedding by animals.
2. Small pieces of garbage, such as cans, bottles and wrappings, that people have left in a public place.
3. A seat mounted on a frame with two poles on which a person can be carried.
The intertidal zone of the seashore.
Cattle, horses, and similar animals kept for domestic use especially on a farm.
The raising of livestock by crossing different varieties to obtain new varieties with desired characteristics.
Breeding of cattle, horses and similar animals.
Any room, structure or area used as a residence and associated with subsistence activities, including sleeping, relaxing or eating.

1. (Sauria) A reptile of the order Squamata.
2. Any reptile of the suborder Lacertilia, especially those of the family Lacertidae, typically having an elongated body, four limbs, and a small tail: includes the gechos, iguanas, chameleons, monitors, and slow worms.
The maximum load that a system can support before failing.
The supply of heat, either in the form of steam or hot water, from a central source to a group of buildings.
Traffic moving within a city, town, or area and subject to frequent stops, as distinguished from long distance traffic.
A self-propelled engine driven by steam, electricity or diesel power and used for drawing trains along railway tracks.
Traffic moving over extended areas, great distances and usually not subject to frequent stops.
Effect which will last long after the cause has ceased.
The prevailing tendency or general direction expected for some observed value over a lengthy and extended period of time, often determined by studying and analyzing statistical data.

1. A large motor vehicle of more than 3,500 kilograms designed for carrying cargo.
2. Any motor vehicle designed for carrying cargo, including vans and pickups.
3. Small rail car wihout cover to transport goods out of mines or quarries.

1. The result of a business operation where overhead costs are greater than the receipts or income.\n(Source: ISEP /  ODE)
2. The act of being defeated and losing something, such as a match.
Destruction of biotopes produced by environmental degradation which in turn is caused by air- or water-borne pollution.\n(Source: WPR)
The magnitude of the physiological sensation produced by a sound, which varies directly with the physical intensity of sound but also depends on frequency of sound and waveform.

Residences built at minimal expense and designed to keep the rental rate or price of purchase affordable for persons with limited means, usually determined by an annual income level set below the local median.

The body of a bicameral legislature composed of representatives elected by the general populace and organized into electorates or districts, each comprising an equal number of citizens.\n(Source: CIV)
Flying at low altitude.
Any relatively unsophisticated technical equipment or method with an amplitude or functionality below what is available in a similar or comparable system.\n(Source: RHW / APD)
A substance used to reduce friction between parts or objects in relative motion.\n(Source: MGH)

1. The functional relationship between stellar magnitude and the number and distribution of stars of each magnitude interval. Also known as relative luminosity factor.
2. The ability of emitting or reflecting light.
The alkaline solution that is obtained from the leaching of wood ashes.\n(Source: MGH)

A system of vessels and nodes conveying lymph in the vertebrate body, beginning with capillaries in tissue spaces and eventually forming the thoracic ducts which empty in the subclavian veins.\n(Source: MGH)
The measurement of the water percolating through soils and the determination of the materials dissolved by the water.

The making or production of mechanical apparatuses used for commercial or industrial purposes, such as engines and turbines, elevators and conveying equipment, computers and office equipment, and hoists, cranes and industrial trucks.

An aim or objective pertaining to the production, distribution and use of income, wealth and commodities in a country, region or other large area, typically concerned with governmental fiscal and monetary policy as it affects employment, consumption, investment and growth levels.\n(Source: ODE)
Modern economic analysis that is concerned with data inaggregate as opposed to individual form such as national income, consumption and investment.
A plastic, paper, or metal tape that is coated or impregnated with magnetizable iron oxide particles, used in magnetic recording.\n(Source: MGH)
A class of physical phenomena associated with moving electricity, including the mutual mechanical forces among magnets and electric currents.
A series of addresses or e-mail addresses to which solicited or unsolicited mass mailings can be sent.\n(Source: RHW)
A group of human and animal febrile diseases with a chronic relapsing course caused by hemosporidian blood parasites of the genus Plasmodium, transmitted by the bite of Anopheles mosquito.
Permanent structural change that may adversely affect survival, development or function.\n(Source: KOREN)
Defective nutrition due to inadequate intake of nutrients or to their faulty digestion, assimilation or metabolism.
Any animal of the Mammalia class, a class of warm-blooded vertebrates having a thoracic diaphragm, a four-chambered heart and in which the females feed the young with their own milk.

1. The management or direction of the affairs of a public or private office, business or organization.
2. Government, control, superintendence, physical or manual handling or guidance; act of managing by direction or regulation, or administration, as management of family, or of household, etc.\n(Source: BLACK)
A command or authorization to act in a particular way given by an administrator to a subordinate, a court to a lower court or an electorate to its representative.\n(Source: RHW)
Any of various tropical evergreen trees or shrubs that grow in shallow coastal water; Plants of the Rhizophoraceae family and/or of the genus Rhizophora.

A wet, spongy area of land in tropical climates and along coastal regions that is dominated by mangrove trees and shrubs, particularly red mangroves (Rhizophora), black mangroves (Avicennia) and white mangroves (Laguncularia).
Man-made climate changes due to the greenhouse effect and other human activities.
The interrelationship between human activity and geographical environment.
The power generated by a man working.
The process or act of exchanging, buying or selling any manufactured product, or the raw materials for any manufacturing process.\n(Source: RHW /  ISEP)
Animal excreta collected from stables and barnyards with or without litter; used to enrich the soil.

1. A representation, normally on a flat medium, that displays the physical and political features of a surface area of the earth, showing them in their respective forms, sizes and relationships according to some convention of representation.
2. The visual representation of a person or an object.
3. Representation of the location of datasets in a computer memory to speed up access and visualization.

1. The process of making a map of an area; especially the field work necessary for the production of a map.
2. Representation of the location of datasets in a computer memory to speed up access and visualization.

Maps of lichens distribution indicating air quality. Fruticose lichens (with branched structures well above the surface) are more susceptible to SO2 damage than foliose lichens (whose leaflike thallus lies nearly flat on surface) and both in turn are more susceptible than crustose lichens (which embed their tissue in the cracks of bark, soil, or rocks). The use of morphological lichen types as indicators of air pollution concentrations is well developed.\n(Source: WESTM)
Metamorphic rock composed of recrystallized calcite or dolomite.
Low quality land the value of whose production barely covers its cultivation costs.
Cultivation of marine organisms in their natural habitats, usually for commercial purposes.
A small port that is used for pleasure rather than trade, often with hotels, restaurants and bars.
A branch of biology that deals with those living organisms which inhabit the sea.\n(Source: MGH)

An integrative science that studies the basic structural and functional relationships within and among living populations and their physical-chemical environments in marine ecosystems. Marine ecology focuses on specific organisms as well as on particular environments or physical settings.
Any marine environment, from pond to ocean, in which plants and animals interact with the chemical and physical features of the environment.
The design, construction, installation, operation, and maintenance of main power plants, as well as the associated auxiliary machinery and equipment, for the propulsion of ships.\n(Source: MGH)
The oceans, seas, bays, estuaries, and other major water bodies, including coastal marine and nearshore zones.
Animals which live in the sea.
The harvest of animals and plants from the ocean to provide food and recreation for people, food for animals, and a variety of organic materials for industry.

That aspect of the study of the ocean that deals specifically with the ocean floor and the ocean-continent border, including submarine relief features, the geochemistry and petrology of the sediments and rocks of the ocean bottom and the influence of seawater and waves on the ocean bottom and its materials.\n(Source: BJGEO)
Any detrimental alteration of the marine environment caused by the intentional or accidental release of dangerous or toxic substances, such as industrial, commercial and urban waste water.
Sea area where marine wildlife is protected.
Solid fragmental material, originated from weathering of rocks, that has settled down from a state of suspension in the water.

1. That system of law which particularly relates to marine commerce and navigation, to business transacted at sea or relating to navigation, to ships and shipping, to seamen, to the transportation of persons and property by sea, and to marine affairs generally.
2. The area of law that deals with ships at sea and the rights of sailors, passengers, and owners of cargo.
Travelling on the sea by means of boats, ships, etc.\n(Source: CEDa)

1. Small amount of an easily detected substance that can be used to follow and quantify the flow of materials or movement of organisms not otherwise visible or detectable by ordinary means.
2. A pen with a wide tip made of felt or fibre.
3. An isotope of an element, a small amount of which may be incorporated into a sample of material in order to follow the course of that element through a chemical, biological, or physical process, and thus also follow the larger sample. The tracer may be radioactive, in which case observations are made by measuring the radioactivity.\n(Source: ECHO1)

1. A minute quantity of radioactive isotope used in medicine or biology to study the chemical changes within living tissues.
2. A person or thing that traces.
Place of commercial activity in which articles are bought and sold.

A mixed economy that relies heavily on markets to answer the three basic questions of allocation, but with a modest amount of government involvement. While it is commonly termed capitalism, market-oriented economy is much more descriptive of how the economy is structured.\n(Source: AMOS2)
The organizational form or structure of the trade or traffic of a particular commodity.\n(Source: ISEP /  RHW)
A related group of business activities whose purpose is to satisfy the demands for goods and services of consumers, businesses and government.
The systematic gathering, recording, computing, and analysing of data about problems relating to the sale and distribution of goods and services for certain time periods.
Type of mammal with a pouch in which the young are carried.

1. The substance of which a product is made or composed.
2. Worldly, as opposed to spiritual.
3. Having to do with matter.
A calculation to inventory material inputs versus outputs in a process system.
All the stages involved in the manufacturing, distribution and retail, use and re-use and maintenance, recycling and waste management of materials.
The study of the nature, behaviour, and use of materials applied to science and technology.

The branch of mathematics most explicitly concerned with the limit process or the concept of convergence; includes the theories of differentiation, integration and measure, infinite series, and analytic functions.\n(Source: MGH)
The maximum concentration of air polluting substances in the free environment whose impact when of specified duration and frequency is not objectionable to man, fauna and flora.\n(Source: ECHO2)

1. Strictly a term for a field of permanent grass used for hay, but also applied to rich, waterside grazing areas that are not suitable for arable cultivation.\n(Source: GOOD)
2. A piece of land covered or cultivated with grass, usually intended to be mown for hay.
The ability of the analytical method or protocol to quantify as well as identify the presence of the substance in question.\n(Source: LEE)
The edible flesh of animals, especially that of mammals.
The branch of engineering concerned with the design, construction, and operation of machines.\n(Source: CED)
The science and art of treating and healing.
Plants having therapeutic properties.

The collective islands and countries of the inland sea between Europe, Africa and Asia that is linked to the Atlantic Ocean at its western end by the Strait of Gibraltar and includes the Tyrrhenian, Adriatic, Aegean and Ionian seas.
A change of the state of a substance from the solid phase to the liquid phase. (Source: MGH)
A thin tissue that encloses or lines biological cells, organs, or other structures.
A heavy silvery-white toxic liquid metallic element with symbol Hg and atomic number 80 occurring principally in cinnabar: used in thermometers, barometers, mercury-vapour lamps, and dental amalgams.
All the chemical reactions that take place in a living organism, comprising both anabolism and catabolism.
A product of intermediary metabolism.
Mineral containing metals, such as bauxite, pyrite, etc.
Any binary compound in which oxygen is combined with one or more metal atoms.
A thin, adherent layer of metal on an object.
An opaque crystalline material usually of high strength with good electrical and thermal conductivities, ductility and reflectivity.

A branch of science that studies the dynamics of the atmosphere and the direct effects of the atmosphere upon the Earth's surface, oceans and inhabitants, focusing particularly on weather and weather conditions.
The science concerned with the atmosphere and its phenomena.

A colourless, odourless, and tasteless gas, lighter than air and reacting violently with chlorine and bromine in sunlight, a chief component of natural gas; used as a source of methanol, acetylene, and carbon monoxide.
The system of methods and principles used in a particular discipline.
A large city, specifically that city in a country which is the seat of government, of ecclesiastical authority, or of commercial activity.\n(Source: GOOD)
Analysis for the identification of viruses, bacteria, fungi and parasites.
The science and study of microorganisms, including protozoans, algae, fungi, bacteria, viruses, and rickettsiae.\n(Source: MGH)
The local, rather uniform climate of a specific place or habitat, compared with the climate of the entire area of which it is a part.
An effect on the climate on a small scale, such as a single forest or other bounded area.

The study of a microclimate, including the study of profiles of temperature, moisture and wind in the lowest stratum of air, the effects of the vegetation and of shelterbelts, and the modifying effects of towns and buildings.\n(Source: MGH)

A microprocessor combined with input/output interface devices, some type of external memory, and the other elements required to form a working computer system; it is smaller, lower in cost, and usually slower than a minicomputer.\n(Source: MGH)

A small-scale, simplified, experimental ecosystem, laboratory- or field- based, which may be: a) derived directly from nature (e.g. when samples of pond water are maintained subsequently by the input of artificial light and gas-exchange); or b) built up from axenic cultures (a culture of an organism that consists of one type of organism only, i.e. that is free from any contaminating organism) until the required conditions of organisms and environment are achieved. Also known as microcosm.\n(Source: ALL2)
The technology of constructing circuits and devices in extremely small packages by various techniques.\n(Source: MGH)
The separation or removal from a liquid of particulates and microorganisms in the size range of 0.1 to 0.2 microns in diameter.
Pollutant which exists in very small traces in water.\n(Source: PHC)
The interpretative application of microscope magnification to the study of materials that cannot be properly seen by the unaided eye.

1. An electromagnetic wave which has a wavelength between about 0.3 and 30 centimeters, corresponding to frequencies of 1-100 gigahertz; however there are no sharp boundaries between microwaves and infrared and radio waves.
2. An appliance for cooking food using microwave energy.
3. To cook or heat in a microwave oven.
Movements that particular animals carry out regularly often between breeding places and winter feeding grounds.
A bird which migrates in a group.
A species that moves from one biome to another for food or to breed.
Air traffic of or relating to the armed forces.
Area whose utilization is exclusively reserved to the army.

1. The whitish fluid secreted by the mammary gland for the nourishment of the young; composed of carbohydrates, proteins, fats, mineral salts, vitamins, and antibodies.
2. To draw milk from (a mammal, especially a cow).

1. A building where grain is crushed into flour.
2. An establishment where products are manufactured using industrial methods.

1. An opening or excavation in the earth for extracting minerals.\n(Source: MGH)
2. An explosive device, concealed under or on the ground and designed to destroy or disable enemy targets as they pass over or near the device.
3. To extract from the earth by excavation.
A mass of naturally occurring mineral material, e.g. metal ores or nonmetallic mineral, usually of economic value, without regard to mode of origin.\n(Source: BJGEO)
The science which concerns the study of natural inorganic substances called minerals.\n(Source: MGH)
A naturally occurring substance with a characteristic chemical composition expressed by a chemical formula; may occur as individual crystals or may be disseminated in some other material or rock.
Water containing naturally or artificially supplied minerals or gases.
A district where mineral exploitation is performed.
Engineering concerned with the discovery, development and exploitation of coal, ores, and minerals, as well as the cleaning, sizing and dressing of the product.
The study of geologic aspects of mineral deposits, with particular regard to problems associated with mining.

A sector of the economy in which an aggregate of commercial enterprises is engaged in the extraction of minerals occurring naturally, often involving quarrying, well operations, milling, exploration and development.\n(Source: SIC)
A rule or order prescribed by government or management to promote the safety, legality or ecological responsibility of any aspect of the process or industry of ore extraction.\n(Source: BLD)

The body of top government administrators or other high ranking public officials that are selected by a head of state to manage certain aspects of a state's affairs, as opposed to civil servants whose tenure is unaffected by public changes resulting from democratic elections or some other process.
A group that is different racially, politically, etc. from a larger group of which it is a part.
The tendency or capacity of two or more liquids to form a uniform blend, that is, to dissolve in each other; degrees are total miscibility, partial miscibility, and immiscibility.\n(Source: MGH)

An order of small Arachnida with rounded bodies. Mites are very abundant in the soil, feeding on plant material and invertebrate animals.
