Some parasitic mites (e.g. red spider) damage crops and can be serious pests. Others cause diseases in animals. Ticks are blood-suckers, some being vectors of diseases such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever in humans and fowls, and louping ill in cattle and sheep.\n(Source: ALL)
Any procedure or action undertaken to reduce the adverse impacts that a project or activity may have on the environment.\n(Source: TOE)
A forest composed of broadleaf trees and coniferous trees.
Use of land for more than one purpose; e.g. grazing of livestock, watershed and wildlife protection, recreation, and timber production.\n(Source: RRDA)
The intermingling of different materials to produce a homogeneous mixture.
Living quarters mounted on wheels and capable of being towed by a motor vehicle.\n(Source: CED)

1. A representation, usually on a smaller scale, of a device, structure, etc. \n(Source: CED /  LEE)
2. A person who serves as a subject for artwork, usually in the medium of photography but also for painting or drawing.
3. Person whose job is to wear clothes in order to present them.
4. A quantitative or mathematical representation or computer simulation which attempts to describe the characteristics or relationships of physical events.
5. A grouping based on shared characteristics.
6. To display an object for others to see, especially in regard to wearing clothing while performing the role of a fashion model.
7. To create from a substance such as clay.
8. A typical example or instance.
9. A type of product.
Water that is dispersed through a gas in the form of water vapour or small droplets, dispersed through a solid, or condensed on the surface of a solid.

The study of the chemical structures and processes of biological phenomena at the molecular level; the discipline is particularly concerned with the study of proteins, nucleic acids, and enzymes, the macromolecules essential to life processes. It seeks to understand the molecular basis of genetic processes. Techniques used include X-ray diffraction and electron microscopy.\n(Source: GILP96)
The regularly checking in order to perceive change in some quality or quantity.\n(Source: BRACK)
Techniques employed in the process of checking, observing and measuring events, processes or physical, chemical, biological and environmental phenomena.\n(Source: ZINZANa /  DUNSTEa)
The market condition where a particular commodity or service has only one seller.

1. An object, especially large and made of stone, built to remember and show respect to a person or group of people, or a special place made for this purpose.
2. A burial vault (usually for some famous person).
A tract of unenclosed waste ground, usually covered with heather, coarse grass, bracken, and moss.
Appealing to the ethical principles or beliefs of an adversary or the public to convince the adversary to change behavior or attitudes.

1. The branch of biology concerned with the form and structure of organisms.
2. In linguistics, the study of word structure.
The number of deaths occurring in a given population for a given period of time.
Any plant of the class Bryophyta, occurring in nearly all damp habitats.
Single-track, two-wheeled motor vehicle.
Any gaseous or liquid flammable fuel that burns in an internal combustion engine.
A road vehicle driven by a motor or engine, especially an internal combustion engine.

1. A feature of the earth's surface that rises high above the base and has generally steep slopes and a relatively small summit area.
2. A great number or large amount of things not placed in a pile.
The sport, hobby or profession of walking, hiking and climbing up mountains.
Area characterized by conspicuous peaks, ridges, or mountain ranges.\n(Source: BJGEO)
A single, large mass consisting of a succession of mountains or narrowly spaced mountain ridges, with or without peaks, closely related in position, direction, formation, and age.
The cutting down of grass, crops or grain with a scythe or a mechanical device.
A relatively level area of fine silt along a shore (as in a sheltered estuary) or around an island, alternately covered and uncovered by the tide, or covered by shallow water.
A layer of organic material applied to the surface of the ground to retain moisture.
A binding agreement between three or more parties.
A business company operating in multiple countries.

The aggregation of services offered by a town or city in which streets and other public areas are kept clean, such as through trash pick-ups, street sweeping and decontamination of water, soil and other natural resources.\n(Source: FFD)
A town, city, or other district having powers of local self-government.\n(Source: LANDY)
The jurisdiction, position or status of city, town or local government.\n(Source: DAM / OED)
The muscle cells, tissues, and organs that effect movement in all vertebrates.

1. A place or building where objects of historical, artistic, or scientific interest are exhibited, preserved or studied.\n(Source: CED)
2. Of or relating to a museum.
An organism belonging to a family of Basidiomycetes that are characterized by the production of spores on gills.

1. The artistic organisation of sounds or tones that expresses ideas and emotions through the elements of rhythm, melody, harmony and tonal colour.
2. A document which contains a musical composition in printed or written form.
Breeding of mussels for sale as food.

A large, diverse family of low-slung, long-bodied carnivorous mammals including minks, weasels, and badgers; distinguished by having only one molar in each upper jaw, and two at the most in the lower jaw.
The property of chemical or physical agents of inducing changes in genetic material that are transmitted during cell division.
An agent that raises the frequency of mutation of genetic material above the spontaneous rate.
An individual bearing an allele that has undergone mutation and is expressed in the phenotype.
A change in the chemical constitution of the DNA in the chromosomes of an organism.
The branch of botany concerned with the study of fungi.
The symbiotic association of the root of a higher plant with a fungus.
A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by the government of a sovereign state that holds force throughout the regions and territories within the government's dominion.\n(Source: RHW)

Areas of outstanding natural beauty, set aside for the conservation of flora, fauna and scenery, and for recreation, if this does not conflict with the conservation objectives of the parks and their landscapes. Hunting, logging, mining, commercial fishing, agriculture and livestock grazing are all controlled within national parks, as is industrial activity.\n(Source: WRIGHT)
An area of certain natural conditions, as opposed to a civilized area shaped and inhabited mainly by humans.
Violent, sudden and destructive change in the environment without cause from human activity, due to phenomena such as floods, earthquakes, fire and hurricanes.
Organic material added to the soil to supply chemical elements needed for plant nutrition.
A forest area that has developed free from the influence of humans and remains largely unaffected by their activities.
A natural fuel containing methane and hydrocarbons that occurs in certain geologic formations.\n(Source: LANDY)

The tapping of natural gas from wells located under the sea and in general from underground sources often in association with petroleum deposits; it is used as a fuel, having largely replaced coal-gas for this purpose, and as a source of intermediates for organic synthesis.
The probability of occurrence, within a specific period of time in a given area of a potentially damaging phenomenon of nature.\n(Source: GUNN)

Generally, the world's natural resources as handed down to the present generation, and specifically, the earth's outstanding physical, biological and geological formations, and habitats of threatened species of animals and plants and areas with scientific, conservation or aesthetic value.\n(Source: WHC /  OED)
A rule or body of rules that derives from nature and is believed to be binding upon human society, as opposed to human-made laws such as legislative acts and judicial decisions.\n(Source: WOR / INP)

A natural/cultural feature which is of outstanding or unique value because of its inherent rarity, representative of aesthetic qualities or cultural significance. Guidance for selection of a natural monument is: a) The area should contain one or more features of outstanding significance (appropriate natural features include spectacular waterfalls, caves, craters, fossil beds, sand dunes and marine features, along with unique or representative fauna and flora; associated cultural features might include cave dwellings, cliff-top forts, archaeological sites, or natural sites which have heritage significance to indigenous peoples).; b) The area should be large enough to protect the integrity of the feature and its immediately related surroundings.\n(Source: AERG)

A designation project of lands which preserves natural resources for their scientific, scenic, cultural and/or educational value by limiting development and management practices. Land managed to protect rare and endangered species of flora and fauna will be designed as natural areas.\n(Source: LANDY)
Radiation stemming mainly from uranium, present in small amounts in many rocks, soils, building material, etc.
A feature or component of the natural environment that is of value in serving human needs, e.g. soil, water, plantlife, wildlife, etc.
The branches of science dealing with objectively measurable phenomena pertaining to the transformation and relationships of energy and matter; includes biology, physics, and chemistry.
A stone that occurs in nature, as distinguished from a man-made substitute.
Active management of the earth's natural resources and environment to ensure their quality is maintained and that they are wisely used.\n(Source: PHC)
Area allocated to preserve and protect certain animals and plants, or both.
Desire to vomit.
The pathologic death of living tissue in a plant or animal.

1. To need a number or amount of something, but not having any at all.
2. The feeling of the lack of something.
3. To need a number or amount of something, but not having enough or any at all.
4. What is necessary to satisfy a need.
5. To feel that something is necessary.

1. A group of unsegmented worms which have been variously recognized as an order, class, and phylum.
2. One of the most common phyla of animals, with over 80,000 different described species (of which over 15,000 are parasitic). They are ubiquitous in freshwater, marine, and terrestrial environments, where they often outnumber other animals in both individual and species counts, and are found in locations as diverse as Antarctica and oceanic trenches.

A coordinating and integrating system which functions in the adaptation of an organism to its environment; in vertebrates, the system consists of the brain, brainstem, spinal cord, cranial and peripheral nerves, and ganglia.
The total decrease in the amount of natural materials available for use by humans and other living beings.
The occurrence of adverse effects on a nervous system following exposure to a chemical.\n(Source: KOREN)
The act of making a solution neutral by adding a base to an acidic solution, or an acid to a basic solution.
A sociopolitical, religious, occupational or other group of common characteristics and interests formed as an alternative to social, and often residential, options currently available.\n(Source: RHW)

A malleable ductile silvery-white metallic element that is strong and corrosion-resistant, occurring principally in pentlandite and niccolite: used in alloys, especially in toughening steel, in electroplating, and as a catalyst in organic synthesis.\n(Source: CED)
Any salt or ester of nitric acid, such as sodium nitrate.

The process by which ammonia compounds, including man-made fertilizer and the humus provided by organic matter or plant and animal origin, are converted into nitrites and then nitrates, which are then absorbed as a nutrient by crops.
A salt or ester of nitric acid, included in compounds such as potassium nitrite, sodium nitrite and butyl nitrite.
Any one of a class of usually organic compounds that contain the monovalent group, -NO2 (nitro group or radical) linked to a carbon atom.
Gaseous, non-metallic chemical element with symbol N and atomic number 7.

The complex set of processes by which crops acquire the large amount of nitrogen they need to make proteins, nucleic acids and other biochemicals of which they are composed, and how the nitrogen returns to the atmosphere.
A reddish-brown gas; it exists in varying degrees of concentration in equilibrium with other nitrogen oxides; used to produce nitric acid.
Assimilation of atmospheric nitrogen by a variety of microorganisms which live freely in soil.
A colourless gas, soluble in water, ethanol and ether.
Any one of a class of neutral, usually yellow oily compounds containing the divalent group.

1. Sound which is unwanted, either because of its effects on humans, its effect on fatigue or malfunction of physical equipment, or its interference with the perception or detection of other sounds.
2. A random and unwanted signal.
Determination of the frequency components that make up a particular noise being studied.\n(Source: MGH)
A barrier for reducing the propagation of sound that are widely used in industry and alongside roads and railways.
The release of noise into the environment from various sources that can be grouped in: transportation activities, industrial activities and daily normal activities.
Immission in the environment of acoustic vibrations that negatively affect human beings, animals, plants or other objects.
Physical quantity of unwanted sound measured, usually expressed in decibels.
The process of quantitatively determining one or more properties of acoustic noise.
Noise in the environment which can be harmful to human beings, animals and plants.\n(Source: ISEP)
Harmful or unwanted sounds in the environment, which in specific places, can be measured and averaged over a period of time.

Adoption of measures for controlling noise pollution, such as restriction of the emission of noise from industrial, commercial and domestic premises, from motor vehicles and aircrafts, the provision of noise barriers and buffer zones, the fitting of sound attenuation equipment, etc.\n(Source: CONFERa /  GILP96a)
A member of a people or tribe who move from place to place to find pasture and food.
The body of specialized words relating to a particular subject.
Any metal other than iron and its alloys.
Minerals containing non-metals, such as quartz, garnet, etc.\n(Source: RRDA)
A chemical element, that does not have the chemical or physical properties of a metal, e. g. oxygen or sulfur.
Clean fuel that does not release polluting emissions in the environment, such as methane.

A natural resource which, in terms of human time scales, is contained within the Earth in a fixed quantity and therefore can be used once only in the foreseeable future (although it may be recycled after its first use).
Any container for which no specific provisions for its return from the consumer or final use has been established.

1. An established standard, guide, or regulation.
2. The most common and popular way of thinking among a population.
(Database) The process of structuring data to minimise duplication and inconsistencies.

A geographic region of the African continent south of Europe and the Mediterranean Sea, and north of Africa's tropical rain forest, including Morocco, Algeria, Tunisia, Libya and the Egyptian region west of the Suez Canal, and also the Sahara Desert and Atlas Mountains.

A continent in the northern half of the western hemisphere, bounded by the Arctic Ocean in the north, by the Pacific Ocean and the Bering Sea in the west, and by the Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico in the east, connected to South America by the Isthmus of Panama, and including the United States, Canada, Mexico and several small island nations.\n(Source: INP)
The northern part of the Atlantic Ocean, extending northward from the equator to the Arctic Ocean.

An ocean north of the equator between the eastern coast of Asia and the western coasts of the Americas, extending northward to the arctic region, with principal arms including the Gulf of Alaska, the Sea of Okhotsk, the Sea of Japan and the Bering, Yellow, East China, South China and Philippine seas, and islands including the Aleutian, Midway, Marshall and Hawaiian islands, the Japanese island arc and the Malay Archipelago.
A type of food that does not have a significant history of consumption or is produced by a relatively new method.

An event occurring in a nuclear power plant or anywhere that radioactive materials are used, stored, or transported and involving the release of potentially dangerous levels of radioactive materials into the environment.\n(Source: FEMAa)
Energy released by nuclear fission or nuclear fusion.
A place, including buildings, where all the activities relating to nuclear research are performed.\n(Source: CAMB)
The division of an atomic nucleus into parts of comparable mass; usually restricted to heavier nuclei such as isotopes of uranium, plutonium, and thorium.
Material that can be used in nuclear fission or fusion to create nuclear energy.
A piece of nuclear fuel which has been formed and coated, and is ready to be placed in a reactor fuel assembly.
Combination of two light nuclei to form a heavier nucleus with release of some binding energy.
The study of the characteristics, behaviour and internal structures of the atomic nucleus.
The ongoing, public discussion and dispute over the uses of nuclear energy.
A power plant in which nuclear energy is converted into heat for use in producing steam for turbines, which in turn drive generators that produce electric power.

A reaction involving a change in an atomic nucleus, such as fission, fusion, neutron capture, or radioactive decay, as distinct from a chemical reaction, which is limited to changes in the electron structure surrounding the nucleus.
Device which creates heat and energy by starting and controlling atomic fission.
Measures and techniques implemented to reduce the possibility of incidence and the potential harm posed by radioactive substances used as an energy source, a test material or in weaponry.
Test performed to evaluate nuclear weapons.
Any bomb, warhead, or projectile using active nuclear material to cause a chain reaction upon detonation.
Any of several organic acids combined with proteins (DNA or RNA) which exist in the nucleus and protoplasm of all cells.
Something which annoys.
A liquid or gel designed to support the growth of microorganisms, cells or small plants.
The amount of proteins, carbohydrates, fats, inorganic salts (e.g. nitrates, phosphates), minerals (e.g. calcium, iron), and water.
A biogeochemical cycle, in which inorganic nutrients move through the soil, living organisms, air and water or through some of these.
Elimination of nutrients as, for example, from sewage in order to prevent eutrophication of water in reservoirs.

Chemical elements which are involved in the construction of living tissue and which are needed by both plant and animal. The most important in terms of bulk are carbon, hydrogen and oxygen, with other essential ones including nitrogen, potassium, calcium, sulphur and phosphorus.

1. Chemical elements which are involved in the construction of living tissue and which are needed by both plant and animal. The most important in terms of bulk are carbon, hydrogen and oxygen, with other essential ones including nitrogen, potassium, calcium, sulphur and phosphorus.
2. A process in animals and plants involving the intake of nutrient materials and their subsequent assimilation into the tissues.

1. Any tree of the genus Quercus in the order Fagales, characterized by simple, usually lobed leaves, scaly winter buds, a star-shaped pith, and its fruit, the acorn, which is a nut; the wood is tough, hard, and durable, generally having a distinct pattern.
2. Wood of the oak tree.

1. The act of a party who objects to some matter or proceeding in the course of a trial or an argument or reason urged by him in support of his contention that the matter or proceeding objected to is improper or illegal.\n(Source: BLACK)
2. An argument that contradicts what is said by other persons.
The legal responsibility or duty compelling manufacturers to affix certain marks or other written identification to their products, as is directed by laws, regulations or government standards.
A functional or organic disease caused by factors arising from the operations or materials of an individual's industry, trade, or occupation.

The branch of medicine which deals with the relationship of humans to their occupations, for the purpose of the prevention of disease and injury and the promotion of optimal health, productivity, and social adjustment.
Law enacted to reduce the incidence among workers of personal injuries, illnesses, and deaths resulting from employment.
The mass of water occupying all of the Earth's surface not occupied by land, but excluding all lakes and inland seas.
Water current flow in a closed circular pattern within an ocean.
A net transport of ocean water along a definable path.\n(Source: MGH)
The process by which pollutants, including sewage, industrial waste, consumer waste, and agricultural and urban runoff are discharged into the world's oceans.

The islands of the southern, western and central Pacific Ocean, including Melanesia, Micronesia, and Polynesia. The term is sometimes extended to encompass Australia, New Zealand, and the Malay Archipelago.\n(Source: AMHER)
The scientific study and exploration of the oceans and seas in all their aspects.\n(Source: MGH)
A measure, referenced to a standard value, of the heat or coldness in a body of oceanic water.
Order in the class of insecta that includes dragonflies and damselflies.
Unlawful acts against the environment, such as water contamination, hazardous waste disposal, air contamination, unpermitted installation of plants, oil spills, etc.\n(Source: AZENPa)

1. Any room, set of rooms or building used for the administration of government service, business transactions or other work related activities.
2. Any building used for the administration of government service, business transactions or other work related activities.
3. The actions and activities assigned to or required or expected of a person or group.
4. Professional or clerical workers in an office.
Proceedings of relative formality, with definite issues of fact or of law to be tried, in which witnesses are heard and parties proceeded against have right to be heard.\n(Source: WESTS)
Oil extraction from platforms situated a short distance from the coast.
Highly absorbent agents used for physically removing spilled oil in case of leakages and oil accidents occurring in water bodies, industry, work-shops, on roads, etc.

1. A floating device used to contain oil on a body of water.
2. A boom in the oil producing sector of an economy.

The disaster caused by the dumping and accidental spillage of oil into waterways from ships and land-based or offshore installations. Oil pollution may destroy or damage aquatic life and wildlife such as birds, contaminate water supplies and create fire hazards.\n(Source: GILP96)
A line of pipe connected to valves and other control devices, for conducting oil.
Contamination of any ecosystem, but usually of freshwater or marine ecosystems, by oil or other petroleum products.
A boat used for recovering oil spilled at sea from oil tankers.
A plant where crude petroleum is transformed into fuels, lubricants, and other petroleum-derived products.
The separation of petroleum mixtures into their component parts.
A kerogen-bearing, finely laminated brown or black sedimentary rock that will yield liquid or gaseous hydrocarbons on distillation.
The mass of oil that floats on a surface of water, which is discharged accidentally, naturally or by design, and can be moved by currents, tides and the wind.

1. Contamination of any ecosystem, but usually of freshwater or marine ecosystems, by oil or other petroleum products.
2. The accidental release of oil, or other petroleum products usually into freshwater or marine ecosystems, and usually in large quantities.
A very large ship which carries crude oil or other petroleum products in big tanks.
The testing and measurement of the sensitivity of the sense of smell.
Infection with the filaria Onchocerca volvulus; results in skin tumours, papular dermatitis, and ocular complications.
The study of the causes, development, characteristics, and treatment of tumors.

1. The extraction of metal ores and minerals that lie near the surface by removing the overlying material and breaking and loading the ore.
2. Superficial mining, in which the valuable rock is exposed by removal of overburden.

1. That which one holds to be true; the acceptance of a fact, opinion, or assertion as real or true despite a lack of strong evidence or knowledge.
2. Judgement or belief not founded on certainty or proof.
A mineral or mineral aggregate, mixed with gangue, that can be worked and treated at a profit.

1. A fully differentiated structural and functional unit, such as a kidney or a root, in an animal or plant.
2. A keyboard instrument played using one or more manuals and a pedalboard. Sound is produced by an airflow through metal or wood pipes and/or electronically by sampled organ sounds or oscillators.
Carbon which comes from an animal or plant. \n\n(Source: PHC)
A branch of chemistry dealing with the study of composition, reaction, properties, etc. of organic compounds.\n(Source: LEE)
Farming without the use of industrially made fertilizers or pesticides.
Organic materials, including diluents and thinners, which are liquids at standard conditions and which are used as dissolvers, viscosity reducers, or cleaning agents.\n(Source: LEE)
Chemical compounds, based on carbon chains or rings and also containing hydrogen with or without oxygen, nitrogen, or other elements.\n(Source: MGH)
A type of waste which can be broken down into its base compounds by micro-organisms.
An individual constituted to carry out all life functions.
Organic compounds containing a C-Cl bond.
Organic compounds containing a C-halogen bond.
Molecules containing carbon-metal linkage; a compound containing an alkyl or aryl radical bonded to a metal.\n(Source: MGH)
Organic compounds having a C-N bond.\n(Source: RRDA)
Compounds, both aliphatic and aromatic, which have a C-O bond, including alcohols, aldehydes, etc.
Organic compound that contains phosphorous; short-lived, but some can be toxic when first applied.\n(Source: EPAGLO)
Any natural substance composed of two or more unlike atoms held together by chemical bonds and containing silicon, a non-metallic element often found in rocks or minerals.\n(Source: RHW)
Chemical compound used in anti-foulant paints to protect the hulls of boats and ships, buoys and pilings from marine organisms such as barnacles.\n(Source: EPAGLO)
The branch of zoology that deals with the study of birds, including their physiology, classification, ecology, and behaviour.
The study of mountain systems and the depiction of their relief.\n(Source: WHIT)
A heterogeneous order of generalized insects with gradual metamorphosis, chewing mouthparts, and four wings.
The passage of a solvent through a semipermeable membrane separating two solutions of different concentrations.
A pastime, diversion, exercise or other means of enjoyment and relaxation that is carried out in a particular city, town or small district.
The material such as soil and rock lying above a mineral deposit that must be removed in order to work the deposit.
An excess of people gathered together in a confined space.
The use of raw materials excessively without considering the long-term ecological impacts of such use.\n(Source: WPR)
Taking out of the sea more fish than natural population growth can sustain.
The damaging of land as a result of excessive animal grazing, for example sheep and goats.
Suspended cables by which electrical power is distributed throughout a country.
A population density that exceeds the capacity of the environment to supply the health requirements of the individual organism.
The passing of winter in a particular place.
A chemical reaction that increases the oxygen content of a compound.
An oxidizing chemical change, where an element's positive valence is increased (electron loss), accompanied by a simultaneous reduction of an associated element (electron gain).
Binary chemical compound in which oxygen is combined with a metal or nonmetal.

A gaseous chemical element with symbol O and atomic number 8; an essential element in cellular respiration and in combustion processes; the most abundant element in the earth's crust and about 20% of the air by volume.\n(Source: MGH)
Treating with oxygen.
Amount of oxygen contained in a solution.

An allotropic form of oxygen containing three atoms in the molecule. It is a bluish gas, very active chemically, and a powerful oxidizing agent. Ozone is formed when oxygen or air is subjected to a silent electric discharge. It occurs in ordinary air in very small amounts only.\n(Source: UVAROV)

A factor that reflects the ozone depletion potential of a substance, on a mass per kilogram basis, as compared to chlorofluorocarbon-11 (CFC-11). Such factor shall be based upon the substance's atmospheric life time, the molecular weight of bromine and chlorine, and the substance's ability to be photolytically disassociated, and upon other factors determined to be an accurate measure of relative ozone depletion potential.\n(Source: LEE)
The general stratum of the upper atmosphere in which there is an appreciable ozone concentration and in which ozone plays an important part in the radiative balance of the atmosphere.

All products made of any materials of any nature to be used for the containment, protection, handling, delivery and presentation of goods, from raw materials to processed goods, from the producer to the user or the consumer.

1. A mixture of pigment and a vehicle, such as oil or water, that together form a liquid or paste that can be applied to a surface to provide an adherent coating that imparts colour, protects the surface and/or gives the surface different features.
2. To make a painting.
3. To make a painting of.
A commercial service through which paint, a decorative or protective coating product, or similar products are applied to the interiors and exteriors of buildings and other surfaces.
A shop where paint and related items are sold.

1. Felted or matted sheets of cellulose fibers, formed on a fine-wire screen from a dilute water suspension, and bonded together as the water is removed and the sheet is dried.
2. Made of paper.
3. A scholarly written work describing the results of observations or stating hypotheses.

1) A quantity in an equation which must be specified beside the independent variables to obtain the solution for the dependent variables. \n2) A quantity which is constant under a given set of conditions, but may be different under other conditions.\n(Source: LEE /  MGH)

1. Organism which lives and obtains food at the expense of another organism, the host.
2. A person who exploits fellow human beings.
A branch of biology which deals with those organisms, plant or animal, which have become dependent on other living creatures.
An assembly of elected representatives, typically controlled by a political party and constituting the legislative and, in some cases, the executive power of a state.
The act of sharing or taking part in a civic, community or public action.

1. Any very small part of matter, such as a molecule, atom, or electron.
2. One-syllable suffixes or short words in Japanese and Korean grammar that immediately follow the modified noun, verb, adjective, or sentence. They have a wide range of grammatical functions, including the indication of a question or the speaker's assertiveness, certitude, or other feelings.
3. A word or term that lack a precise lexical definition, that is typically short, indeclinable, and have a grammatical function.
4. A very small piece of matter.
A device for segregation of solid particles by size range, as a screening.
The conveyance of people over land, water or through air by automobile, bus, train, airplane or some other means of travel.

1. Land covered with grass or herbage and grazed by or suitable for grazing by livestock.
2. To put livestock into a field or pasture or meadow to graze.
3. (For livestock) To feed on grass or herbage from a pasture.
4. To feed as in a meadow or pasture.
Any disease-producing agent or microorganism.
Agents producing or capable of producing disease.
The branch of medicine concerned with the causes, origin, and nature of disease, including the changes occurring as a result of disease.
Unconsolidated soil material consisting largely of undecomposed or slightly decomposed organic matter accumulated under conditions of excessive moisture.\n(Source: LANDY)
Area in a city where vehicles are not allowed.
That shell or layer of the Earth in which soil-forming processes occur.

1. Punitive sanction taken against someone who has broken the law.
2. A free kick in football taken from 11 m in front of the goal with only the goalkeeper defending.
3. A disadvantage imposed upon a competitor or team, according to the rules of the game.
4. A legal punishment.
A toxic phenolic compounds with formula C6HOCl5, used as a fungicide, herbicide and molluscicide.
Stable, colorless liquid, nonflammable and nonexplosive, with low toxicity; used as a dry-cleaning and industrial solvent, in pharmaceuticals and medicines, and for metal cleaning.
A plant or animal organism which is attached or clings to surfaces of leaves or stems of rooted plants above the bottom stratum.
The ability of a membrane or other material to permit a substance to pass through it.

An exposure limit that is set for exposure to an hazardous substance or harmful agent and enforced by OSHA (Occupational Safety and Health Act) as a legal standard. It is based on time-weighted average concentrations for a normal 8-hour work day and 40 hour work week.
Voluntary agreement or permission.
A pollutant created by the action of sunlight on hydrocarbons and nitrogen oxides in the air. An ingredient of smog.

1. The capacity of a substance to remain chemically stable. This is an important factor in estimating the environmental effects of substances discharged into the environment. Certain toxic substances (e.g., cyanides) have a low persistence, whereas other less immediately toxic substances (e.g., many organochlorines) have a high persistence and may therefore produce more serious effects.\n(Source: ALL)
2. Lasting for a long period, being present for a long period.

The ability of a chemical to retain its molecular integrity and hence its physical, chemical, and functional characteristics in the environment through which such a chemical may be transported and distributed for a considerable period of time.\n(Source: GILP96)

1. Any unwanted insect or other organism that attacks and damages crops, reduces the fertility of land or injures or irritates livestock or people.
2. A persistently annoying person.
Keeping down the number of pests by killing them or preventing them from attacking.
A general term for chemical agents that are used in order to kill unwanted plants, animals pests or disease-causing fungi.
A pesticide remaining in the environment for a fairly long time, continuing to be effective for days, weeks, and months.

1. The occurrence of one or more pest species in an area or location where their numbers and impact are currently or potentially at intolerable levels.
2. A sudden increase in destructiveness or population numbers of a pest species in a given area.

1. An animal which is kept in the home as a companion and treated affectionately.
2. To stroke or caress in an erotic manner, as during lovemaking.
The production of materials derived from petroleum or natural gas.\n(Source: MGH)
A fuel for internal combustion engines consisting essentially of volatile flammable liquid hydrocarbons derived from crude petroleum.
A comparatively volatile liquid bitumen composed principally of hydrocarbon, with traces of sulphur, nitrogen or oxygen compounds; can be removed from the earth in a liquid state.

Petroleum belongs to non-renewable energy sources; it is a complex substance derived from the carbonized remains of trees, ferns, mosses, and other types of vegetable matter. The principal chemical constituents of oil are carbon, hydrogen, and sulphur. The various fuels made from crude oil are jet fuel, gasoline, kerosine, diesel fuel, and heavy fuel oils. Major oil consumption is in the following areas: transportation, residential-commercial, industrial and for generating electric power.\n(Source: PARCOR)

The branch of economic geology that relates to the origin, migration and accumulation of oil and gas, and to the discovery of commercial deposits. Its practice involves the application of geochemistry, geophysics, paleontology, structural geology and stratigraphy to the problems of finding hydrocarbons.\n(Source: BJGEO)

Manufacturing industry utilizing complex combination of interdependent operations engaged in the storage and transportation, separation of crude molecular constituents, molecular cracking, molecular rebuilding, and solvent finishing to produce petrochemical products.
Plants that produce seeds. The group comprises the Gymnospermae and the Angiospermae.\n(Source: ALL)
Concerted activity concerned with manufacturing pharmaceutical goods.
The study of the rates of absorption, tissue distribution, biotransformation, and excretion.\n(Source: LEE)
The science dealing with the nature and properties of drugs, particularly their actions.\n(Source: MGH)

A white crystalline soluble poisonous acidic derivative of benzene, used as an antiseptic and disinfectant and in the manufacture of resins, nylon, dyes, explosives and pharmaceuticals.\n(Source: CED)
Any substance secreted by an animal which influences the behaviour of other individuals of the same species.\n(Source: MGH)

The academic discipline concerned with making explicit the nature and significance of ordinary and scientific beliefs and investigating the intelligibility of concepts by means of rational argument concerning their presuppositions, implications, and interrelationships; in particular, the rational investigation of the nature and structure of reality (metaphysics), the resources and limits of knowledge (epistemology), the principles and import of moral judgment (ethics), and the relationship between language and reality (semantics).
Any salt or ester of any phosphoric acid, especially a salt of orthophosphoric acid.

Replacement of phosphate in detergents by environmentally safer substances, such as zeolite. The substitute will not act as a nutrient, and so will not cause eutrophication as a result of the accelerated growth of plants and microorganisms if it is released into waterways.\n(Source: WRIGHTa)
All substances that are able to substitute phosphate compounds in detergents; they must have the same chemical and physical properties and must be less polluting for the environment.\n(Source: RRDA)

A nonmetallic element used to manufacture phosphoric acid, in phosphor bronzes, incendiaries, pyrotechnics, matches, and rat poisons; the white or yellow allotrope is a soft waxy solid, soluble in carbon disulfide, insoluble in water and alcohol, and is poisonous and self-igniting in air; the red allotrope is an amorphous powder, insoluble in all solvents and is nonpoisonous; the black allotrope comprises lustrous crystals similar to graphite, and is insoluble in most solvents.
The result or consequence of a chemical reaction caused by light or ultraviolet radiation.
Any of the chemicals which enter into oxidation reactions in the presence of light or other radiant energy.
Degradation products that are produced by the action of light radiation.\n(Source: FLGISAa)
Chemical reaction which is initiated by light of a specific wavelength.
A combination of fog and chemicals that come from automobile and factory emissions and is acted upon by the action of the sun.
The process of making measurements from photographs, used especially in the construction of maps from aerial photographs and also in military intelligence, medical and industrial research, etc.

1. An image captured by a camera or some other device and reproduced as a picture, usually on a sensitized surface and formed by the chemical action of light or of radiant energy.
2. To obtain an image of someone or something on photographic film or digital format by using photography.
Process by which plants transform carbon dioxide and water into carbohydrates and other compounds, using energy from the sun captured by chlorophyll in the plant.
The study of the spatial and temporal characteristics and relationships of all phenomena within the Earth's physical environment.
The study of the physical aspects of the ocean, the movements of the sea, and the variability of these factors in relationship to the atmosphere and the ocean bottom.\n(Source: MGH)
A form of urban land use planning which attempts to achieve an optimal spatial coordination of different human activities for the enhancement of the quality of life.\n(Source: LANDY)
A continuous action or series of changes which alters the material form of matter.\n(Source: RHW)

1. Property of a substance that cannot change without involving a change in chemical composition.
2. Physical quantity that is characteristic for a material or an object, e. g. density
The sciences concerned with nonliving matter, energy, and the physical properties of the universe, such as physics, chemistry, astronomy, and geology.
The study of those aspects of nature which can be understood in a fundamental way in terms of elementary principles and laws.
The biological study of the functions of living organisms and their parts.
The study of plant diseases and their control.\n(Source: ZINZAN)
Planktonic plant life.\n(Source: MGH)
The study of vegetation, including the organization, interdependence, development, geographical distribution and classification of plant communities.
Ability of a substance to cause injury or damage to a plant.
A pictorial representation of data projected onto a two-dimensional grid of individual picture elements (pixels) and acquired from a human-made vessel placed in orbit round a planet, moon or star.
The service provided by a pilot, one who controls the movements of a ship or aircraft by visual or electronic means.
A small version of a planned industrial plant, built to gain experience in operating the final plant.
A small scale experiment or set of observations undertaken to decide how and whether to launch a full-scale project.
A mammal belonging to the Pinnipedia, an order of aquatic placental mammals having a streamlined body and limbs specialized as flippers: includes seals, sea lions, and the walrus.

1. A line of pipe connected to valves and other control devices, for conducting fluids, gases, or finely divided solids.\n(Source: MGH)
2. A system of tubes, especially the ones with a large diameter, for conducting ou distributing liquids or gases.
3. To convey something by a system of pipes.

1. A rigid tube that transports water, steam or other fluid, as used in plumbing and numerous other applications.
2. A device consisting of a mouthpiece, a long pipe stem and a pipe bowl, that is used to smoke tobacco.

1. An extensive, broad tract of level or rolling, almost treeless land with a shrubby vegetation, usually at a low elevation.
2. Having a surface without slope nor variations in altitude.
3. To state complaints, discontent, displeasure, or unhappiness.
4. Having only one color.

1. A scheme of action, a method of proceeding, or a series of steps, thought out in advance to accomplish a goal.
2. Scale drawing of a structure or its parts.
3. To make or work out a plan for; devise.
4. To have the intention to carry out some action.
5. To make a (graphic) design of.
Small organisms (animals, plants, or microbes) passively floating in water.
The act of making a detailed scheme for attaining an objective.
A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by a government to organize, designate and regulate land use.

An authorization, license or equivalent control document issued by a government agency that approves a step by step method and process of defining, developing and outlining various possible courses of action to meet existing or future needs, goals and objectives.\n(Source: TOE / ISEP)
Raising a certain type of plant by crossing one variety with another to produce a new variety where the desired characteristics are strongest.

Any group of plants belonging to a number of different species that co-occur in the same habitat or area and interact through trophic and spatial relationships; typically characterized by reference to one or more dominant species.
A disease that affects plants.
The scientific study of the hereditary material of plants for purposes such as hybridization, improved food resources and increased production.
Any substance or mixture of substances which through physiological action protects the plants against parasites, fungi, virus, or other damaging factors.\n(Source: KORENa)

1. Pertaining to mammals walking with the whole sole of the foot touching the ground.
2. Mammal walking with the whole sole of the foot touching the ground.
The establishment of trees or other plants by transplanting, or planting seedlings or cuttings.
The study of the function and chemical reactions within the various organs of plants.\n(Source: UVAROV)
Conservation of plant species that may be rare or endangered, and of other plants of particular significance.\n(Source: GILP96)
Trade of plants subjected to regulations established by the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES).

1) Common name for a number of industrial applications of plasma, such as: etching of semiconductor chips, deposition of silicon for solar cell production, deposition of silicon dioxide for passivation of surfaces, activation of surfaces, melting and welding with plasma arcs as well as plasma chemistry. \n2) Plasma technology consists of minute gas-filled cells, which emit light when an electric current is channelled through them.\n(Source: IEAP /  Z2Z)

1. A polymeric material (usually organic) of large molecular weight which can be shaped by flow; usually refers to the final product with fillers, plasticizers, pigments, and stabilizers included (versus the resin, the homogeneous polymeric starting material); examples are polyvinyl chloride, polyethylene, and urea-formaldehyde.
2. Capable of being molded or modeled.
Any discarded plastic (organic, or synthetic, material derived from polymers, resins or cellulose) generated by any industrial process, or by consumers.\n(Source: APD)

A ductile malleable silvery-white metallic element very resistant to heat and chemicals. It occurs free and in association with other platinum metals, especially in osmiridium; used in jewellery, laboratory apparatus, electrical contacts, dentistry, electroplating, and as a catalyst.
A piece of land used for recreation, especially by children, often including equipment such as swings and slides.
A highly toxic metallic transuranic element with symbol Pu and atomic number 94.
The action of catching game, fish, etc. illegally by trespassing on private property.\n(Source: CED)
A single identifiable localized source of something.

1. A substance which, when ingested, inhaled, or absorbed, or when applied to, injected into, or developed within the body, in relatively small amounts, may cause injury, harm, or destruction to organs, tissue, or life.
2. To administer a toxic substance.
The morbid condition produced by a poison which may be swallowed, inhaled, injected, or absorbed through the skin.\n(Source: KOREN)

1. The interacting systems of the biological communities and their nonliving environmental surroundings located in the regions where the air temperature is perennially below 10 Celsius, usually at and near the North and South Poles.
2. Ecosystem of the region around Earth's poles.
Area relating to the earth's poles or the area inside the Arctic or Antarctic Circles.

A generally fertile tract of flat, low-lying land (as in Netherlands and Belgium) reclaimed and protected from the sea, a lake, a river, or other body of water by the use of embankments, dikes, dams, or levees.
Branch of the government which is charged with the preservation of public order, the promotion of public health and safety, and the prevention, detection, and punishment of crimes.

A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by a government to regulate the employment and tactics of police or other civil agents organized to maintain order, prevent and detect crimes and promote obedience to civil regulations and authority.
A general plan of action, formulated by a political party, a government agency or a similar institution.
The theory and practice of acquiring and exercising the power to govern in a society in order to arbitrate values, allocate resources and establish and enforce rules.
The process of making arrangements or preparations to facilitate any course of action that may be adopted and pursued by government, business or some other organization.
A policy, position or principle advocated, taught or put into effect concerning the acquisition and exercise of the power to govern or administrate in society.\n(Source: RHW)
The study of how political, economic, and social factors affect environmental issues.
The study of the effects of political actions on human geography, involving the spatial analysis of political phenomena.\n(Source: GOOD)

An organized group that has as its fundamental aim the attainment of political power and public office for its designated leaders. Usually, a\npolitical party will advertise a common commitment by its leaders and its membership to a set of political, social, economic and/or cultural values.

The might, ability or authority of governments, citizens groups and other interested parties in enacting change or in influencing or controlling the outcome of governmental or public policies affecting a nation, region or municipality.\n(Source: BLD)
A fine granular substance produced in flowers. Collective term for pollen grains or microspores produced in the anthers of flowering plants.

1. A substance, usually a residue of human activity, which has an undesirable effect upon the environment.
2. A substance that pollutes.
The process by which concentrations of pollutants progressively increase in the tissues of living organisms in environments where these pollutants are present.
Release of polluting substances in the air, water and soil from a given source and measured at the immission point.
The amount of polluting material that a transporting agent, such as a stream, a glacier, or the wind, is actually carrying at a given time.
The principle that those causing pollution should meet the costs to which it gives rise.

The indirect or direct alteration of the biological, thermal, physical, or radioactive properties of any medium in such a way as to create a hazard or potential hazard to human health or to the health, safety or welfare of any living species.\n(Source: ALL)
The amount of polluting material that a transporting agent, such as a stream, a glacier, or the wind, is actually carrying at a given time.
The assessment of the concentration of pollutants for a given time in a given point.
A chemical substance consisting of several bromine atoms attached to biphenyl.
Any of a class of aromatic organic compounds formed by the chlorination of the hydrocarbon biphenyl; they have many industrial applications but are damaging to the environment.

PCDD are formed (along with variants including furans) when compounds containing chlorine are burnt at low temperature in improperly operated/designed domestic refuse and industrial waste incinerators where PCDDs can be found in both the flue gases and the fly ash.\n(Source: PORT)

A family containing 135 individual, colorless compounds known as congeners with varying harmful health and environmental effects. They are produced as unwanted compounds during the manufacture of several chemicals and consumer products such as wood treatment chemicals, some metals, and paper products; also produced from the burning of municipal and industrial waste in incinerators, from exhaust of leaded gasoline, heat, or production of electricity. They are hazardous to the respiratory system, gastrointestinal system, liver, musculoskeletal system, skin and nervous system; and are toxic by inhalation, ingestion, and contact. Symptoms of exposure include frequent coughing, severe respiratory infections, chronic bronchitis, abdominal pain, muscle pain, acne rashes, skin color changes, unexpected weight loss, nonmalignant or malignant liver disease.\n(Source: KOREN)
Compounds consisting of three benzene rings linked to each other in either ortho, meta or para positions and substituted with chlorine atoms.
Hydrocarbons containing two or more closed rings of atoms.

Hydrocarbon molecule with two or more nuclei; examples are naphtalene, with two benzene rings side by side, or diphenyl, with two bond-connected benzene rings. Also known as polynuclear hydrocarbon.\n(Source: MGH)
A thermoplastic polyester resin made from ethylene glycol and terephthalic acid; melts at 265C; used to make films or fibers.
Substance made of giant molecules formed by the union of simple molecules (monomers).\n(Source: MGH)
Polymer of vinyl chloride; tasteless, odourless; insoluble in most organic solvents; a member of the family of vinyl resins.
A natural body of standing fresh water occupying a small surface depression, usually smaller than a lake and larger than a pool.
Any collection of liquid effluents or wastewater drained or separated out during the processing of crops or mineral ores.
A small, natural body of standing water, usually fresh; e.g. a stagnant body of water in a marsh, or a still body of water within a cave.
The density, dispersal pattern and apportionment of the total number of persons in any area.\n(Source: RHW / EEN)
The process of numerical and structural change within populations resulting from births, deaths, and movements.
The study of the interaction of a particular species or genus population with its environment.
An increase in the total number of inhabitants of a country, city, district or area.
Any shift or migration of a statistically significant number of persons inhabiting a country, district or area.\n(Source: RHW)
The organization of, and inter-relationships among, inhabitants of a given region, country or city.
The direction of change in the total number of persons inhabiting a country, city, district or area.
Any of several compounds containing potassium, especially soluble compounds such as potassium oxide, potassium chloride, and various potassium sulfates, used chiefly in fertilizers.

Rock salt mining is an underground mining process in which the salt is physically dug out of the ground in an operation involving drilling, blasting and crushing the rock. The major percentage of this output is used for winter road maintenance.\n(Source: SALINF)

1. Domesticated fowl grown for their meat and eggs.
2. A bird that is kept for its meat and eggs.

1. State in which the individual lacks the resources necessary for subsistence.
2. Lack of the means of subsistence.

1. A stationary plant containing apparatus for large-scale conversion of some form of energy (such as hydraulic, steam, chemical, or nuclear energy) into electrical energy.
2. A stationary plant containing apparatus for large-scale conversion of some form of energy (such as hydraulic, steam, chemical, or nuclear energy) into electrical energy.

Increase of precipitation resulting from changes in the colloidal stability of clouds. This can be either intentional, as with cloud seeding, or unintentional, as with air pollution, which increases aerosol concentrations and reduces sunlight.\n(Source: PARCOR)

1. Animal which kills and eats other animals.\n(Source: PHC)
2. Man who is hostile to, feels hatred towards, opposes the interests of, or intends injury to someone else.
Building whose sections are manufactured in specialized factories and later transported and assembled on a building site.
Any introductory action in the judicial process designed to determine the need for further court involvement or to expedite a motion that requires immediate attention.\n(Source: BLD)
Amount to be paid for a contract of insurance or life assurance.
A chemical added to foodstuffs to prevent oxidation, fermentation or other deterioration, usually by inhibiting the growth of bacteria.

1. A sweet spread made of any of a variety of berries.
2. To keep something or someone safe or prevent harm coming to someone or something.
3. To protect; to keep; to maintain the condition of.

1. Printed matter as a whole, especially newspapers and periodicals.
2. A crowd of people pressed close together in a small space.
3. To apply pressure to an item.
4. To force or impel in a given direction.
Needing urgent attention.

1. A type of stress which is exerted uniformly in all directions; its measure is the force exerted per unit area.
2. To exert violence, or constraint upon or against a person in order to obtain something by physical, moral or intellectual means.
Any politically active group with a common set of values about resource use allocation.

1. The amount of money paid per unit for a good or service.
2. To attach a price tag to goods or services which are to be sold.
3. To fix or set a price to be paid for, or asked for, a good or service which one wants to sell.
The first five or six years of instruction in elementary schools.\n(Source: COE)
Consumption of energy used in the same form as in its naturally occurring state, for example crude oil, coal, natural gas, e.g. before it is converted into electricity.\n(Source: BRACK)
That part of a country's or region's economy that makes direct use of natural resources, including agriculture, forestry, fishing and the fuel, metal and mining industries.

1. Order of mammals containing monkeys, apes, and human beings.
2. In the Western Catholic Church and in the Anglican Communion, a bishop with higher rank than a metropolitan archbishop but, in the Catholic Church, with less high rank than a major archbishop.
Forest which originally covered a region before changes in the environment brought about by people.

A sector of the economy in which an aggregate of commercial enterprises is engaged in the reproduction of written text or images in multiple copies such as books, periodicals, newspapers or other similar formats.\n(Source: SIC)
The art, process or business of producing reproductions of written text or images in multiple copies, in book, periodical or newspaper formats, or in other similar formats.\n(Source: SIC / RHW)
Living quarters where a group of persons (family) live together.\n(Source: GOOD)
The branch of law dealing with such aspects of relationships between individuals that are of no direct concern to the state.
Segment of the economy not run by government, including households, sole traders, partnerships and companies.
Transport performed with private means.
An order of herbivorous placental mammals characterized by having a proboscis, incisors enlarged to become tusks, and pillarlike legs with five toes bound together on a broad pad.

Organisms (i.e. prokaryotes) whose genetic material (filaments of DNA) is not enclosed by a nuclear membrane, and that do not possess mitochondria or plastids. Bacteria and cyanophyta are the only prokaryotic organisms.

Law which prescribes method of enforcing rights or obtaining redress for their invasion. Laws which fix duties, establish rights and responsibilities among and for persons, natural or otherwise, are "substantive laws" in character, while those which merely prescribe the manner in which such rights and responsibilities may be exercised and enforced in a court are "procedural laws".\n(Source: BLACK)
The act of converting material from one form into another desired form.
Water used in a manufacturing or treatment process or in the actual product manufactured.

Obligations, responsibilities or debts imposed upon all members of an industry that manufactures or produces a product or service causing injury or harm to a consumer and apportioned according to each member's share of the market for the product.\n(Source: BLD)

1. Something produced by human or mechanical effort or by a natural process.
2. A chemical substance formed as a result of a chemical reaction.
3. A commodity offered for sale.
4. A quantity obtained by multiplication of two or more numbers.
Factual, circumstantial and, often, comparative knowledge concerning various goods, services or events, their quality and the entities producing them.
The amount of output or yield per unit of input or expenditure achieved by a company, industry or country.
The general direction or tendency in the measurement of the production of goods and services having exchange value.
The legal liability of manufacturers and sellers to compensate buyers, users, and even bystanders, for damages or injuries suffered because of defects in goods purchased.

A standard which prescribes aspects of the physical or chemical composition of products which have potential for causing environmental damage or the handling, presentation and packaging of products, particularly those which are toxic.\n(Source: GRAHAW)

1. An excess of the receipts over the spending, costs and expenses of a business or other commercial entity during any period.
2. What it remains after subtracting from the total of the revenues the total of the costs of an economic activity or a commercial or financial operation.
3. Income following the deduction of all expenses, taxes, and the like.
4. The advantageous quality of being beneficial.
5. To derive a benefit from.

1. A scheme of action, a method of proceeding, or a series of steps, thought out in advance to accomplish a goal.
2. To enter a program or other instructions into a computer (or other electronic device) to instruct it to do a particular task.
3. To arrange the schedule of an event.
An interdiction or forbidding of an activity or action by authority or law.

1. To make or work out a plan for; devise.
2. To extend out or project in space.
3. To show on a screen.
4. To communicate vividly (e.g. feelings).
A gas used in aerosol preparations to expel the liquid contents through an atomizer.
The pursuit of legal proceedings, particularly criminal proceedings.
State of being prosperous; wealth or success.
Area surrounding a water recovery plant in which certain forms of soil utilization are restricted or prohibited in order to protect the groundwater.\n(Source: AZENP)
Measures adopted for the safeguarding of species, of their ecosystems and their biodiversity.\n(Source: ADMIN)
A series of procedures and devices designed to preserve people, property or the environment from injury or harm.\n(Source: RHW)
Any of a class of high-molecular weight polymer compounds composed of a variety of alfa-amino acids joined by peptide linkages.

1. The original draft of a document.
2. An international agreement of a less formal nature than a treaty. It is often used to amend treaties. (Source: DICLAW)
3. A formal description of digital message formats and the rules for exchanging those messages in or between computing systems and in telecommunications.

A diverse phylum of eukaryotic microorganisms; the structure varies from a simple uninucleate protoplast to colonial forms, the body is either naked or covered by a test, locomotion is by means of pseudopodia or cilia or flagella, there is a tendency toward universal symmetry in floating species and radial symmetry in sessile types, and nutrition may be phagotrophic or autotrophic or saprozoic.

1. A geographic area of some considerable extent, smaller than a continent but larger than a region, which is unified by some or all of its characteristics and which can therefore be studied as a whole. A faunal province, for example, has a particular assemblage of animal species, which differs from assemblages in different contemporaneous environments elsewhere.\n(Source: WHIT)
2. An administrative subdivision of a country, in some cases relatively autonomous and equivalent to a state, in others, smaller and less autonomous and more akin to a county.
The science that deals with the functions of the mind and the behaviour of an organism in relation to its environment.\n(Source: MGH)
Illness arising from or aggravated by a mind-body relationship.
A measure or provision taken on behalf and with the consent of the general populace.
A place having baths for public use.
A building to which there is free access by the public and which is available for the use of a community.

The discipline in health science that, at the level of the community or the public, aims at promoting prevention of disease, sanitary living, laws, practices and a healthier environment.\n(Source: GUNN)
The branch of law which governs relationships between individuals and the government.
The purported, collective view of the public on some issue or problem, typically formulated by selective polling or sampling, and frequently used as a guide to action or decision.
The canvassing of a representative sample of a large group of people on some question in order to determine the general opinion of a group.
Park with big trees, ornamental plants, alleys bordered by trees or bushes, fountains and statues situated in a town and whose access is free.
The involvement of citizens in public matters, with the purpose of exerting influence.
A joint venture between corporations and government or between community members and government or business beyond the course of normal interaction.
Segment of the economy run to some degree by government, including national and local governments, government-owned firms and quasi-autonomous non-government organizations.
An enterprise concerned with the provision to the public of essentials, such as electricity or water.\n(Source: CED)
The act or the means of conveying people in mass as opposed to conveyance in private vehicles.\n(Source: GOOD)
An enterprise concerned with the provision to the public of essentials, such as electricity or water.\n(Source: CED)
Any disease pertaining to the lungs.

1. A soft and moist mass of material usually obtained by pressing or beating a relatively hard object. It is mostly used about vegetable matter.
2. The soft center of a tooth, where blood vessels and nerve endings are located.
3. The soft and moist interior of a fruit.
4. The edible inner of fruit, as opposed to that of animals, fish or nuts.

1. A machine that draws a fluid into itself through an entrance port and forces the fluid out through an exhaust port.\n(Source: MGH)
2. To use a pump to move (liquid or gas).
3. To move up and down (e.g. weights in the gym).

1. The acquisition or the act of buying something by payment of money or its equivalent.
2. To obtain in exchange for money or goods.
3. The mechanical advantage gained by being in a position to use a lever.
The removal of unwanted constituents from a substance.
Any of a number of nitrogenous bases, such as guanine and adenine, that are derivatives of purine and constituents of nucleic acids and certain coenzymes.\n(Source: CED)
The breaking apart of complex molecules into simpler units by the use of heat.\n(Source: MGH)
The inspection, analysis, and other relevant actions taken to provide control over what is being done, manufactured, or fabricated, so that a desirable level of quality is achieved and maintained.
All the factors that determine the well-being of an individual or societies, including wealth, employment, physical and mental health, environment, education and leisure time.

1. An open or surface working or excavation for the extraction of building stone, ore, coal, gravel, or minerals.
2. Animal hunted or caught for food.
3. A person who is the aim of an attack (especially a victim of ridicule or exploitation) by some hostile person or influence.
The surface exploitation and removal of stone or mineral deposits from the earth's crust.\n(Source: MGH)

The associations, tensions or harmony between two or more groups of people distinguished by history, culture, religion or physique: distinctions erroneously construed as being based on consistent biological differences and as representing, in effect, species of a human genus.\n(Source: SOC / RHW)
A system using beamed and reflected radiofrequency energy for detecting and locating objects, measuring distance or altitude, navigating, homing, bombing and other purposes.

Emission of any rays from either natural or man-made origins, such as radio waves, the sun's rays, medical X-rays and the fall-out and nuclear wastes produced by nuclear weapons and nuclear energy production. Radiation is usually divided between non-ionizing radiation, such as thermal radiation (heat) and light, and nuclear radiation. Non-ionizing radiation includes ultraviolet radiation from the sun which, although it can damage cells and tissues, does not involve the ionization events of nuclear radiation.\n(Source: WRIGHT)
Somatic and genetic damage to living organisms caused by exposure to ionizing radiation.
The total amount of radiation absorbed by material or tissues, in the sense of absorbed dose, exposure dose, or dose equivalent.

Prolonged exposure to ionizing radiation from various sources that can be harmful. Nuclear radiation from fallout from nuclear weapons or from power stations, background radiation from substances naturally present in the soil, exposure to X-rays can cause radiation sickness. Massive exposure to radiation can kill quickly and any person exposed to radiation is more likely to develop certain types of cancer than other members of the population.\n(Source: PHC)
The act or state of being subjected to electromagnetic energy strong enough to ionize atoms thereby posing a threat to human health or the environment.\n(Source: APD / MHD)

The periodic or continuous surveillance or analysis of the level of radiant energy present in a given area, to determine that its prescribed amount has not been exceeded or that it meets acceptable safety standards.\n(Source: TOE / OMD)
The study of ionizing radiation and its effects on matter.
Precautionary actions, measures or equipment implemented to guard or defend people, property and natural resources from the harmful effects of ionizing energy.

Damage to the body resulting from excessive exposure to ionizing radiation which causes symptoms like nausea, fatigue, vomiting, and diarrhea and in severe cases loss of hair, hemorrhage, inflammation and death.

1. The process, equipment or programming involved in transmitting and receiving sound signals by electromagnetic waves.
2. A device that can capture the signal sent over radio waves and render the modulated signal as sound.
Contamination of a substance, living organism or site caused by radioactive material.
The release of radioactive substances into the environment deriving from nuclear installations and from mining, purification and enrichment operations of radioactive elements.\n(Source: FLGISA)
The material that descends to the earth or water well beyond the site of a surface or subsurface nuclear explosion.
Any substance that contains one or more radionuclides of which the activity or the concentration cannot be disregarded as far as radiation protection is concerned.\n(Source: ECHO2)

A radioactive isotope which, when injected into a biological or physical system, can be traced by radiation detection devices, permitting determination of the distribution or location of the substance to which it is attached.
Any waste that emit radiation in excess of normal background level, including the toxic by-products of the nuclear energy industry.
The property possessed by some atomic nuclei of disintegrating spontaneously, with loss of energy through emission of a charged particle and/or gamma radiation.

1. A nuclide that exhibits radioactivity.
2. An unstable isotope of an element that decays or disintegrates spontaneously, emitting radiation.

A radioactive gaseous element emitted naturally from rocks and minerals where radioactive elements are present. It is released in non-coal mines, e.g. tin, iron, fluorspar, uranium. Radon is an alpha particle emitter as are its decay products and has been indicted as a cause of excessive occurrence of lung cancer in uranium miners. Concern has been expressed at radon levels in some housing usually adjacent to granite rocks or old tin mining regions.\n(Source: PORT)

1. To make someone rather angry or impatient; to cause annoyance.
2. A piece of old cloth; a tattered piece of cloth; a shred, a tatter.
The movement and circulation of vehicles transporting goods and people on railroad systems.
Transportation of goods and persons by railway.\n(Source: CEDa)

1. Precipitation in the form of liquid water drops with diameters greater than 0.5 millimetres.
2. To fall from the clouds in drops of water.
A forest of broad-leaved, mainly evergreen, trees found in continually moist climates in the tropics, subtropics, and some parts of the temperate zones.
A sporting fixture that could not be completed because of rain.
Water which falls as rain from clouds.
A test which does not always yield the same result when repeated under the same conditions.
Species which have a restricted world range.
A crude, unprocessed or partially processed material used as feedstock for a processing operation.
Measures used to ensure the provision of or the access to crude, unprocessed or partially processed materials used as feedstock for processing or manufacturing.\n(Source: RHWa /  MHD)
That branch of physical chemistry concerned with the mechanisms and rates of chemical reactions.
A device that introduces either inductive or capacitive reactance into a circuit, such as a coil or capacitor.\n(Source: MGH)
Those studies and activities that seek to minimise the risk of a nuclear reactor accident.\n(Source: RRDA)

1. An action which is advisory in nature rather than one having any binding effect.
2. The act of commending.

1. Activities that promote refreshment of health or spirits by relaxation and enjoyment.
2. Any activity, such as play, that diverts, amuses or stimulates.
Paper that has been separated from the solid waste stream for utilization as a raw material in the manufacture of a new product.
A resource recovery method involving the collection and treatment of a waste product for use as raw material in the manufacture of the same or a similar product.

Management of all the stages involved in the life of a product such as raw materials acquisition, manufacturing, distribution and retail, use and re-use and maintenance, recycling and waste management, in order to create less environmentally harmful products.\n(Source: PORT)
Sea water which is covered or discoloured by the sudden growth of algal bloom or by a great increase in single-celled organisms, dinoflagellates.
Chemical reaction in which an element gains an electron.
Any of various types of tall stiff grass-like plants growing together in groups near water.
A line of rocks in the tidal zone of a coast, submerged at high water but partly uncovered at low water.
A factory for the purification of some crude material such as ore, sugar, oil, etc.\n(Source: CED)
The processing of raw material to remove impurities. \n\n(Source: PHC)
The return of waves or particles from surfaces on which they are incident.
The study of the reflectance of light or other radiant energy.

1. A substance that by undergoing a change in phase (liquid to gas, gas to liquid) releases or absorbs a large latent heat in relation to its volume, and thus effects a considerable cooling effect.
2. Causing cold or cooling.
The cooling of substances, usually food, below the environmental temperature for preservative purposes.
A household appliance used for keeping food fresh by refrigeration.

1. A restricted and isolated area in which plants and animals persisted during a period of continental climatic change that made surrounding areas uninhabitable; especially an ice-free or unglaciated area within or close to a continental ice sheet or upland ice cap, where hardy biotas eked out an existence during a glacial phase. It later served as a center of dispersal for the repopulation of surrounding areas after climatic readjustment.
2. A shelter from danger or hardship.
3. A place of safety, refuge or protection.
4. A shielding or protection against the unpleasant, unwanted, or dangerous.
A person who is outside his country of origin and who, due to well-founded fear of persecution, is unable or unwilling to avail himself of that country protection.
Compost derived by the biodegradation of the organic constituents of solid wastes and wastewater sludges.
The renewing or reuse of materials such as activated carbon, single ion exchange resins, and filter beds by appropriate means to remove organics, metals, solids, etc.\n(Source: LEE)

1. A designated area or an administrative division of a city, county or larger geographical territory that is formulated according to some biological, political, economic or demographic criteria.
2. A place in or a part of the body in any way indicated.
3. Any considerable and connected part of a space or surface.
4. A large area or range of something specified but with undefined boundaries.
5. A tract of land of undefined size.

1. An instance of or a certificate attesting to the fact of entering in an official list various pieces of information in order to facilitate regulation or authorization, including one's name, contact information and, in some instances, data concerning a specific possession or property.
2. The act of registering or state of being registered.

Resources that have a natural rate of availability and yield a continual flow of services which may be consumed in any time period without endangering future consumption possibilities as long as current use does not exceed net renewal during the period under consideration.
A rule established by authority; a permanent rule of action.
A conservation measure involving the correction of past abuses that have impaired the productivity of the resources base.\n(Source: MGH)
The provision with new or different housing.

1. The expression of man's belief in and reverence for a superhuman power recognized as the creator and governor of the universe.
2. An institution to express belief in a divine power.

1. The scientific detection, recognition, inventory and analysis of land and water area by the use of distant sensors or recording devices such as photography, thermal scanners, radar, etc.
2. Complex of techniques for the remote measure of electromagnetic energy emitted by objects.

1. The elimination of substances from a medium or from the environment.\n(Source: RRDA)
2. The act of removing a part from a whole.
A process of returning natural ecosystems or habitats to their original structure and species composition.

A resource capable of being continuously renewed or replaced through such processes as organic reproduction and cultivation such as those practiced in agriculture, animal husbandry, forestry and fisheries.
