1. Substitution of an atom or atomic group with a different one.
2. The act of replacing or substituting.
3. Someone appointed as the substitute of another, and empowered to act for him, in his name or on his behalf.
Any conduct or action undertaken on behalf of a person, group, business or government, often as an elected or appointed voice.
Restoration of contaminated nuclear fuel to a usable condition.

1. A class of terrestrial vertebrates, characterized by the lack of hair, feathers, and mammary glands; the skin is covered with scales, they have a three chambered heart and the pleural and peritoneal cavities are continuous.
2. Any cold-blooded vertebrate of the class Reptilia.
Service organized to provide immediate assistance to persons injured or in distress.\n(Source: RRDA)

1. Scientific investigation aimed at discovering and applying new facts, techniques and natural laws.
2. A detailed critical inspection.
Proposal, plan or design containing the necessary information and data for conducting a specific survey.
An artificial or natural storage place for water, such as a lake or pond, from which the water may be withdrawn as for irrigation, municipal water supply, or flood control.
Area that has only private houses, not offices and factories.
A building allocated for residence.
Remaining potential for harm to persons, property or the environment following all possible efforts to reduce predictable hazards.\n(Source: TOE)
Any of a class of solid or semisolid organic products of natural or synthetic origin with no definite melting point, generally of high molecular weight.
Absorption or, less commonly, adsorption of material by a body or system from which the material was previously released.

1. Any component of the environment that can be utilized by an organism.
2. Something that one uses.
The process in living organisms of taking in oxygen from the surroundings and giving out carbon dioxide.
Air volumes inspired and expired through the lungs.
A disease of the airways.
Any of a group of devices that protect the respiratory system from exposure to airborne contaminants; usually a mask with a fitting to cover the nose and mouth.\n(Source: KOREN)
The structures and passages involved with intake, expulsion, and exchange of oxygen and carbon dioxide in the vertebrate body.
The obligation to answer for an act done, and to repair or otherwise make restitution for any injury it may have caused.
Resistant structure that allows the organism to survive adverse environmental conditions.\n(Source: ALL2)
The process of renewing or returning something to its original, normal or unimpaired condition.
The sale of goods, in small numbers and directly to the consumer.
A basin designed and operated to provide temporary storage and thus reduce the peak flood flows of a stream.

Any container which has been conceived and designed to accomplish within its life cycle a minimum number of trips or rotations in order to be refilled or reused for the same purpose for which it was conceived.\n(Source: PORT)

Planting of new trees and, particularly, of native plants in disturbed sites where the vegetation cover has been destroyed, to stabilize the land surface from wind and water erosion and to reclame the land for other uses.
A technique whereby a solution is forced through a semipermeable membrane under pressure, used to generate drinkable water from sea water, or to separate chemical compounds.

1. An erect grass, Oryza sativa, that grows in East Asia on wet ground and has drooping flower spikes and yellow oblong edible grains that become white when polished.
2. Seeds of the rice plant (Oryza sativa) used as food.
3. Boiled rice.

A legal guarantee or just claim enabling a citizen or employee to compose and submit a formal written request to an authority asking for some benefit or favor or for intervention and redress of some wrong.

The individual's right to know in general about the existence of data banks, the right to be informed on request and the general right to a print-out of the information registered and to know the actual use made of the information.

1. The expected number of lives lost, persons injured, damage to property and disruption of economic activity due to a particular natural phenomenon, and consequently the product of the probability of occurrence and the expected magnitude of damage.\n(Source: GUNN /  RRDA)
2. A qualitative assessment describing the likelihood of an attacker/threat using an exploit to successfully bypass a defender, attack a vulnerability, and compromise a system. (Schneider)
A technique used to determine the likelihood or chance of hazardous events occurring (such as release of a certain quantity of a toxic gas) and the likely consequences.

The qualitative and quantitative evaluation performed in an effort to define the risk posed to human health and/or the environment by an action or by the presence or use of a specific substance or pollutant.
A systematic process of evaluating and assessing the hazards of loss versus the possibility of financial gain or profit.
The exchange of information about health or environmental risks among risk assessors and managers, the general public, news media, interest groups, etc.
A subjective appreciation by individuals which will more often than not bear little relation to the statistical probability of damage or injury.
Any act, instance or process lowering the probability that harm will come to an area or its population as the result of some hazard.
A stream of water which flows in a channel from high ground to low ground and ultimately to a lake or the sea, except in a desert area where it may dwindle away to nothing.
Water which flows in a channel from high ground to low ground and ultimately to a lake or the sea, except in a desert area where it may dwindle away to nothing.\n(Source: WHIT)
A long piece of hard ground that people can drive along from one place to another.
Any measure, technique or design intended to reduce the risk of harm posed by moving vehicles along a constructed land route.\n(Source: RHW)
Salt used against the formation of ice on roads.
Circulation of motor vehicles and people on the road network.

Discipline which includes the design of highways and pedestrian ways, the study and application of traffic statistics, and the environmental aspects of the transportation of goods and people.\n(Source: CED)

1. Any aggregate of minerals that makes up part of the earth's crust. It may be unconsolidated, such as sand, clay, or mud, or consolidated, such as granite, limestone, or coal.
2. To move gently back and forth.
3. A music style characterized by basic drum-beat, generally 4/4 riffs, based on (usually electric) guitar, bass guitar, drums, and vocals.
A generic term for felted or matted fibers manufactured by blowing or spinning threads of molten rock, slag, or glass.\n(Source: BJGEO)
Any of the relatively small placental mammals that constitute the order Rodentia, having constantly growing incisor teeth specialized for gnawing.

1. The absorbing and anchoring organ of a vascular plant; it bears neither leaves nor flowers and is usually subterranean.
2. A word from which another word or words are derived.
3. Origin, beginning of an event, a condition or a period

A heat-treating furnace of circular construction which rotates the workpiece around the axis of the furnace during heat treatment; workpieces are transported through the furnace along a circular path.

1. A cream to dark brown elastic material obtained by coagulating and drying the latex from certain plants, especially the rubber tree.
2. A contraceptive device consisting of a thin rubber or latex sheath worn over the penis during intercourse.
3. An elastic hydrocarbon polymer that naturally occurs as a milky colloidal suspension, or latex, in the sap of some plants.

The systematic series of actions in which a solid substance deriving from rubber trees and plants is toughened and treated chemically to give it the strength, elasticity, resistance and other qualities needed for the manufacture of products such as erasers, elastic bands, water hoses, electrical insulation and tires.\n(Source: RHW)
A sector of the economy in which an aggregate of commercial enterprises is engaged in the manufacture and marketing of natural or synthetic rubber products.\n(Source: RHW)
Any refuse or unwanted material made of synthetic or natural rubber, often the byproduct of rubber processing.\n(Source: RHW)

Rate at which water is removed by flowing over the soil surface. This rate is determined by the texture of the soil, slope, climate, and land use cover (e.g. paved surface, grass, forest, bare soil).\n(Source: LANDY)
The total number of persons inhabiting an agricultural or pastoral region.\n(Source: RHW)
A form of tourism in which holidays are organized in a farm: meals are prepared with natural products and guests are entertained with handicraft, sporting and agricultural activities.

1. The state of being secure from harm, injury, danger or risk.
2. A contraceptive device consisting of a thin rubber or latex sheath worn over the penis during intercourse.
An action, procedure or contrivance designed to lower the occurrence or risk of injury, loss and danger to persons, property or the environment.\n(Source: OED / RHW)
A principle or regulation governing actions, procedures or devices intended to lower the occurrence or risk of injury, loss and danger to persons, property or the environment.\n(Source: OED / RHW)
A norm or measure applicable in legal cases for any action, procedure or contrivance designed to lower the occurrence or risk of injury, loss and danger to persons, property or the environment.

Research, detailed examination and usually a written report on the need for or efficacy of actions, procedures or devices intended to lower the occurrence or risk of injury, loss and danger to persons, property or the environment.

1. Any amphibian of the order Urodela (or Caudata). The adults keep their tails by opposition to the frogs and the caecilians.
2. Name given to most of the species of amphibians of the order Urodela.
The accumulation of soluble salts by evaporation of the waters that bore them to the soil zone, in a soil of an arid, poorly drained region.

General name for a family of microorganisms, one of the largest groups of bacteria, that includes those most frequently implicated in food poisoning and gastroenteritis. Unhygienic handling and inadequate cooking of poultry and meat, improper storage of cold meats and, more recently, contamination of battery-reared hen eggs, are the most common sources of salmonella infections.\n(Source: WRIGHT)
Amount of salt contained in a solution.
Area of brackish, shallow water usually found in coastal areas and in deltas.
A meadow subject to overflow by salt water.
The core of a salt dome.

1. The reaction product when a metal displaces the hydrogen of an acid.
2. A condiment (NaCl - Sodium Chloride) used to add to or enhance the flavour of food (commonly with pepper).
3. Containing salt.
4. To season with salt.
5. To preserve with salt.
6. To spread salt.
7. Randomly generated data added to an encryption algorithm to increase its effectiveness.
Water that contains dissolved salts.
The act, process, or business of rescuing vessels or their cargoes from loss at sea.
The obtaining of small representative quantities of material for the purpose of analysis.
Method of selecting items at random from a set in such a manner that the sample will be representative of the whole.

1. A measure, including removal of diplomatic ties, ban on trade, or military intervention, adopted by a country, or group of countries, against another country for political reasons.
2. The approval, by some authority, that makes something valid.

1. A loose material consisting of small mineral particles, or rock and mineral particles, distinguishable by the naked eye; grains vary from almost spherical to angular, with a diameter range from 1/16 to 2 millimeters.
2. To cover with sand.
3. To rub with sandpaper.

Stabilization of dunes effected by the planting of marram grass (Ammophila arenaria), or rice grass, whose long roots bind the surface layers of sand and so hinder its removal by wind. A larger scale method of dealing with the same problem is by afforestation.\n(Source: BLYFRE)
An accumulation of loose sand heaped up by the wind.
The extraction of sand by mining for building purposes and for the extraction of heavy minerals such as rutile and zircon.
A place where sand is extracted from the ground.
The study and use of practical measures for the preservation of public health.
Plans for the control of the physical factors in the human environment that can harm development, health, or survival.
Indication or measure of the level of organic pollution.
Referring to the classification of organisms according to the way in which they tolerate pollution.
An object that orbits around a larger one.
The amount of current income which is not spent for survival or enjoyment.
Small wood fragments produced by a saw when cutting.
A disease in which humans are parasitized by any of three species of blood flukes: Schistosoma mansoni, S. haematobium, and S. japonicum; adult worms inhabit the blood vessels.

1. An institution or building at which children and young people receive education.
2. Group of a large number of fish (or other sea animals, such as dolphins or whales), normally from the same species, that swim together.
Instruction or training received in any educational institution, but especially to persons under college age.\n(Source: RHW)

The study of the physical universe and its contents by means of reproducible observations, measurements, and experiments to establish, verify, or modify general laws to explain its nature and behaviour.
Recyclable material from any manufacturing process or discarded consumer products.
The amount of money or the monetary rate at which materials discarded from manufacturing operations can be bought or sold.\n(Source: TOE / RHW)
Any metal material discarded from manufacturing operations and usually suitable for reprocessing.
Car which is no longer functional and may be dismantled for spare parts or completely demolished.
The reduction of the electric field about a nucleus by the space charge of the surrounding electrons.

1. The mass of water occupying all of the Earth's surface not occupied by land, but excluding all lakes and inland seas.
2. In general, the marine section of the globe as opposed to that of the land.
3. A body of salt water that is smaller than an ocean and generally in proximity to a continent.
4. Different parts of the ocean.
5. The use of the sea (as in, naval operations, the shipping trade, the profession of a sailor, etc.)
6. The darker parts of the moon's surface.
7. A large lake.
8. The volume of water in the sea in relation to the tides.
9. Condition of the sea with regards to ts use (like sailing or swimming).
10. At sea, the direction of the waves.
11. A large, heavy wave in the sea.
12. Wind driven waves.
13. A large number (of something)
14. A large horizontal surface.
15. A great quantity (of a liquid).
16. A space filled with particles of a certain kind.
17. A large quantity (of something).
The bottom of the ocean.
Large-scale horizontal water motion within an ocean.
The level of the surface of the ocean; especially, the mean level halfway between high and low tide, used as a standard in reckoning land elevation or sea depths.
The zone of unconsolidated material that extends landward from the low water-line to where there is marked change in material or physiographic form or to the line of permanent vegetation.

1. One of the six equal periods into which the Hindu year is divided.
2. One of the four equal periods into which the year is divided by the equinoxes and solstices, resulting from the apparent movement of the sun north and south of the equator during the course of the earth's orbit around it. These periods (spring, summer, autumn and winter) have their characteristic weather conditions in different regions, and occur at opposite times of the year in the N and S hemispheres.
3. A yearly recurring period of undetermined length, relatively long but still shorter than a year, when a certain crop is ripe or a certain type of work, most commonly related to agriculture, is being performed.
4. A predetermined series of cultural events; for example theatrical performances or  sports events, that take place under an extended period of time, which however is shorter than a year.
5. To add spices.
The periodic movement of a population from one region or climate to another in accordance with the yearly cycle of weather and temperature changes.
Water found in the seas or oceans which has an average salinity of about 3.5%.
Removal salt from ocean or brackish water.
In the case of disruption of an existing biotope, secondary biotope can be created as a compensation and substitute measure for the loss of the natural one.\n(Source: RRDA)
The years of instruction following elementary school and until the end of high school.\n(Source: COE)
The part of a country or region's economy that produces commodities without much direct use of natural resources.
Goods or products that have been used previously.

A part of a country's or region's commercial, industrial and financial activity, delimited either by public, corporate and private organization of expenditures or by agriculture, manufacturing and service product types.
A geomorphic feature of the earth in which the surface has subsided for a prolonged time, including deep ocean floors, intercontinental rifts and elevated and interior drainage basins.

1. Any material transported by water which will ultimately settle to the bottom after the water loses its transporting power.\n(Source: LANDY)
2. Matter deposited by some natural process.
A chemical applied before planting to protect seeds and seedlings from disease or insects.
The slow movement of water through small openings and spaces in the surface of unsaturated soil into or out of a body of surface or subsurface water.\n(Source: MGH)
The phenomenon of Earth movements.
The gathering of seismic data from an area.
The official or legally authorized act of taking away possessions or property, often for a violation of law or to enforce a judgment imposed by a court of law.
A highly toxic, nonmetallic element with symbol Se and atomic number 34; used in analytical chemistry, metallurgy, and photoelectric cells.
A natural process of organic degradation that produces nutrients utilized by autotrophic organisms.\n(Source: LBC)
A solid crystalline material whose electrical conductivity is intermediate between that of a metal and an insulator and is usually strongly temperature-dependent.
Product that has undergone a partial processing and is used as raw material in a successive productive step.\n(Source: ZINZAN)
An element having some properties characteristic of metals and others of non-metals.

A formalized procedure to identify the impact of changes in various model components on model output. Sensitivity analysis is an integral part of simulation experimentation and may influence model formulations. It is commonly used to examine model behaviour. The general procedure is to define a model output variable that represents an important aspect of model behaviour. The values of various inputs of the model are then varied and the resultant change in the output variable is monitored. Large changes in the output variable imply that the particular input varied is important in controlling model behaviour. Within this general definition, sensitivity analysis has been applied to a variety of model inputs including state variables, environmental variables and initial conditions.\n(Source: YOUNG)
A machine for separating materials of different specific gravity by means of water or air.
A tank, usually underground, into which sewage flows, the deposited matter being wholly, or partially broken down through anaerobic action.

1. 1) A legal term referring generally to the act of valuable property being taken into custody by an agent of the court and locked away for safekeeping, usually to prevent the property from being disposed of or abused before a dispute over its ownership can be resolved.\n2) The taking of someone's property, voluntarily (by deposit) or involuntarily (by seizure), by court officers or into the possession of a third party, awaiting the outcome of a trial in which ownership of that property is at issue.\n(Source: DUC /  EMBMO)
2. The act of segregating or sequestering.
Any reptile of the suborder Serpentes, typically having a scaly cylindrical limbless body, fused eyelids, and a jaw modified for swallowing large prey.

1. The business sector that consists of companies whose line of work involves doing something for customers, but that do not produce goods.
2. A service station to get food and eat something, often found at motorways.
The distribution or total amount of communities, villages and houses within a specified geographic area.
The expansion of urban areas into surrounding rural areas, creating low-density neighbourhoods.
A tank into which a two-phase mixture is fed and the entrained solids settle by gravity during storage.
A liquid composed by waste substances in decomposition that is conveyed in sewers.
Area of land on which sewage or any other type of waste water is distributed in order to purify it.
A semi-liquid waste with a solid concentration in excess of 2500 parts per million, obtained from the purification of municipal sewage.
System of pipes, usually underground, for carrying waste water and human waste away from houses and other buildings, to a place where they can be safely get rid of.
An aquatic invertebrate, such as a mollusc or crustacean, that has a shell.
Barrier devised for keeping people away from harmful substances.

Agricultural practice using the rotation of fields rather than crops, short cropping periods followed by long fallows and the maintenance of fertility by the regeneration of vegetation.\n(Source: PHC)

1. A vessel propelled by engines or sails for navigating on the water, especially a large vessel that can not be carried aboard another, as distinguished from a boat.
2. A boat that by its size, solidity and power is appropriate for long navigations and big marine enterprises.
The art or business of designing and constructing ships.
An unexpected incident, failure or loss involving a vessel or its contents in the course of commercial transport that poses potential harm to persons, property or the environment.\n(Source: RHW)
Domestic and operational wastes, disposed of continuously or periodically, that are generated during the normal operation of a ship; usually excluding fresh fish waste from fishing operations.
Area designed for target shooting.

1. A place, especially a small building, for the retail sale of goods and services.
2. To visit shops; to look around shops with the intention of buying something.

1. A performance, program or exhibition providing entertainment to a group of people, displayed either through some communication media, such as radio or television, or live at a museum or theater.
2. To give a proof that something is true.
3. To have somebody see something.
4. To go or travel in the company of someone.
5. The pretending that something is the case in order to make a good impression.
A size-reduction machine which tears or grinds materials to a smaller and more uniform particle size.

1. A woody perennial plant, smaller than a tree, with several major branches arising from near the base of the main stem.
2. A plant resembling a small tree, but has no, and will never develop, a stem.

A set of symptoms, including headaches, fatigue, eye irritation, and dizziness, typically affecting workers in modern airtight office buildings and thought to be caused by indoor pollutants, such as formaldehyde fumes, particulate matter, microorganisms, etc.
Any secondary effect, especially an undesirable one.
The size distribution of solid particles on a series of standard sieves of decreasing size, expressed as a weight percent.\n(Source: MGH)
Any device designed to reduce noise, especially the device in the exhaust system of a motor vehicle.

A brittle metalloid element with symbol Si and atomic number 14 that exists in two allotropic forms; occurs principally in sand, quartz, granite, feldspar, and clay. It is usually a grey crystalline solid but is also found as a brown amorphous powder. It is used in transistors, rectifiers, solar cells, and alloys. Its compounds are widely used in glass manufacture, the building industry, and in the form of silicones.
A large round tower on a farm for storing grain or winter food for cattle.

The fine mineral material formed from the erosion of rock fragments and deposited by rivers and lakes. Its particles are the intermediate form between sand and clay. The particles can range in size from 0.01-0.05 mm in diameter.

1. A very ductile malleable brilliant greyish-white element with symbol Ar and atomic number 47 having the highest electrical and thermal conductivity of any metal.
2. Made of silver.
3. The colour of silver. A shiny greyish-white.

1. A representation of a problem, situation in mathematical terms, especially using a computer.\n(Source: CED)
2. The attempt by a football player to gain an unfair advantage by falling to the ground and possibly feigning an injury.
Act of fixing the cross-section of structural components on the basis of statics and material strength.
The gliding over snow on skis, especially as a sport.

1. The tissue forming the outer covering of the vertebrate body: it consists of two layers, the outermost of which may be covered with hair, scales, feathers, etc. It is mainly protective and sensory in function.
2. Strip or pull off the skin or hide of
A nonmetallic product resulting from the interaction of flux and impurities in the smelting and refining of metals.
A place where animals are butchered for food.
Animal body parts cut off in the preparation of carcasses for use as food. This waste can come from several sources including slaughterhouses, restaurants, stores and farms.\n(Source: OED)

1. A periodic state of physiological rest during which consciousness is suspended and metabolic rate is decreased.
2. To rest in a state of decreased consciousness and reduced metabolism.
Medical disorder of the sleep patterns of a person or animal. (Source: Wikipedia)

1. A semifluid, slushy, murky mass of sediment resulting from treatment of water, sewage, or industrial and mining wastes, and often appearing as local bottom deposits in polluted bodies of water.\n(Source: BJGEO)
2. Soaked clay or soil; very soft ground.
3. A soft, soupy, or muddy bottom deposit, such as found on tideland or in a stream bed.
Vertical sliding gate or valve to regulate the flow of water in a channel or lock.
Air pollution consisting of smoke and fog.
Action, device or announcement that serves to give caution or notice to the level of air pollutants typically associated with oxidants in a given area.

1. An aerosol, consisting of visible particles and gases, produced by the incomplete burning of carbon-based materials, such as wood and fossil fuels.
2. To inhale smoke from for example a cigarette or a cigar.
3. A product manufactured out of cured and finely cut leaves, which are rolled or stuffed into a paper-wrapped cylinder for smoking.
4. To kill a person or an animal with a shot from a firearm.
5. To expose food to the smoke of wood fires in order to preserve it.
6. To give off smoke.

1. The inhalation and exhalation of carcinogenic fumes from burning plant material, usually tobacco.
2. The process of flavoring, cooking, or preserving food by exposing it to the smoke from burning or smoldering plant materials, most often wood.
Family of snakes (Colubridae), including many harmless snakes, such as the grass snake.

1. The most common form of frozen precipitation, usually flakes or starlike crystals, matted ice needles, or combinations, and often rime-coated.
2. To fall from the clouds in the form of ice crystals.
3. Material composed of small ice crystals.
4. A street name for cocaine.
5. To confuse completely by concealing one's true motives from, especially by elaborately feigning good intentions so as to gain an end.
An avalanche of relatively pure snow; some rock and earth material may also be carried downward.
Absorption of liquid by a solid or a semisolid material.\n(Source: MGH)

1. A cleansing agent, manufactured in bars, granules, flakes, or liquid form, made from a mixture of the sodium salts of various fatty acids of natural oils and fats.
2. A television serial about the lives of melodramatic characters, which are often filled with strong emotions, highly dramatic situations and suspense.
An existing circumstance, situation or state affecting the life, welfare and relations of human beings in community.\n(Source: RHW)
The state of nations and the historical processes of change experienced by them.

A concept associated with evolutionary theories of history and with structural functionalism. Societies are seen as moving from the simple to the complex via a process of social change based on structural differentiation.
The pattern, change, development and driving forces of a human group, community or society.
Any structure designed, built or installed to provide space for living or interaction among persons in a community.\n(Source: RHW)
A collection of people who interact with one another and share a certain feeling of unity.\n(Source: SOC)
Medicine as applied to treatment of diseases which occur in certain social groups.
A organized effort by a significant number of people to change (or resist change in) some major aspect or aspects of society.
Collective, civic action shared and performed by a significant number of the community or general population.\n(Source: RHW)

A course of action adopted and pursued by government, business or some other organization, which seeks to ensure that all people have acceptable working or living conditions by providing social security, welfare, health care, insurance, fair employment practices, low cost housing or educational opportunities.

A generic term applied to the range of conditions and aberrant behaviours which are considered to be manifestations of social disorganization and to warrant changing via some means of social engineering.
Public assistance especially financial given to persons in special need or difficulty.
Branch of social legislation which has as its purpose the protection of workers from risks resulting from the impairment or loss of their earning capacity due to predetermined events.
A term loosely applied to any recurring pattern of social behaviour; or, more specifically, to the ordered interrelationships between the different elements or a social system or society.

The concept of system appears throughout the social and natural sciences and has generated a body of literature of its own (general systems theory). A system is any pattern of relationships between elements, and is regarded as having emergent properties on its own over and above the properties of its elements.

1. Human group of people, more or less large and complex, associated for some common interest and characterized by distinctive hierarchical relationships.
2. A formal association of people with similar interests.
The study of the development, organization, functioning and classification of human societies.

The general term used to describe all of the various programs that may be used on a computer system. It can be divided into four main categories: systems software, development software, user interface software, applications software.

1. The top layer of the land surface of the earth that is composed of disintegrated rock particles, humus, water and air.
2. A mixture of sand and organic material, used to support plant growth.
3. To make filthy.
4. To become filthy.
The buildup of hydrogen cations, also called protons, which reduces the pH of the soil.
The air and other gases in spaces in the soil; specifically that which is found within the zone of aeration. Also known as soil atmosphere.\n(Source: MGH)
The study of the living organisms, mainly microorganisms and microinvertebrates which live within the soil, and which are largely responsible for the decomposition processes vital to soil fertility.
The study of the inorganic and organic components of the soil and its life cycles.
An increase in bulk density (mass per unit volume) and a decrease in soil porosity resulting from applied loads, vibration, or pressure.
Description of the character of the surface of the ground at the time of observation, especially in relation to the influence of rain and snow.\n(Source: ECHO2)
Technologies employed in the removal of PCBs, PAH, pesticides and, more generally, of organic compounds by physical, chemical or biological treatments.\n(Source: EUROPAa)

Detachment and movement of topsoil or soil material from the upper part of the profile, by the action of wind or running water, especially as a result of changes brought about by human activity, such as unsuitable or mismanaged agriculture.
The status of a soil with respect to the amount and availability to plants of elements necessary for plant growth.
The combination of natural processes by which soils are formed.
Process of protecting the soil from excessive erosion and making soil more fertile and productive.\n(Source: LANDY)

Distinctive successive layers of soil produced by internal redistribution processes. Conventionally the layers have been divided into A, B and C horizons. The A horizon is the upper layer, containing humus and is leached and/or eluviated of many minerals. The B horizon forms a zone of deposition and is enriched with clay minerals and iron/aluminium oxides from the A layer. The C layer is the parent material for the present soil and may be partially weathered rock, transported glacial or alluvial material or an earlier soil.\n(Source: ALL)
A two-dimensional representation that shows the areal extent or the distribution of soils in relation to other features of the land surface.
The study of the physical properties of soil, especially those properties that affect its ability to bear weight such as water content, density, strength, etc.\n(Source: CED)
Study of the formation, occurrence, properties, composition, and classification of the minerals present in the soil.\n(Source: BJGEOa)
Water stored in soils.
Organism which lives in the soil.
Solid, liquid and gaseous substances that detrimentally alter the natural condition of the soil.
A vertical section of a soil, showing horizons and parent material.
All current positive or negative properties with regard to soil utilization and soil functions.
The accumulation of soluble mineral salts near the surface of soil, usually caused by the capillary flow of water from saline ground water.
The study of the properties, occurrence, and management of soil as a natural resource.
A sinking down of a part of the earth's crust, generally due to underground excavations.
Any activity or process in which ground surface areas are packed or plugged to prevent percolation or the passage of fluids.
A phase or subdivision of a soil series based primarily on texture of the surface soil to a depth at least equal to plow depth (about 15 cm).\n(Source: BJGEO)
Functional utilization of soil for agriculture, industry, or residential building purposes.\n(Source: GREMES)
Water stored in soils.\n(Source: LANDY)

1. A device for converting sunlight into electrical power using a semiconductor sensitive to the photovoltaic effect.
2. A device that absorbs radiant energy and converts it into electrical energy.
Device which converts the energy from light into electricity.

The energy transmitted from the sun in the form of electromagnetic radiation. The most successful examples of energy extraction from the sun are so far solar cells used in satellites and solar collectors used to heat water.\n(Source: MGH /  ALL)
A domestic or industrial heating system that makes direct use of solar energy.
Plant where energy is generated using radiation from the sun.
The electromagnetic radiation and particles emitted by the sun.
A crystalline material, that is, one in which the constituent atoms are arranged in a three-dimensional lattice, periodic in three independent directions.
The physical state of matter in which the constituent molecules, atoms, or ions have no translatory motion although they vibrate about the fixed positions that they occupy in a crystal lattice.
The ability of a substance to form a solution with another substance.\n(Source: MGH)

1. Substance, generally a liquid, capable of dissolving another substance.
2. The conclusion or end to which any course or condition of things leads.
Any passerine bird of the suborder Oscines, having highly developed vocal organs and, in most, a music call.\n(Source: CED)
A noise caused by a shock wave that emanates from an aircraft or other object traveling at or above sonic velocity.
Impure black carbon with oily compounds obtained from the incomplete combustion of resinous materials, oils, wood, or coal.
The taking up, usually, of a liquid or gas into the body of another material (the absorbent).

1. Auditory sensation produced by the oscillations, stress, pressure, particle displacement, and particle velocity in a medium with internal forces; pressure variation that the human ear can detect.\n(Source: KOREN)
2. To produce a sound.
Diffusion into the environment of a sound emitted from a given source.
The introduction in the environment of noise deriving from various sources that can be grouped in: transportation activities, industrial activities and daily normal activities.\n(Source: DIFIDa)
The sound pressure level (in decibels) at a point in a sound field, averaged over the audible frequency range and over a time interval.\n(Source: MGH)
Reducing or eliminating reverberation in a room by placing sound-absorbing materials on the walls and ceiling.\n(Source: MGH)

The travelling of acoustic waves in the atmosphere with a speed independent of their amplitude. The speed only depends on the acoustic medium and is proportional to the square root of the absolute temperature for any given medium.\n(Source: RRDA /  PARCOR)
Passage of a sound wave through a medium or series of media.

A continent in the southern part of the western hemisphere, astride the equator and the Tropic of Capricorn, bordered by the Caribbean Sea to the north and between the Atlantic and Pacific Oceans, connected to North America by the Isthmus of Panama, and divided into twelve countries:  Argentina, Bolivia, Brazil, Chile, Columbia, Ecuador, Guyana, Paraguay, Peru, Suriname, Uruguay and Venezuela.

An ocean south of the equator between the eastern coast of South America and the western coast of Africa that extends southward to the Antarctic continent, including the Drake Passage, South Sandwich Islands and Falkand Islands.

A geographic region of continental Asia, south of China, west of the South Pacific Ocean, north of the Indian Ocean, and east of the Bay of Bengal and the Indian subcontinent, including the Indochina Peninsula, the Malay Peninsula and the Indonesian and Philippine Archipelagos, and countries such as Brunei, Cambodia, Indonesia, Laos, Malaysia, Myanmar, the Philippines, Singapore, Thailand and Vietnam.

1. A geographic region of the African continent astride the Tropic of Capricorn, including Angola, Botswana, Lesotho, Malawi, Mozambique, Namibia, South Africa, Swaziland, Zambia and Zimbabwe, and also the Kalahari Desert, Zambezi River and Orange River.\n(Source: AFR)
2. ISO 639-6 entity

A geographic region of the Asian continent bordered in the north by the countries of Central Asia and in the south by the Arabian Sea and the Bay of Bengal, extending  westward into Iran and eastward into China, including Afghanistan, Pakistan, India, Nepal, Bangladesh, Burma, Bhutan and Sri Lanka.

An ocean south of the equator between Southeast Asia and Australia in the Eastern hemisphere and South America in the Western hemisphere, extending southward to the Antarctic region, including the Tasman and Coral seas and numerous islands, such as Galapagos, Solomon, Easter, Samoa, Fiji and Tonga islands, and also New Zealand and its islands.
Travel in the space beyond the earth's atmosphere performed for scientific research purposes.
Nonfunctional debris of human origin left in a multitude of orbits about the earth as the result of the exploration and use of the environment lying outside the earth's atmosphere.
A respiratory condition that is usually triggered by an acute viral infection of the upper airway.

One relating to particular persons or things; one made for individual cases or for particular places or districts; one operating upon a selected class, rather than upon the public generally. A law is special when it is different from others of the same general kind or designed for a particular purpose, or limited in range or confined to a prescribed field of action or operation.
Waste which must be handled in a particular manner and for which particular rules apply.
A taxonomic category ranking immediately below a genus and including closely related, morphologically similar individuals which actually or potentially inbreed.
Controlled utilization, protection or development of selected classes of plants or animals for their richness, biodiversity and benefits to humanity.\n(Source: TOE / EEN)
The branch of physics concerned with the production, measurement, and interpretation of electromagnetic spectra arising from either emission or absorption of radiant energy by various substances.

1. A scalar measure of the rate of movement of a body expressed either as the distance travelled divided by the time taken (average speed) or the rate of change of position with respect to time at a particular point (instantaneous speed). It is measured in metres per second, miles per hour, etc.
2. To move faster.
3. An addictive psychoactive drug of formula CHN.
4. To cause to move faster.
5. To move fast.
The maximum permitted speed at which a vehicle may travel on certain roads.

1. Any predatory silk-producing arachnid of the order Araneae, having four pairs of legs and a rounded unsegmented body consisting of abdomen and cephalothorax.
2. A type of skimmer in the form of a wire mesh basket attached to a handle, used to remove food from a hot liquid or skim off foam from a broth.

1. The uncontrolled discharge, leakage, dripping or running over of fluids or liquid substances.
2. Fluid or liquid substance that was discharged, leaked, dripped or running over without control.
Place where rubbish and waste minerals dug out of a mine are deposited.
A phylum of the animal kingdom characterized by the presence of canal systems and chambers through which water is drawn in and released; tissues and organs are absent.

1. The complex of individual or group activities pursued for exercise or pleasure, often taking a competitive form.
2. A person who engages in sports.
Buildings, constructions, installations, organized areas and equipment for indoor and outdoor sport activities.\n(Source: RRDA)
An aerosol can for applying paint, deodorant, etc., as a fine spray.
Asbestos emitted into the atmosphere in a spraying operation.
Water obtained from an underground formation from which water flows naturally to the surface, or would flow naturally to the surface if it were not collected underground.

1. Delimited area on a game board, a form or in a table
2. An open area in a town, sometimes including the surrounding buildings.
3. A two dimensional polygon with four equal sides and four right angles.
4. Mathematics: to multiply a value, term, or expression by itself.
5. Having the shape of a square (the polygone).
Settlement on the outskirts of a city, often built without authorization, where poor people live in improvised dwellings made from carton, wood or corrugated metal.

1. A building or structure usually with stalls that is used to house and feed horses, cattle or other animals.
2. In a state that is not likely to change.

1. A great number or large amount of things not placed in a pile.
2. A pile of similar objects, each directly on top of the last.
3. A linear data structure in which the last datum stored is the first retrieved.
4. To place one or more objects or material in the form of a stack or on an existing stack.
5. To put together several things in one pile; to arrange in stacks.

1. Something considered by an authority or by general consent as a basis of comparison.
2. A rule or principle that is used as a basis for judgement.
3. An object regarded as the most common size or form of its kind.
4. An average or normal quality, quantity, or level.
The most commonly or regularly eaten food in a country or community and which forms the mainstay of the total calorie supply, especially in the poorer populations and at times of food shortage.

1. A polysaccharide which is a combination of many monosaccharide molecules, made during photosynthesis and stored as starch grains in many plants.
2. To treat with laundry starch in order to stiffen.

1. A people permanently occupying a fixed territory bound together by common law, habits and custom into one body politic exercising, through the medium of an organized government, independent sovereignty and control over all persons and things within its boundaries, unless or until authority is ceded to a federation or union of other states.
2. A political entity asserting ultimate authority over a geographical area.
3. The condition in which someone or something is in.
4. To declare to be a fact.
5. A political division of a federation retaining a degree of autonomy.
6. In computing, the stable condition of a processor during a particular clock cycle.
7. In computing, the set of all parameters relevant to a computation.
8. In computing, the values of all parameters at some point in a computation.
9. To put before.

Everything made available to the public by means of a written or oral description, by use or in any other way before the date of the patent application, or an application filed in a foreign country the priority of which is validly claimed.
One of the three fundamental conditions of matter: the solid, the liquid, and gaseous states.

1. A place along a route or line at which a bus, train, etc. stops for fuel or to pick up or let off passengers or goods, especially with ancillary buildings and services.
2. A place used for broadcasting radio or television.
The body of techniques used in statistical inference concerning a population.
A branch of mathematics dealing with the collection, analysis, interpretation, and presentation of masses of numerical data.
The extent to which a society promotes human well-being in all dimensions of existence by forming people's capabilities, expanding choices and increasing opportunities.\n(Source: POP)
A pressurized system in which water is vaporized to steam by heat transferred from a source of higher temperature, usually the products of combustion from burning fuels.

Any of various alloys based on iron containing carbon (usually 0.1-0.7 per cent) and often small quantities of other elements such as phosphorus, sulphur, manganese, chromium, and nickel. Steels exhibit a variety of properties, such as strength, machinability, malleability, etc., depending on their composition and the way they have been treated.
Industry that deals with the processing of iron.
A compound composed of a series of four carbon rings joined together to form a structural unit called cyclopentanoperhydrophenanthrene.
The handling or controlling of accumulated materials or stored goods.
The counting over of materials or goods on hand, as in a stockroom or store.

1. A lump or mass of hard consolidated mineral matter that is used in construction, either crushed for use as aggregate or cut into shaped blocks as dimension stone.
2. A small (and usually irregular) piece of mineral, approximately 20-200 mm in diameter.
3. The wooden shell found inside some fruits, particularly drupes, that surrounds the seed.
4. To kill or excecute (a person) by throwing rocks or boulders at and on them.
5. An Imperial unit of weight and mass, equal to 6.35029318 kilograms.
6. Made out of stone.

1. An atmospheric disturbance involving perturbations of the prevailing pressure and wind fields on scales ranging from tornadoes to extratropical cyclones; also the associated weather and the like.\n(Source: MGH)
2. To act or speak violently, as if in state of a great anger.
Damage caused by a storm, for example damaged houses, streets and power lines, uprooted trees, destroyed crops.

1. A chamber within which a fuel-air mixture is burned to provide heat, the heat itself being radiated outward from the chamber; used for space heating, process-fluid heating, and steel blast furnaces.
2. A kitchen appliance used for cooking food.
The arrangement of a body of water, as a lake, into two or more horizontal layers of different characteristics, especially densities.\n(Source: MGH)
The layer of the atmosphere which is sandwiched between the troposphere and mesosphere.
Damage of the ozone shield by chemicals released on Earth.
The quantitative determination of the rate and amount of flow or discharge from a natural body of running water, such as a small river or brook.
The process of removing dirt, litter or other unsightly materials from city or town streets.
The material's ability to resist an applied force.

1. A stimulus or succession of stimuli of such magnitude as to tend to disrupt the homeostasis of the organism.
2. Emphasis on a word or phrase by pronouncing it by increasing the volume or changing the tone.
3. To stress, single out as important.
4. Difficulty that causes worry or emotional tension.
5. To test the limits of.
6. To put stress on; to utter with an accent.
Superficial mining, in which the valuable rock is exposed by removal of overburden.
A soft silvery-white element of the alkaline earth group of metals, occurring chiefly as celestite and as strontianite.
The association between a chemical structure and carcinogenicity.
Sound that travels over at least part of its path by means of the vibration of a solid structure.
That aspect of geological oceanography which deals with the relief features of the ocean floor and with the forces that modify them.

1. A boat that can go underwater.
2. Located under the surface of the sea.

1. A sinking down of a part of the earth's crust, generally due to underground excavations.
2. The sudden sinking or gradual downward settling of the Earth's surface with little or no horizontal motion. The movement is not restricted in rate, magnitude, or area involved. Subsidence may be caused by natural geologic processes, such as solution, thawing, compaction, slow crustal warping, or withdrawal of fluid lava from beneath a solid crust; or by man's activity, such as subsurface mining or the pumping of oil or ground water.

Any monetary grant made by the government to a private industrial undertaking or charitable organization, but especially one given to consumers or producers in order to lower the market price of some service or product and make it readily affordable to the public.
Soil underlying surface soil, devoid of plant roots.
A residential district situated on the outskirts of a city or town.
A poisonous gas with the formula SO2 that is released by volcanoes and the burning of coal and petroleum.
A highly corrosive acid made from sulfur dioxide; widely used in the chemical industry.
A substance that, when used in small quantities, modifies the surface properties of liquids or solids.
The water flow that occurs when the soil is infiltrated to full capacity and excess water from rain, meltwater, or other sources flows over the land.

The force acting on the surface of a liquid, tending to minimize the area of the surface; quantitatively, the force that appears to act across a line of unit length on the surface. Also known as interfacial force; interfacial tension; surface intensity.\n(Source: MGH)

Any method of treating a material (metal, polymer, or wood) so as to alter the surface, rendering it receptive to inks, paints, lacquers, adhesives, and various other treatments, or resistant to weather or chemical attack.
All waters on the surface of the Earth found in streams, rivers, ponds, lakes, marshes or wetlands, and as ice and snow.
Any tissue, blood or mucus removed during surgery or autopsy, soiled surgical dressings, or other materials requiring special disposal procedures.

1. The extent to which assets exceed liabilities, especially the profits remaining after operating expenses, taxes, interest and insurance costs are subtracted.\n(Source: IVW)
2. More than is needed, desired, or required.

1. A critical examination of facts or conditions to provide information on a situation. Usually conducted by interviews and/or on-site visitations.
2. A detailed critical inspection.
3. To plot a map of (land).
Development that provides economic, social and environmental benefits in the long term having regard to the needs of living and future generations.
An periodically inundated area of low ground having shrubs and trees, with or without the formation of peat.
A sweetening agent, especially one that does not contain sugar.
A close and mutually beneficial association of organisms of different species.
Study of the ecology of organisms, populations, communities or systems.
An ecological association in which the physiological processes of behaviour of an individual are enhanced by the nearby presence of another organism.
An artificially produced solid or liquid cleansing substance that acts like soap but is stronger, and is capable of dissolving oily materials and dispersing them in water.\n(Source: DOE / RIC)
Material made artificially by chemical reaction.\n(Source: CEDa)
A means of organizing elements into an integrated analytic and/or decisionmaking procedure to achieve the best possible results.\n(Source: LANDY)
The science concerned with the general study of structures and behaviours of systems which may be applicable in different branches of learning.
Storage space for containers of liquids or gases.
One of a group of complex organic chemicals commonly found in leaves, unripe fruits, and the bark of trees.

1. A viscous material composed of complex, high-molecular-weight, compounds derived from the distillation of petroleum or the destructive distillation of wood or coal.
2. A long-necked, waisted lute.
The group of people that something, for example an advertising campaign, is primarily aimed at.
A classified list or scale of charges made in any private or public business.\n(Source: OED)
A mixture of bitumen, sand, clay and water.
An amount of money demanded by a government for its support or for specific facilities or services, most frequently levied upon income, property or sales.
The act or result of a government requiring money for its support or for specific facilities or services.\n(Source: RHW)

A binding rule or body of rules prescribed by a government stipulating the sum of money and manner of collection it demands for governmental support, facilities and services, usually levied upon income, property, sales or other financial resources.

1. The branch of biology concerned with the classification of organisms into groups based on similarities of structures, origin, etc.
2. A hierarchical organization of a subject area, from one perspective in one language.
The act of imparting knowledge or skill.
A procedure, technique or system with definite plans for instruction or imparting knowledge.
Systematic knowledge of industrial processes and their application.

The systematic analysis of the anticipated impact of a particular technology in regard to its safety and efficacy as well as its social, political, economic, and ethical consequences.\n(Source: KOREN)
The transfer of development and design work from a parent company to a subsidiary or from one country to another as a form of aid to help promote development and sustainable growth.

A branch of geology dealing with the broad architecture of the outer part of the Earth, that is, the regional assembling of structural or deformation features, a study of their mutual relations, origin and historical evolution.
The conveyance of images, speech and other sounds, usually over great distances, through technological means, particularly by television, telegraph, telephone or radio.

The convergence of computing and communications technologies, thus the use of telephone or radio to link computers and the use of computers to send messages via telephone or radio links.\n(Source: NECTAR)
The use of radio waves, telephone lines, etc., to transmit the readings of measuring instruments to a device on which the readings can be indicated or recorded.

1. The process, equipment or programming involved in converting a succession of audiovisual images into corresponding electrical signals that are transmitted by means of electromagnetic waves to distant receivers or screens, at which the signals can be used to reproduce the original image.
2. A device for receiving television signals and displaying them in visual form.

Mixed forest of conifers and broad-leaf deciduous trees, or mixed conifer and broad-leaf evergreen trees, or entirely broad-leaf deciduous, or entirely broad-leaf evergreen trees, found in temperate regions across the world; characterized by high rainfall, warm summers, cold winters occasionally subzero, seasonality; typically with dense canopies, understorey saplings and tall shrubs, large animals, carnivores dominant, very rich in bird species.

Forest dominated by broad-leaved hardwoods, which occurs over large tracts in the mid-latitudes of Europe, N. America, and eastern Asia, but which is restricted in the southern hemisphere to Chilean Patagonia.
A measure of cold or hot. A property that determines the direction of heat flow when an object is brought into thermal contact with other objects.
Simple facility for asylum or provisional lodgings to individuals or groups in emergencies.\n(Source: ECHO2)
The process whereby abnormalities of the offspring are generated, usually as the result of damage to the embryonal structure during the first trimester of pregnancy, producing deformity of the fetus.
The ability or tendency to produce anomalies of formation.
Substance causing formation of a congenital anomaly or monstrosity in the embryo.

1. The body of specialized words relating to a particular subject.
2. The study of the designating of concepts particular to one or more domains of human activity, through research and analysis of terms in context, for the purpose of documenting and promoting correct usage.

A soft-bodied insect of the order Isoptera; individuals feed on cellulose and live in colonies with a caste system comprising three types of functional individuals: sterile workers and soldiers, and the reproductives.
Subdivisions of the continental surfaces distinguished from one another on the basis of the form, roughness, and surface composition of the land.\n(Source: PARCOR)
A course of action adopted and pursued by government, business or some other organization, which determines the present and future use of each parcel of land in an area.\n(Source: DOE)

1. An area that an animal or group of animals defends, mainly against members of the same species.
2. Land that is controlled by a specific country or ruler.
3. Land or an area of a particular type.
4. A tract of land of undefined size.
5. A geographic area owned or controlled by a single person or organization.
6. The region of responsibility assigned to a representative, agent, or the like.
7. A non-sovereign geographic area which has come under the authority of an external government but has not yet been admitted to the full rights of a province or federal state of the controlling country.

1. The part of a country or region's economy that produces services or assets lacking a tangible and storable form.
2. The business sector that consists of companies whose line of work involves doing something for customers, but that do not produce goods.

1. To carry out an examination on (a substance, material, or system) by applying some chemical or physical procedure designed to indicate the presence of a substance or the possession of a property.
2. A session in which a product or piece of equipment is placed under everyday and/or extreme conditions and is examined for its durability, etc.
3. A series of questions (set by the teacher or professor), aiming to gauge how much students have learnt over a given academic module, term or year.
4. To test or examine for the presence of disease or infection.
5. to check a property or quality of

An animal on which experiments are conducted in order to provide evidence for or against a scientific hypothesis, or to prove the efficacy of drugs or the reaction to certain products.\n(Source: CEDa)
Any animal organism used for scientific research.
Industry for the production of fabrics.\n(Source: MGHa)
A material made of natural or man-made fibers and used for the manufacture of items such as clothing and furniture fittings.
Bluish-white metal with tinlike malleability, but a little softer; used in alloys.

A coherent group of general propositions about the supply and demand of money, interest rates, the flow of money's influence on the overall economy or the policies that should be adopted by institutions controlling the money supply.

A political conception of government in a capitalist economy where the state is responsible for insuring that all members of society attain a minimum standard of living through redistribution of resources, progressive taxation and universal social programs, including health care and education.
The treatment of physical, mental or social disorders or disease.
The process of preventing the passage of heat to or from a body by surrounding it with a nonconducting material.

The excessive raising or lowering of water temperature above or below normal seasonal ranges in streams, lakes, or estuaries or oceans as the result of discharge of hot or cold effluents into such water.\n(Source: LANDY /  WPR)
A power-generating plant which uses heat to produce energy. Such plants may burn fossil fuels or use nuclear energy to produce the necessary thermal energy.
Water, generally of a spring or geyser, whose temperature is appreciably above the local mean annual air temperature.

The branch of physics which seeks to derive, from a few basic postulates, relationships between properties of matter, especially those connected with temperature, and a description of the conversion of energy from one form to another.
A thermic waste processing technology.

A compilation of terms showing synonyms, related terms and other relationships and dependencies, often used in a book format or as a standardized, controlled vocabulary for an information storage and retrieval system.
Mechanical power, which may be converted to electrical power, generated by the rise and fall of ocean tides.
Any water whose level changes periodically due to tidal action.
The periodic rise and fall of the water resulting from gravitational interaction between the sun, moon and earth.

1. The grammatical construct of the time in which a sentence acts.
2. The dimension of the physical universe which, at a given place, orders the sequence of events.
3. To measure the amount of time an object takes to complete a course (e.g., "to clock a race car").
4. The period of time a prisoner is imprisoned.
5. A designated instant in time.
6. An instance or occurrence of an event.

1. A part of an organism consisting of a large number of cells having a similar structure and function.
2. A sheet of paper that absorbs water, used for example to weep wet surfaces.

A strong malleable white metallic element with symbol Ti and atomic number 22, which is very corrosion-resistant and occurs in rutile and ilmenite. It is used in the manufacture of strong lightweight alloys, especially aircraft parts.
A white, water-insoluble powder that melts at 1560C, and which is produced commercially from the titanium dioxide minerals ilmenite and rutile; used in paints and cosmetics.
Any anuran amphibian of the family Bufonidae, such as Bufo bufo of Europe. They are similar to frogs but are more terrestrial, having a drier warty skin.

1. A genus of short-leafed plants (Nicotiana spp., L.) of the nightshade family indigenous to North and South America.
2. Leaves of certain varieties of the tobacco plant, cultivated and harvested to make cigarettes, cigars, snuff, for smoking in pipes or for chewing.

The grey, brown, or blackish mixture of gases and suspended carbon particles resulting from the combustion of tobacco. Tobacco smoke is inhaled and distributes toxins widely throughout the body and causes an enormous variety of illness among users and among non-smokers exposed to tobacco smoke.
A rapidly rotating column of air developed around a very intense low-pressure centre.
Any herbivorous terrestrial chelonian reptile of the family Testudinidae, of most warm regions, having a heavy dome-shaped shell and clawed limbs.
The sum of parameters that must be taken into account when assessing water quality (organoleptic factors, physico-chemical factors, toxic substances, microbiological parameters.

The temporary movement of people to destinations outside their normal places or work and residence, the activities undertaken during their stay in those destinations and the facilities created to cater for their needs.
Any section of a region which attracts travelers, often because of its scenery, objects of interest or recreational activities.
A result produced by the ingestion or contact of poisonous materials.
The degree of danger posed by a substance to animal or plant life.
Metal (usually heavy metals) which interferes with the respiration, metabolism or growth of organisms.
Test for the determination of the inherent toxicity of a chemical.
A science that deals with poisons, their actions, their detection, and the treatment of the conditions they produce.\n(Source: LANDY)
Refuse posing a significant hazard to the environment or to human health when improperly handled.
A substance that may present a risk or injury to health or the environment.
Any of various chemical elements that occur in very small amounts in organisms and are essential for many physiological and biochemical processes.
A large group of plants characterized by the presence of specialized conducting tissues (xylem and phloem) in the roots, stems, and leaves.\n(Source: MGH)
An artificial restraint on the free exchange of goods and services between nations.

A course of action adopted and pursued by government, business or some other organization, which promotes or determines the direction for the act or process of buying, selling or exchanging goods and services within a country or between countries.
Commercial discrimination that apply to the exports of certain countries but not to similar goods from other countries.
A system of treating and healing maladies based on cultural beliefs and practices handed down from generation to generation.\n(Source: FIT)

1. The movement of vehicles, ships, aircraft, persons, etc., in an area or over a route.
2. The vehicles, persons, etc., moving in an area or over a route.
3. The buying and selling, especially of illicit trade.
4. To buy and sell goods illegally.
5. To exchange goods.
An unexpected incident with potential for harm occurring through the movement or collision of vessels, vehicles or persons along a land, water, air or space route.\n(Source: OED)
The organization of a more efficient movement of traffic within a given road network by rearranging the flows, controlling the intersections and regulating the times and places for parking.
The determination of the required capacity and layout of highway and street facilities that can safely and economically serve vehicular movement between given points.\n(Source: MGH)
The fundamental facilities and systems used for the movement of vehicles, often provided through public funding.
A number of vehicles so obstructed that they can scarcely move.
The periodic or continuous surveillance or analysis of the movement of persons, objects, vehicles or other conveyances along an area of passage.
Noise emitted by vehicles (heavy vehicles, cars and motorcycles, tyre/road interaction).
The movement of boats and other vessels over any water route or area.

1. A self-propelled, connected group of vehicles moving on rails.
2. To point or cause to go (blows, weapons, or objects such as photographic equipment) towards
3. To develop behaviour by instruction and practice.
4. A group of animals, vehicles, or people that follow one another in a line.
5. To do physical exercise to improve one's fitness.
6. To exercise in order to prepare for an event or competition.
7. To teach by training.
8. To undergo training or instruction for a particular role, function, or profession.
9. To educate for a future role or function.
10. To act as a trainer or coach (to), as in sports.

1. The process of bringing a person or a group of persons to an agreed standard of proficiency and skilled behavior, by practice and instruction.
2. The period in which someone who starts a profession is trained; the position of apprentice.
The path described by an object moving in air or space under the influence of such forces as thrust, wind resistance, and gravity, especially the curved path of a projectile.

One of a group of metallic elements in which the members have the filling of the outermost shell to 8 electrons interrupted to bring the penultimate shell from 8 to 18 or 32 electrons; includes elements 21 through 29 (scandium through copper), 39 through 47 (yttrium through silver), 57 through 79 (lanthanum through gold), and 89 through 112 (actinium through ununbium) on.

1. The loss of water vapour from a plant, mainly through the stomata and to a small extent through the cuticle and lenticels.
2. The production and evaporation of a watery fluid called sweat that is excreted by the sweat glands in the skin of mammals.
Any commercial venture involved in the processes of conveying things or people from one place to another.

Comprehensive statements of the objectives and policies which a local transport authority intends to pursue; it includes and estimate of transport expenditure, a statement of transport objectives, etc.\n(Source: GOOD)

1. The act or means of moving tangible objects (persons or goods) from place to place. Often involves the use of some type of vehicle.
2. The act of expelling a person from his native land.
The act of catching an animal in a mechanical device or enclosed place or pit.

1. To move from one place to another generally by using a transportation mean; to undertake a trip.
2. The transport of people on a trip or journey.
Expenditure of money or the amount of money incurred for journeying or going from one place to another by some mode of transportation.\n(Source: ISEP /  RHW)
An international agreement in writing between two states or a number of states. They are binding in international law; some create law only for those states that are parties to them.

1. Any large woody perennial plant with a distinct trunk giving rise to branches or leaves at some distance from the ground.
2. A widely-used data structure that emulates a tree structure with a set of linked nodes.
An area where trees, shrubs, or plants are grown for transplanting, for use as stocks for budding and grafting.\n(Source: ECHO2)
The general drift, tendency, or bent of a set of statistical data as related to time or another related set of statistical data.\n(Source: MGH)
Azines that contain three nitrogen atoms in their molecules.
Three fundamental principles of environmental policy: precautionary principle, polluter pays-principle and cooperation principle.
The hydrogen isotope having mass number 3; it is one form of heavy hydrogen, the other being deuterium.
Any of the feeding levels through which the passage of energy through an ecosystem proceeds.

The interacting system of a biological community and its non-living environmental surroundings in forests found in tropical regions near the equator, which are characterized by warm to hot weather and abundant rainfall.

A vegetation class consisting of tall, close-growing trees, their columnar trunks more or less unbranched in the lower two-thirds, and forming a spreading and frequently flat crown; occurs in areas of high temperature and high rainfall.
A type of forest that occurs roughly within the latitudes 28 degrees north or south of the equator and is characterized by high average temperatures and a significant amount of rainfall.

The region of the earth's surface lying between two parallels of latitude on the earth, one 2327' north of the equator and the other 2327' south of the equator, representing the points farthest north and south at which the sun can shine directly overhead and constituting the boundaries of the Torrid Zone.\n(Source: AMHER)
The lowest of the concentric layers of the atmosphere, occurring between the Earth's surface and the tropopause.

Tropospheric ozone is a secondary pollutant formed from emissions of nitrogen oxides, non-methane volatile organic compounds and carbon monoxide. Ozone scars lung tissue, makes eyes sting and throats itch. It has been implicated as a contributor to forest dieback, damage to agricultural crops, etc.\n(Source: WPR)

An area supporting some vegetation (lichens, mosses, sedges and low shrubs) between the northern upper limit of trees and the lower limit of perennial snow on mountains, and on the fringes of the Antarctic continent and its neighbouring islands.

1. A underground passageway, especially one for trains or cars that passes under a mountain, river or a congested urban area.
2. An Internet Protocol (IP) network communications channel between two networks. It is used to transport another network protocol by encapsulation and often encryption of its packets.
Cloudy or hazy appearance in a naturally clear liquid caused by a suspension of colloidal liquid droplets or fine solids.
A fluid acceleration machine for generating rotary mechanical power from the energy in a stream of fluid.\n(Source: MGH)
A sea-going vessel that includes space between two continuous floor-like surfaces or platforms, which is also designed for bulk shipments of liquids or gases.
Oil tank vessels provided with a double-hull to meet the regulatory safety requirements in oil transportation.
An internal combustion engine whose cycle is completed in two strokes of the piston.

A class or category of interests or remedies recognized in law or equity that create in the holder a right to the interest or its proceeds, typically taking the form of money, property or privilege.\n(Source: BLD)
A severe tropical cyclone in the western Pacific.
A rubber ring placed over the rim of a wheel of a road vehicle to provide traction and reduce road shocks.
Separation of colloidal or very fine solid materials by filtration through microporous or semipermeable mediums.
Sound waves having a frequency above about 20,000 hertz.
The part of the electromagnetic spectrum with wavelengths shorter than light but longer than x-rays; in the range of 4-400 nm.\n(Source: CED)
A train for transportation of people, mostly beneath the surface of the ground, in order to lessen the traffic.
The condition of being without remunerative employment.

1. Animal with hooved feet.
2. Having a hoof.

1. A voluntary association of around 180 state signatory to the UN charter (1945), whose primary aim is to maintain international peace and security, solve economic, social, and political problems through international co-operation, and promote respect for human rights.
2. Relating to the United Nations.
Petrol, which has no lead additives in it and therefore creates less lead pollution in the atmosphere.
Area where significant reductions in ozone forming pollutants have been achieved.
Water that has not been treated.
The way in which a child is cared for and taught while it is growing up.
The body of a bicameral legislature comprising either representatives of member states in a federation or a select number of individuals from certain privileged estates or social classes.
A metallic element highly toxic and radioactive; used as nuclear fuel.\nSymbol: U, atomic number: 92.

1. Areas within the legal boundaries of cities and towns; suburban areas developed for residential, industrial or recreational purposes.
2. The area within a city or town, as indicated by appropriate traffic signs (or, in the United Kingdom, by the presence of street lights), where different traffic rules are in effect, such as a reduction of the speed limit.
Condition where part of a city or town becomes old or dirty or ruined, because businesses and wealthy families have moved away from it.
A plan, outline or preliminary sketch of, or for, a city or town.

Any physical extension of, or changes to, the uses of land in metropolitan areas, often involving subdivision into zones; construction or modification of buildings, roads, utilities and other facilities; removal of trees and other obstructions; and population growth and related economic, social and political changes.
The complex of private and public gardens in an urban area.\n(Source: DIFID)
The traits, patterns and structure of a city's specific geographic area, including its biological composition, its physical environment and its social patterns.

The administration, organization and planning performed for cities or towns, particularly the process of converting farmland or undeveloped land into offices, businesses, housing and other forms of development.\n(Source: DOE)

1. The activity of designing, organizing or preparing for the future lay-out and condition of a city or town.
2. The study and theory of building and other physical needs in cities or predominantly urban cultures.
The total number of persons inhabiting a city, metropolitan region or any area where the sum of residents exceeds a designated amount.

A continuing process of remodelling urban areas by means of rehabilitation and conservation as well as redevelopment. Urban renewal programmes are generally undertaken by public authorities and concern those parts of the city which have fallen below current standards of public acceptability.
A state of bodily or mental tension developed through city living, or the physical, chemical, or emotional factors that give rise to that tension.
The study and theory of building and other physical needs in cities or predominantly urban cultures.
Movements of vehicles and people within a city.\n(Source: RRDA)
The distribution of water, including collection, treatment and storage, for use in a town, city or municipal area, and used generally for domestic and industrial needs.

Any low-lying land bordered by higher ground; especially an elongate, relatively large, gently sloping depression of the Earth's surface, commonly situated between two mountains or between ranges of hills or mountains, and often containing a stream with an outlet.
A silvery-white, ductile metal resistant to corrosion; used in alloy steels and as an x-ray target.
The deliberate or wanton destruction of personal or public property caused by a vandal.
A transparent surface coating which is applied as a liquid and then changes to a hard solid.
Number of plants growing on a certain area of land.
Cultivation of herbaceous plants that are used as food.
