A course of action or procedure regarding compensation or recompensation for work done or services rendered.\n(Source: RHW)

An organization established in Europe in 1979 to coordinate financial policy and exchange rates for the continent by running the Exchange Rate Mechanism (ERM) and assisting movement toward a common European currency and a central European bank.\n(Source: ODE)
A financial market that trades Treasury bills, commercial paper and other short-term financial instruments.
Course of action or procedure by government, business, or an individual concerning trade activities.\n(Source: ISEP /  RHW)
The total amount of all government securities outstanding.

A sum of money demanded from businesses by a government, usually based on a percentage of total sales of select goods and services, and generally passed on to consumers with each individual purchase.\n(Source: ODE)

A government imposed levy on the wealth or assets gained by an individual, firm, or corporation for the purpose of raising revenue to pay for services or improvements for the general public benefit.\n(Source: EFP / RHW)
A tax on the annual profits arising from property, business pursuits, professions, trades or offices.

The price actually given in current market dealings; the actual price at which given stock or commodity is currently sold in the usual and ordinary course of trade and competition between sellers and buyers.\n(Source: WESTS)
The outlay or expenditure involved in moving goods from one place to another.\n(Source: ODE)
The guiding procedure, philosophy, or course of action for decisions regarding the monetary rate or value for goods and services.
The type of organization of a company. Three kinds of structure are usually recognized: centralized, formal or hierarchical.
The part of the national law of a country that establishes rules for dealing with cases involving a foreign element.
The general rules and principles pertaining to the conduct of nations and of international organizations and with the relations among them.\n(Source: BLD)

The recognized rules guiding the commercial relations of at least two sovereign states or private parties involved in cross-border transactions, including regulations for trade, finance and intellectual property.\n(Source: IEL)
Branch of specialty of law concerned with such subjects as adoption, annulment, divorce, paternity, custody and child support.
A body of rules or orders prescribed by government or management for the safe and orderly movement of vehicles on land, sea or in the air.\n(Source: BLD / RHW)
Binding rules and regulations pertaining to the construction, use and operation of jails, penitentiaries and other places of legal confinement and punishment.

That part of the law dealing with matters such as those arising from monopolies and mergers, restrictive trading agreements, resale price maintenance and agreements involving distortion of competition affected by EU rules.

A judicial or administrative interpretation of a provision of a statute, order, regulation, or ordinance. May also refer to judicial determination of admissibility of evidence, allowance of motion, etc.
All proceedings authorised or sanctioned by law, and brought or instituted in a court of legal tribunal, for the acquiring of a right or the enforcement of a remedy.\n(Source: WESTS)

The organization and network of courts and other institutions, procedures and customs, officers and other personnel concerned with interpretation and enforcement of a country's law or with advice and assistance in matters pertaining to those laws.
Any prescribed step or manner of proceeding that a law making body takes in proposing laws, resolutions or special acts before they can be enacted or passed.\n(Source: RHW)
Systematic approach or method of performance for the accomplishment of administrative goals or tasks.

A course of action adopted and pursued by government, business or some other organization, which plans or organizes for the maintenance, development and erection of houses, offices, bridges or other building structures.\n(Source: OED)

A course of action adopted and pursued by government or some other organization, which seeks to support research and the exploration of planets, asteroids and other elements in the region beyond earth's atmosphere or beyond the solar system.\n(Source: OED)
A district or an administrative division of a city or territory that is designed according to some material, distributive or productive criteria.

The support or relief given to save human lives or to alleviate suffering, including public health efforts and the provision of financial resources and food, often when governmental authorities are unable or unwilling to provide for such assistance.
A controversy, disagreement, quarrel or warfare between or among two or more nations or countries, often requiring involvement or monitoring by other members of the global community.

The activities to prevent, contain, moderate and/or terminate the hostilities between or within States, through the medium of an impartial third party intervention, organised and directed internationally.

A position along a scale of increasingly advanced training marking the degree or grade of instruction either obtained by an individual, offered by a some entity or necessary for a particular job or task.\n(Source: RHW)

Informal learning or formal instruction with broad application to human existence beyond the domain of any particular subject or discipline, often equated with liberal arts in the university setting and contrasted to courses required for a specific major or program.
The material studied in or for an educational institution, comprising homework and work done in the classroom.\n(Source: RHW)
A coordinated assemblage of people, devices or other resources providing written, printed or digitized items that furnish or substantiate information or evidence.\n(Source: RHW)
A coordinated assemblage of people, devices or other resources designed to exchange information and data by means of mutually understood symbols.

An assembly of computer hardware, firmware and software configured for the purpose of performing various operations on digital information elements with a minimum of human intervention.\n(Source: JON)
A profession specific to the health care industry.
A person that suffers from the destructive action undertaken as a result of an armed conflict between two or more parties, particularly death, injury, hardship, loss of property or dislocation.
A population shift occurring within national or territorial boundaries, often characterized by persons seeking labor opportunities in more advantageous areas.\n(Source: ISEP)
The standing of an individual with regard to a legally recognized conjugal relationship, either in the present or past.
A collection of people who interact and share a sense of unity on account of a common ethnic, ancestral, generational or regional identity.\n(Source: RHW)
The organization and proportions of the various job types and skill levels in an enterprise or economy.\n(Source: LAB)

1. Tents, cabins, etc., used as temporary lodgings by a group of travellers, holiday-makers, Scouts, Gypsies, etc.
2. To live in a tent or similar temporary accomodation.
Compensation for the use of a person's property, based on an agreed percentage of the income arising from its use.
Regular allocation or deduction of money.
A place where crystalline salt deposits are formed or found, such as a salt flat or pan, a salada, or a salt lick.
A trail in the country along which one can walk, usually for pleasure or exercise.

An eco-balance refers to the consumption of energy and resources and the pollution caused by the production cycle of a given product. The product is followed throughout its entire life cycle, from the extraction of the raw materials, manufacturing and use, right through to recycling and final handling of waste.\n(Source: DUNI)
A colorless gas that, at room temperature, reacts with\noxygen to form nitrogen dioxide; may be used to form other compounds.
An enclosed heated compartment usually lined with a refractory material used for drying substances, firing ceramics, heat-treating, etc.
Medium-sized to large ungulates, including domestic cattle, Bison, the Water Buffalo, the Yak, and the four-horned and spiral-horned antelopes.
Approbation; a sanctioning of an item.
The act or process of washing, laundering or removing dirt and other unwanted substances from the surface of an object, thing or place.\n(Source: RHW)
In the United States, United Kingdom and Ireland: Part of a city at or near the centre, especially a slum area where poor people live in bad housing.
A valve or gate fitted to a sluice to control the rate of flow of water.

1. The temperate forests comprised of trees that seasonally shed their leaves, located in the east of the USA, in Western Europe from the Alps to Scandinavia, and in the eastern Asia. The trees of deciduous forests usually produce nuts and winged seeds.\n(Source: WRIGHT)
2. Wood taken from a deciduous tree.
A forest composed of broadleaf trees and coniferous trees.
Punishment for the commission of a specific crime, such as fines, restitution, probation and imprisonment.
Any tree bearing cones.
The creation of photographs from an airplane.
A permanently waterlogged area in which there is often associated tree growth, e.g. mangroves in hot climates.
The entire course of action necessary to bring a law, resolution or special act to an authoritative, legally binding status.\n(Source: RHW)

Container whose return from the consumer or final user is assured by specific means (separate collection, deposits, etc.), independently on its final destination, in order to be reused, recovered or subjected to specific waste management operations.\n(Source: PORTa)
Product that has undergone a partial processing and is used as raw material in a successive productive step.
Agents that induce a permanent change in the genetic material.
A tax charged on goods produced within the country.
An order of insects possessing only a single pair of wings on the mesothorax.
Forest, mainly containing conifers.
An electric passenger railway operated in underground tunnels.
An organism that has undergone external processes by which its basic set of genes has been altered.

Any soluble substance composed of two or more unlike atoms held together by chemical bonds that reduces interfacial tension between liquids or a liquid and a solid, often used as detergents, wetting agents and emulsifiers.
(logarithmical) Measure of the acidity or alkalinity of an aqueous solution.
The act, process or industry of extracting coal, ores, etc. from the earth.\n(Source: CED)
An inland sea between southeastern Europe and Anatolia.
A landlocked sea between Asia and European Russia. It is the worlds largest inland body of water.

The largest inland sea between Europe, Africa and Asia, linked to the Atlantic Ocean at its western end by the Strait of Gibraltar, including the Tyrrhenian, Adriatic, Aegean and Ionian seas, and major islands such as Sicily, Sardina, Corsica, Crete, Malta and Cyprus.

Local knowledge that is unique to a given culture or society, which is the basis for local-level decision making in agriculture, health care, education and other matters of concern in rural communities.\n(Source: WIK)
A group of persons engaged in the same profession, business, trade or craft that is organized or formally structured to attain common ends.\n(Source: RHW)

1. The general category, often stated in a word or phrase, to which the ideas of a passage as a whole belong.
2. The grammatical subject.
3. The subject of discourse; the point at issue.
4. Area of knowledge taught in an educational institution.
Any change in a body or substance that does not involve an alteration in its chemical composition.
The basic, underlying framework and features of a communications system supporting the exchange of knowledge, including hardware, software and transmission media.\n(Source: WIC / RHW)
A system of interrelated computer and telecommunications devices linking two or more computers separated by a great distance for the exchange of electronic data.\n(Source: WIC)

A graphical, interactive, hypertext information system that is cross-platform and can be run locally or over the global Internet. The Web consists of Web servers offering pages of information to Web browsers who view and interact with the pages. Pages can contain formatted text, background colors, graphics, as well as audio and video clips.
The preset document that is displayed after starting a World Wide Web browser, or the main World Wide Web document in a series of related documents.\n(Source: UNM / WIC)

The organization of information units typically containing visible links that users can select or click with a mouse pointer or some other computer device to automatically retrieve or display other documents.\n(Source: WIC / TWI)
A discussion group on a specific topic maintained on a computer network, frequently on the Internet.
Information or message that is transmitted or exchanged from one computer terminal to another, through telecommunication.
Any technical means used to combine text, sound, still or animated images and video in computers and electronic products, often allowing audience interactivity.\n(Source: ENC / WIS)

1. A display of an object or collection of objects for general dissemination of information, aesthetic value or entertainment.
2. To make known something heretofore kept secret.
A printed periodical bulletin circulated to members of a group.
The methods and activities employed by an individual, organization, corporation, or government to promote a favourable relationship with the public.

A coordinated assemblage of people, devices or other resources organized for the exchange of data pertaining to the history, physical description, comparison, and classification of books and other works.\n(Source: RHW)
Data pertaining to the history, physical description, comparison, and classification of books and other works.\n(Source: RHW)

A coordinated assemblage of people, devices or other resources organized to provide directions leading people to sources known to provide knowledge or assistance on a specified topic or request.\n(Source: RHW)
A coordinated assemblage of people, devices or other resources enabling the exchange of numerical data that has been collected, classified or interpreted for analysis.\n(Source: RHW)

The duties of an establishment, or a public institution, charged with the care and organizing of a collection of printed and other materials, and the duty of interpreting such materials to meet the informational, cultural, educational, recreational or research needs of its clients.\n(Source: OED /  LFS)

The service provided by one library in which a second library's clients are temporarily allowed to use books and other printed materials belonging to the first library; and consequently the system providing rules and infrastructure for this service to a group of libraries.\n(Source: RHW)
A central institution or agency for the collection, maintenance, and distribution of materials or data compiled to convey knowledge on some subject.\n(Source: RHW)
A reciprocal transference of data between two or more parties for the purpose of enhancing knowledge of the participants.
A collection of digital information items organized as a set of formally described tables from which the information can be accessed or reassembled in different ways without reorganizing the tables.
A remote sensing term referring to a scanning radiometer that simultaneously acquires images in various wavebands at the same time.
The smallest unit of information in an image or raster map.
Closely grouped bands of lines characteristic of molecular gases of chemical compounds (spectroscopy).
A coordinated assemblage of computer devices designed to capture and manipulate pictures stored as data in discrete, quantized units or digits.\n(Source: GIS)

Techniques employed in the calibration of image data, the correction or reduction of errors occurring during capture or transmission of the data and in various types of image enhancement-operations which increase the ability of the analyst to recognize features of interest.\n(Source: YOUNG)

A remote sensing term referring to an automated process through which unidentified patterns can be classified into a limited number of discrete classes through comparison with other class-defining patterns or characteristics.
A composite photograph consisting of separate aerial photographs of overlapping surface areas, producing an overall image of a surface area too large to be depicted in a single aerial photograph.
A remote sensing term related to image enhancement that refers to the removal of a spatial component of electromagnetic radiation.\n(Source: WHITa)
In remote sensing, the filtering of data and other processes to manipulate pixels to produce an image that accentuates features of interest or visual interpretation.
A remote sensing term referring to the adjustment of an image for geometric errors.\n(Source: DWEB)
The process of linking map coordinates to control points with known earth-surface coordinates.

Processing techniques which apply quantitative methods to the values in a digital yield or remotely sensed scene to group pixels with similar digital number values into feature classes or categories.\n(Source: DYNAMO)

The removal of atmospheric effects from astronomical data or satellite imagery. These effects are caused by the scattering and absorption of sunlight by particles in the earth's athmosphere; the removal of these effects improves not only the quality of the observed earth surface imaging but also the accuracy of classification of the ground objects.\n(Source: YOUNG)
The digital form of data collected by remote sensing.

1. One of the two major types of internal data organization used in GIS. Vector systems are based primarily on coordinate geometry.
2. A mathematical object defined by both magnitude and direction; in contrast to a scalar, an object with magnitude only.
3. An element in a vector space, often represented as a coordinate vector.
4. A virus modified to deliver genetic material into a cell.
5. An organism that transmits diseases or infections.

1. A position on a reference system determined by a survey.
2. Zero-dimensional mathematical object.
3. A certain place in a continuum.
4. A dot-shaped punctuation mark.
5. A small spot, mark or feature which does not bear any details.
6. The narrow, acute end of an object of variable thickness.
7. To indicate with a pointy object; to direct into a position.
8. To indicate a person, thing, direction, etc. e.g. with a finger.

1. Term used in GIS technologies in the vector type of internal data organization: spatial data are divided into point, line and polygon types.
2. The descendants of one individual.
3. A succession of notes forming a distinctive sequence.
4. A measure of length equal to one twelfth of an inch.
5. An infinitely long, infinitely thin, not bent line in geometry.
6. A mark that is long relative to its width.

1. In the vector type of GIS internal data organization spatial data are conveniently divided into point, line and polygon types. Some vector GIS store information in the form of points, line segments and point pairs; others maintain close lists of points defining polygon regions.
2. Geometrical figure that is circumscribed by straight lines.
One of the two major types of internal data organization used in GIS.

1. A distinctive feature of an object. In mapping and GIS applications, the objects are points, lines, or polygons that represent features such as sampling locations, section corners (points); roads and streams (lines); lakes, forest and soil types (polygons). These attributes can be further divided into classes such as tree species Douglas-fir and ponderosa pine) for forest types and paved and gravel for road types. Multiple attributes are generally associated with objects that are located on a single map layer.\n(Source: FORUMT)
2. To credit something to.
3. To attribute or credit to.
4. To associate ownership of (something) to someone.
The transformation to digital form of data collected by remote sensing, traditional field and documentary methods and of existing historical data such as paper maps, charts, and publications.

A process used to estimate an intermediate value of one (dependent) variable which is a function of a second (independent) variable when values of the dependent variable corresponding to several discrete values of the independent variable are known.\n(Source: MGH)
A system of uniformly spaced perpendicular lines and horizontal lines running north and south, and east and west on a map, chart, or aerial photograph; used in locating points.
The line demarcating recognized limits of established political units.
A representation of the globe constructed on a plane with lines representative of and corresponding to the meridians and parallels of the curved surface of the earth.
An angular distance in degrees north or south of the equator (latitude 0), equal to the angle subtended at the centre of the globe by the meridian between the equator and the point in question.

Distance in degrees east or west of the prime meridian at 0 measured by the angle between the plane of the prime meridian and that of the meridian through the point in question, or by the corresponding time difference.
A laboratory where GIS data drawn from different sources are stored, handled, analyzed and updated.\n(Source: GILP96a)
Any subterranean or below-ground site in which solid, or other, waste is deposited without environmental controls.
The art of purchasing and selling goods from an economics perspective or a perspective involving the scientific study of the production, distribution, and consumption of goods and services.
The power of discouraging actions or preventing occurrences by instilling the fear of punishment.

The most valuable of the marine mineral resources is petroleum. About 15% of the world's oil is produced offshore, and extraction capabilities are advancing. One of the largest environmental impacts of deep sea mining are discharged sediment plumes which disperse with ocean currents and thus may negatively influence the marine ecosystem. Coal deposits known as extensions of land deposits , are mined under the sea floor in Japan and England.\n(Source: PARCOR /  ERIB)
Manure that contains between 12-20% dry matter, and therefore are too solid for pumping, but too liquid for stacking.
The provision of heating fuel, coal or other heating source materials, or the amount of heating capacity, for the use of a specific local community.\n(Source: ISEP)

1. A person or business that specializes in the shipment and receiving of goods.
2. A person or company that organizes shipments for individuals or other companies.
Procedure that allows a request, signed by a group of people, to activate a public voting.
Any shelter or protection from distress or danger located in a predominantly mountainous area.\n(Source: RHW)
Research involving studies of all aspects of environmental conditions beyond the atmosphere of the earth.

A series of publications produced by the International Union for the Conservation of Nature and Natural Resources (IUCN) which provides an inventory on the threat to rare plants and animal species and conservation measures.
Material that prevents or reduces the transmission of electricity, heat, or sound to or from a body, device or region.\n(Source: CED)
Sizing or classifying particulate matter by suspension in a fluid (liquid or gas), the larger particulates tending to separate by sinking.\n(Source: ECHO2)

1. Not specific or particular.
2. Rank in the army and air force that is higher than colonel or brigadier, and is usually the highest rank group next to commander in chief, except in countries that use the rank of field marshal.
3. Applicable to an entire class or group.
The substance of which a product is made or composed.

1. To give something in return for something received.
2. The act or process of buying, selling or exchanging goods and services at either wholesale or retail, within a country or between countries.
3. The act or the business of buying and selling for money. Mercantile or commercial business in general or the buying and selling, or exchanging, of commodities, either by wholesale or retail within a country or between countries.\n(Source: WESTS)
4. The skilled practice of a practical occupation.

1. The people living in a certain area as a whole.
2. A group of organisms of one species, occupying a defined area.\n(Source: LBC)
3. The abstract property of a human, of living in a specific area given by precise, and well defined, borders. (This may be part of, or include, citizenship, but not necessarily so, e.g. for people having several places of residence, for foreigners, or ones officially being accepted on long-term transient living terms)
4. The totality of persons or objects with which a research study is concerned.

1. Space extending between the sun and the planets of the solar system. Interplanetary space is not empty, but contains dust, particles with an electric charge, and the magnetic field of the sun (also called the IMF, or Interplanetary Magnetic Field).
2. The location of an object or organism.
3. Relatively empty regions (with very small densities) of the universe outside the atmospheres of celestial bodies.

1. The act or means of moving tangible objects (persons or goods) from place to place. Often involves the use of some type of vehicle.
2. Transfer of mass, momentum, or energy in a system as a result of molecular agitation, including such properties as thermal conduction and viscosity.
3. To change the location or place of.
4. To delight to a high degree; to hold spellbound.

1. Significant accumulation of water, covering the Earth or another planet.
2. Common liquid (HO) which forms rain, rivers, the sea, etc., and which makes up a large part of the bodies of organisms.
3. To pour water onto the soil surrounding plants.
4. Of the eyes: To secrete tears because of an irritation caused by wind, smoke etc.
A young goat.

The waters, including ice shelves, that surround the continent of Antarctica, which comprise the southernmost parts of the Pacific, Atlantic and Indian oceans, and also the Ross, Amundsen, Bellingshausen and Weddell seas.

1. A group of mechanical or electrical parts or machines arranged to perform or assist a particular function.
2. The mechanic part of a device.
The social study of the production, distribution, and consumption of wealth.
Any one of the monatomic gaseous elements forming group 18 (formerly group 0) of the periodic table.
An animal that feeds on plants.
An indefinite large number of.

1. The first natural number (1).
2. One certain or particular.
3. The cardinal number that directly follows zero and precedes two, represented in Roman numerals as I, and in Arabic numerals as 1.
4. An unspecified individual.
5. The symbol representing the number 1.
6. Being the only representative of its kind.
7. Forming a whole.
8. The same in substance or being, in relation to two or more things or persons.
9. Identical in nature.
10. United in feeling, opinion, purpose, attitude.
11. A note or coin worth one unit of a currency.
12. One person or thing, identified in context.
13. A single individual, as opposed to none.
14. An individual among many.
15. A person or thing of the kind already mentioned.
16. A person or thing having the characteristic mentioned.
17. A person called...
18. Any person in general, including the speaker.
19. An individual..., a specific ...
20. The single, special individual
21. The digit "1".

1. Two human beings, at least one of whom is a male.
2. The second natural number (2).
3. The cardinal number occurring after one and before three, represented in Roman numerals as II and in Arabic numerals as 2.
4. The digit "2".

1. A member of the human species.
2. The generic name for a piece used in board games.
3. All human beings.
4. An adult human member of the sex that begets young by fertilizing ova.
All human beings.
A married woman.
The male partner in a marriage.

1. Three human beings, at least one of whom is a male.
2. The cardinal number occurring after two and before four, represented in Roman numerals as III, in Arabic numerals as 3.
3. The digit "3".
4. The third natural number (3).
A chess piece, the least valuable one.

1. The result of the printing process; something in printed or published form.
2. To press something onto or into a surface, usually with a press.
3. To reproduce a document with black or color ink using a printer.
4. Concrete result of the reproduction process of an image by means of different techniques.
5. To produce a positive image on photographic paper from a negative.
A branching, hair-like structure that grows on the skin of birds and protects them against coldness and water and allows their wings to create lift.

1. Of a great size; the weakest sense of great size.
2. Having relevant and crucial value.
3. (for abstract matters) of larger than normal size.
4. In a major way.

1. Having much distance from one terminating point on an object or an area to another terminating point.
2. Having relatively great height.
3. Of relatively great duration.
4. Of a specified linear extent or duration.
5. To have a yearning desire.
6. Qualifying a measure of length, to indicate that it is greater than stated, or is felt by the speaker to be excessive in duration.
7. Having a shape with one dimension of much greater length than the others.
8. Having (a specified) distance from end to end.
9. Of something consisting of a series of items (like a list, a sentence, a literary work): having a great extent from the start to the end.
10. That which has been so for a long time.
11. A person who buys a financial security such as a stock, commodity or currency, with the expectation that it will rise in value
12. Extending to a great distance.
13. For or during a long time.
14. Having a financial position in a security so as to profit if the price of the security goes up.

1. The exterior covering of the trunk and branches of a tree.
2. The short, loud, explosive sound produced by a dog.
3. To produce a loud, short, explosive sound similar to that of a dog.
4. A sailing ship with three or more masts, fore-and-aft sails on the aftermost mast and square sails on all other masts.

1. The flexible muscular organ in the mouth that is used to move food around, for tasting and that is moved into various positions to modify the flow of air from the lungs in order to produce different sounds.
2. In a shoe, the flap of material that goes between the laces and the foot.
3. A person's manner of speaking.
A common four-legged animal (Felis silvestris) that is often kept as a household pet.

1. Four human beings, at least one of whom is a male.
2. The fourth natural number (4).
3. The cardinal number occurring after three and before five, represented in Roman numerals as IV, in Arabic numerals as 4.
4. The digit "4".

1. Five human beings, at least one of whom is a male.
2. The cardinal number occurring after four and before six, represented in Roman numerals as V, in Arabic numerals as 5.
3. The digit "5".
4. The fifth natural number (5).

1. The speaker or writer referring to himself or herself alone.
2. The capitalized version of the ninth letter of the Latin alphabet.
Of a physical object, having great weight.
Not large or big; small in size.

1. The second person singular feminine subject pronoun.
2. The second person singular masculine subject pronoun.
3. The person addressed as the subject.
4. The person addressed.

1. Another person; the person previously mentioned.
2. A male other; the male previously mentioned; himself.  \n3rd person singular masculine subject pronoun.

1. exclusive "we": I and at least one other person, but not the addressed person (you)\n\n(pronoun 1st person plural without 2nd person)
2. inclusive "we": I and at least one other person, including the addressed person(s)\n(pronoun 1st person plural with 2nd person)
3. The speaker or writer and at least one other person.

1. The second person plural feminine subject pronoun.
2. The second person singular feminine subject pronoun.
3. The second person singular masculine subject pronoun.
4. The second person plural masculine subject pronoun.
5. The second person singular masculine object pronoun.
6. The second person plural masculine object pronoun.
7. The second person plural feminine object pronoun.
8. The person addressed as the subject.
9. The group of persons addressed.
10. The person addressed.
11. An unspecified individual.
12. Used before epithets for emphasis.

1. [A group of others previously mentioned.]
2. The previously mentioned persons.
3. The things previously mentioned.
4. Form in its third person plural of the personal pronoun that designates more than one male person (or male animals), which have already been mentioned previously.
5. The third person plural of the personal pronoun that designates more than one female person or animal, which have already been mentioned previously.
6. An unknown unnamed anonymous authority, ruling body, shaping or governing force, be it real or fictional, working openly or secretly.
7. The third person plural of the personal pronoun that designates more than one person or animal, thing or idea which have already been mentioned previously.

1. [Something that is farther than "this" but nearer than "that".]
2. [Used to refer to something between the speaker and the listener.]
3. The indicated object, item, etc.
4. An indicated thing that is near in space or in mind, as having been just mentioned.
A sailing ship with three or more masts, fore-and-aft sails on the aftermost mast and square sails on all other masts.

1. The indicated item (at a distance from the speaker, next to the listener).
2. The indicated item (at a distance from the speaker, or previously mentioned, or at another time).
3. Demonstrative pronoun (feminine, singular): the indicated thing is implied, since it is previously mentioned. Collocation: that of; to that of.
4. In the same manner or to the same extent as mentioned before.

1. A mature fertilized plant ovule, consisting of an embryo and its food store surrounded by a protective seed coat (testa).
2. Anything that provides inspiration for later work.
3. To remove the seeds from.
4. To place seeds in or on the ground for future growth.
5. One of the outstanding players in a tournament.

1. A fluid connective tissue consisting of the plasma and cells that circulate in the blood vessels.
2. The descendants of one individual.

1. A woman who has at least one child.
2. A female parent.
3. A woman acting like a mother.
4. A female ancestor (usually in reference to Eve).
5. Term of address to an old or elderly woman.
6. The female head of a religious organization.
7. A woman who runs a brothel.
8. A term of address to someone who is a female parent (a biological mother or a woman with parental responsibility).
9. The female animal that gave birth to an animal.
10. The source of something.
11. A country, region, etc. in relation to its inhabitants.
12. The Christian Church (usually as "holy mother")
13. The source of a substance, structure, object.
14. The first mold from which other molds are made for the manufacturing of music discs.
15. Give birth to.

A persistent organochlorine insecticide, also known as dichlorodiphenyltrichloroethane, that was introduced in the 1940s and used widely because of its persistence (meaning repeated applications were unnecessary), its low toxicity to mammals and its simplicity and cheapness of manufacture. It became dispersed all over the world and, with other organochlorines, had a disruptive effect on species high in food chains, especially on the breeding success of certain predatory birds. DDT is very stable, relatively insoluble in water, but highly soluble in fats. Health effects on humans are not clear, but it is less toxic than related compounds. It is poisonous to other vertebrates, especially fish, and is stored in the fatty tissue of animals as sublethal amounts of the less toxic DDE. Because of its effects on wildlife its use in most countries is now forbidden or strictly limited.\n(Source: MGH /  ALL)

The principal material of inheritance. It is found in chromosomes and consists of molecules that are long unbranched chains made up of many nucleotides. Each nucleotide is a combination of phosphoric acid, the monosaccharide deoxyribose and one of four nitrogenous bases: thymine, cytosine, adenine or guanine. The number of possible arrangements of nucleotides along the DNA chain is immense. Usually two DNA strands are linked together in parallel by specific base-pairing and are helically coiled. Replication of DNA molecules is accomplished by separation of the two strands, followed by the building up of matching strands by means of base-pairing, using the two halves as templates. By a mechanism involving RNA, the structure of DNA is translated into the structure of proteins during their synthesis from amino acids.\n(Source: ALL)

1. A mythical creature of Germanic mythology. In Norse mythology they were originally minor gods of nature and fertility. They are often pictured as youthful-seeming men and women of great beauty living in forests and other natural places, underground, or in wells and springs. They have been portrayed to be long-lived or immortal and they have magical powers attributed to them.
2. One of the archetypal races of modern fantasy literature, most notably the "Lord of the Rings" cycle by J.R.R. Tolkien. Usually, they are conceived as beings similar in appearance to humans with pointy ears. Compared to humans, they are depicted as fairer and wiser, with greater spiritual powers, keener senses, and a closer empathy with nature.
3. A playable race in the fantasy roleplaying game Dungeons and Dragons and similar games. They have a slighter build than humans and pointy ears, and are generally more agile. They have a reputation as good wizards and archers.

The body's ability to fight or prevent a specific infection. This
ability can be acquired either actively (by having and recovering from an infection or by being vaccinated against an infec
tion) or passively (by receiving antibodies from an outside
source, such as from breast milk or donated blood components). (Source: AIDSinfo)

An enzyme normally present in certain cells within the liver,
bone, kidney, intestine, and placenta. When cells are destroyed
in those tissues, the enzyme leaks into the blood, and levels rise
in proportion to the severity of the condition. Measurement of
this enzyme is one way to evaluate the health of the liver.
(source: AIDSinfo)

ness, or unconsciousness. Anaphylaxis can be triggered by
foods, drugs, insect stings, or exertion.

The deliberate, programmed death of a cell. Apoptosis occurs
as a normal part of life and helps the body stay healthy. If cells

with HIV), the body orders those cells to die in order to contain the disease.

PML is considered an AIDS-defining condition in people with HIV.\n(source: AIDSinfo)

A sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. In the early stage of syphilis, a genital or mouth sore called a chancre develops, but eventually disappears on its own. However, if the disease is not treated, the infection can progress over years to affect the heart and central nervous system. Syphilis can also be transmitted from an infected mother to her fetus during pregnancy, with serious health consequences for the infant.

A sexually transmitted disease (STD) caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Many people with gonorrhea have no symptoms. 1. Paraffins. A homologous series of saturated hydrocarbons having the general formula CnH2n+2. Their systematic names end in -ane. They are chemically inert, stable, and flammable. The first four members of the series (methane, ethane, propane, butane) are gases at ordinary temperatures; the next eleven are liquids, and form the main constituents of paraffin oil; the higher members are solids. Paraffin waxs consists mainly of higher alkanes.\n(Source: UVAROV)
2. A group of high molecular weight alkane hydrocarbons with the general formula CnH2n+2, where n is between 22 and 27. Paraffin is also a technical name for an alkane in general, but in most cases it refers specifically to a linear, or normal alkane. It is mostly found as a white, odorless, tasteless, waxy solid, with a melting point between 47C and 65C. It is insoluble in water, but soluble in ether, benzene, and certain esters. Paraffin is unaffected by most common chemical reagents but oxidizes readily.

a civilization that grew from a small agricultural community founded on the Italian Peninsula in the 9th century BC to a large empire straddling the Mediterranean Sea. In its 12 centuries of existence, Roman civilization shifted from a monarchy, to a republic based on a combination of oligarchy and democracy, to an autocratic empire. It came to dominate Western Europe and the area surrounding the Mediterranean Sea through conquest and assimilation. (source: Wikipedia).

1. The western half of the Roman Empire, from its division by Diocletian in 286. Its capital was in Mediolanum (modern Milan), until it was moved to Ravenna in 402. (source: Wikipedia)
2. The western half of the Roman Empire which emerged after the division in 395 AD and ended in 476.

1. The eastern part of the Roman Empire after its division in the 3rd century AD. Its capital city was Constantinople (or New Rome). It represented an administrative division of the Roman Empire, but after the fall of the western part it survived until the fall of Constantinople in 1453. (source: Wikipedia)
2. Empire in the eastern Mediterranean which emerged from the eastern part of the Roman Empire in 395 AD and ended with the conquest of Constantinople by the Ottomans in 1453.

Paraffins. A homologous series of saturated hydrocarbons having the general formula CnH2n+2. Their systematic names end in -ane. They are chemically inert, stable, and flammable. The first four members of the series (methane, ethane, propane, butane) are gases at ordinary temperatures; the next eleven are liquids, and form the main constituents of paraffin oil; the higher members are solids.
